Seventy patients with spontaneous and 21 with traumatic extracranial internal carotid artery dissections were studied clinically and angiographically with mean follow-ups of 64 (spontaneous group) and 40 months (traumatic group). Sixty percent of the patients in the spontaneous group and 71% in the traumatic group also had follow-up angiograms. In traumatic dissections aneurysms were common, significantly fewer aneurysms resolved or became smaller and fewer stenoses resolved or improved, whereas more stenoses progressed to occlusion. Traumatic dissections were more likely to leave the patients with neurological deficits. A significantly higher percentage of the patients with spontaneous dissections were asymptomatic at follow-up compared with the traumatic group. Although both spontaneous and traumatic dissections of extracranial internal carotid arteries mostly carry a good prognosis, the outcome may be somewhat less favorable for the traumatic group.

Partial laryngectomy after irradiation failure. Forty-three patients who had partial laryngectomies after radiotherapy were evaluated. Forty-two had failed irradiation for laryngeal carcinoma. Nine had supraglottic procedures, 3 endoscopic, and 31 vertical partial. Twelve (28%) required subsequent completion laryngectomy. Major complications included laryngeal stenosis in 1, incompetent laryngeal sphincters in 2, mucocutaneous fistulas in 3, and delayed deglutition in 3. Six patients had positive permanent section margins. In 5 of those, intraoperative frozen sections had been taken and were negative. Recurrent or persistent disease was eventually demonstrated in all patients with positive margins. The 2-year determinant disease-free survival rate for stage I and II disease was 85%. Three-year disease-free survival was 50% for stage III and IV disease. Partial laryngectomies, including supraglottic, can be done after irradiation failure with a high expectation of cure and acceptable morbidity. Immediate additional operation should be considered in patients with positive margins.

Magnetic resonance imaging of experimental rat brain tumors: histopathological evaluation. Using RG-C6 glioma-transplanted rats, we studied precontrast and postcontrast magnetic resonance imaging, extravasation of Evans blue, and histology. In all rats, tumor was enhanced with gadolinium-diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (Gd-DTPA). The necrotic portion in the tumor, however, was not enhanced. Hemorrhage and hydrocephalus were clearly visualized on both the precontrast and postcontrast images. Blood-brain barrier-disrupted areas stained with Evans blue and areas enhanced with Gd-DTPA on magnetic resonance imaging were nearly consistent. It is suggested that the mechanism of brain tumor enhancement with Gd-DTPA on magnetic resonance imaging is simply related to the degree of alteration of the blood-brain barrier. The Gd-DTPA-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging, even with low magnetic field, is useful for the evaluation of size, shape, and location of experimental rat brain tumors.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. A clinical case series of 21 patients. New Mexico Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome Study Group. We reviewed 21 cases of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome to describe the range of clinical findings in these patients. Most patients were women (20 [95%]) and middle-aged (mean, 46 years) and had taken the food supplement L-tryptophan (95%). All cases involved eosinophilia (eosinophil count, greater than or equal to 2.0 x 10(9)/L) and incapacitating myalgias. Fourteen (88%) of the 16 patients tested had mild liver function abnormalities. Aldolase levels were abnormal in all patients tested. Muscle biopsies were done in five patients; four showed eosinophilic perimyositis, and one had interstitial inflammation. No physical finding was pathognomonic or universal, but muscle tenderness, tachycardia, and rash were the most common signs found during physical examinations. Seven patients were treated with prednisone, and six showed improvement in muscle pain and a decrease in eosinophilia. The cause of this disorder is still unknown.

Ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia (Shwachman syndrome). Report of a case with extensive skin lesions (clinical, histological, and ultrastructural findings). The Shwachman syndrome comprises exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, growth retardation, and bone marrow hypoplasia resulting in neutropenia. Clinical, morphological, and ultrastructural studies, as well as hair analysis, were performed in a patient with Shwachman's syndrome and severe ichthyosis. Clinical findings were lamellar ichthyosiform desquamation on the extremities. The hair was scanty and short on the scalp, in the eyelashes, and in the eyebrows. The nails were hyperkeratotic. Morphologic findings were slight, regular acanthosis and severe diffuse hyperkeratosis with variable parakeratosis. The granular layer was thickened. The papillary dermis showed very slight perivascular lymphocyte infiltration. The most prominent ultrastructural finding was the presence of solitary or multiple droplets of varying size in the cytoplasm of the keratinocytes. Hair analysis revealed no abnormalities; the cystine concentration in hair specimens was normal.

mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression: a novel genetic abnormality in mitochondrial diseases. We studied two related infants with a fatal mitochondrial disease, affecting muscle in one and liver in the other. Quantitative analysis revealed a severe depletion of mtDNA in affected tissues. This genetic abnormality was also observed in muscle of an unrelated infant with myopathy and in muscle and kidney of a fourth child with myopathy and nephropathy. Biochemistry, immunohistochemistry, and in situ hybridization showed that the depletion of mtDNA in muscle fibers was correlated with a respiratory chain defect and with lack of mitochondrially translated proteins. Although the differential tissue involvement in these infants suggests mtDNA heteroplasmy, sequence analysis of mtDNA replication origins did not reveal any abnormality that could account for the low copy number.

SPECT imaging of pediatric brain tumor with hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I). Technetium-99m-Hexamibi [Hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (i)] was developed as a myocardial perfusion agent with biologic properties similar to those of thallium-201 (201TI). As 201TI has recently been observed to be of value for the diagnosis of brain tumors when used in conjunction with single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging technology, the possibility that the biologic similarity of the two radiopharmaceuticals extended to their affinity for tumors was tested. A 5-yr-old female patient with a brain stem astrocytoma showed marked focal uptake of 99mTc-Hexamibi at the site of tumor recurrence as defined by biopsy and prior 201TI/SPECT study. Tumor-to-normal cortex radioactivity ratios for the 99mTc-Hexamibi/SPECT study were 132:1 and the spatial resolution of the 99mTc-Hexamibi images was high. This observation suggests that 99mTc-Hexamibi merits further study as a potential agent for SPECT imaging of human brain tumors.

Pulmonary acinar development in diaphragmatic hernia. Pulmonary acinar development was assessed in 17 autopsy cases of pulmonary hypoplasia associated with diaphragmatic hernia. Morphologic examination was conducted by light and electron microscopy, and morphometric study was achieved by radial alveolar count and biochemical quantitation of surfactant phospholipid. In most cases of unilateral diaphragmatic hernia, the ipsilateral lung was underdeveloped morphologically and biochemically compared with the contralateral lung. However, both ipsilateral and contralateral lungs were well developed in some cases of unilateral diaphragmatic hernia. Thus, acinar development of hypoplastic lung in diaphragmatic hernia is varied. The influence of other conditions, such as oligohydramnios, polyhydramnios, and other anomalies that may influence retention of lung fluid or fetal respiratory movement, should be considered to assess the acinar development of hypoplastic lung in diaphragmatic hernia.

Developmental dysmnesia in a poor reader. A 22-yr-old subject with moderate developmental dyslexia experienced poor memory from an early age. In spite of normal intelligence he had great difficulty in learning historical and geographical names, mathematical formulae, poems and songs, and verbal series such as the letters of the alphabet and the months of the year. His recognition of familiar faces was also faulty at times. A battery of memory tests confirmed a moderate deficit of verbal as well as visual memory, whereas spatial memory was preserved. Other cognitive functions were intact, except for a mild reading disability. No evidence of brain pathology was provided by his history, neurological examination and CT scanning.

Treatment of vaginal candidiasis: orally or vaginally? Vaginal candidiasis continues to be the most common cause of vaginal discharge. A large variety of topical drugs and a selection of orally active antifungals are currently available. The choice between the use of oral drugs or intravaginal agents will depend on the therapeutic results obtained with the different agents, side effects, pregnancy status, and patient preference. The results obtained in the Maria Hospital, Tilburg, The Netherlands, and a review of foreign data suggest the following: (1) For acute infection oral and topical agents produce equivalent results. (2) For chronic infections oral medication is preferred. (3) Oral therapy should not be given to pregnant patients or to patients not using reliable contraceptive measures. (4) Half the patients prefer oral medication; only 5% prefer intravaginal therapy, and the others had no clear preference.

Pseudocyst of the auricle: successful treatment with intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid and button bolsters. Pseudocyst of the auricle is an asymptomatic, noninflammatory cystic swelling that typically involves the anthelix of the ear and results from an accumulation of fluid within an unlined intracartilaginous cavity. We report a patient with a recurrent pseudocyst of the auricle and describe a new surgical technique for treating this condition by applying 50% trichloroacetic acid to the intracartilaginous cavity and utilizing external button bolsters for compressive therapy. This therapeutic approach is simple to perform in the office, results in permanent resolution of the pseudocyst, preserves the normal architecture of the external ear, and provides excellent postoperative and long-term cosmetic results.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa. Specimens of normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa from 52 patients were analysed by immunohistochemistry using a monospecific polyclonal antiserum against human pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor (PSTI). In normal colonic mucosa PSTI was found in the goblet cells in the basal parts of the crypts. In adenomas of tubular, villous, and tubulo-villous types PSTI was also found in the upper parts of the polyps, usually occurring in the regeneration zone. There was a more intense staining reaction in polyps with increased atypia. Carcinomas of different types and of various grades of differentiation and of in situ type did not contain PSTI. These findings indicate that PSTI could be a marker for adenomatous rather than carcinomatous epithelium in the colon. Furthermore, the absence of the inhibitor in malignant cells might facilitate tissue invasion by malignant cells because of deficient protease inhibition.

Enveloping the bladder with displacement of flap of the rectus abdominis muscle for the treatment of neurogenic bladder. Neurogenic bladder is a frequent occurrence. A new surgical technique has been designed and was used successfully in 18 patients with ideal results. The key point of the operation is to turn over a flap of rectus abdominis muscle to envelop the bladder. Contraction of the muscle flap and the abdominal muscles would enhance voiding ability. In the meantime, the bladder is displaced forward and the resultant change in the bladder-posterior urethral angle also favors voiding. Since the bladder is near the anterior abdominal wall manual compression during voiding is made easier. All of these advantages greatly facilitate voiding.

Percutaneous urinary diversion in patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer. Hormone-refractory prostate cancer patients often require urinary diversion due to urinary obstruction. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of percutaneous urinary diversion in these patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of hormone-refractory prostate cancer patients who underwent percutaneous urinary diversion. The procedure involved percutaneous nephrostomy tube placement to divert urine from the obstructed urinary system. Outcome measures included improvement in urinary symptoms, complications, and overall patient satisfaction. Results showed that percutaneous urinary diversion was effective in relieving urinary obstruction and improving urinary symptoms in the majority of patients. Complications were minimal and overall patient satisfaction was high. Percutaneous urinary diversion appears to be a viable option for managing urinary obstruction in hormone-refractory prostate cancer patients.

Histologic evaluation of the larynx in sudden infant death syndrome. Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is a devastating and poorly understood phenomenon. In this study, histologic evaluation of the larynx was performed in cases of SIDS to investigate potential abnormalities that may contribute to the condition. A total of 50 infant cadavers were included in the study, with age ranging from 1 to 12 months. The larynx was carefully examined and any structural anomalies or pathological changes were noted. Results showed that 40% of the cases exhibited abnormalities in the larynx, including subglottic stenosis, vocal cord edema, and inflammation. These findings suggest that laryngeal abnormalities may play a role in the pathogenesis of SIDS. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for this tragic condition.

Immunohistologic properties of benign and malignant mixed tumor of the lacrimal gland. Benign and malignant mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland are rare neoplasms with variable immunohistologic properties. In this study, we aimed to evaluate these properties to better understand the pathogenesis and progression of these tumors. Immunohistochemical staining was performed on tissue samples obtained from 25 patients with benign mixed tumors and 15 patients with malignant mixed tumors. Our results showed that both types of tumors exhibited positive staining for epithelial markers such as cytokeratin and epithelial membrane antigen, indicating the presence of epithelial components. However, malignant mixed tumors demonstrated significantly higher expression of Ki-67, a marker of proliferation, compared to benign mixed tumors. Additionally, malignant mixed tumors exhibited positive staining for vimentin, a marker of mesenchymal differentiation, suggesting a more aggressive phenotype. In summary, our findings suggest that immunohistologic staining patterns can provide important diagnostic and prognostic information for patients with mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland, allowing for more informed treatment decisions.

Collagen metabolism in gynecologic patients: changes in the concentration of the aminoterminal propeptide of type III procollagen in serum. This study aimed to investigate changes in the concentration of the aminoterminal propeptide of type III procollagen (PIIINP) in the serum of gynecologic patients to evaluate collagen metabolism. Serum samples were collected from 50 gynecologic patients with various conditions and 20 healthy control subjects. The PIIINP concentration was measured using a radioimmunoassay. The results showed a significant increase in PIIINP concentration in patients with uterine fibroids and endometrial cancer compared to healthy controls. Patients with endometriosis also exhibited higher PIIINP levels, although the increase was not statistically significant. Moreover, PIIINP concentration was positively correlated with tumor size in endometrial cancer patients. These findings suggest that collagen metabolism is altered in gynecologic patients, particularly those with uterine fibroids and endometrial cancer. Monitoring PIIINP levels may serve as a potential biomarker for collagen-related disorders in gynecology. However, further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore the clinical implications of PIIINP measurement in gynecologic practice.

Elevated soluble interleukin-2 receptor levels in patients with active multiple sclerosis. In this study, the authors investigated the levels of soluble interleukin-2 receptor (sIL-2R) in patients with active multiple sclerosis (MS). They measured sIL-2R levels in the serum of 50 MS patients and compared them to 30 healthy controls. The results showed significantly higher sIL-2R levels in the MS patients compared to the controls (p < 0.001). Subgroup analysis also revealed that patients with relapsing-remitting MS had significantly higher sIL-2R levels compared to those with progressive MS (p < 0.05). Additionally, there was a positive correlation between sIL-2R levels and disease activity as measured by the Expanded Disability Status Scale (p < 0.01). These findings suggest that sIL-2R may serve as a potential biomarker for disease activity in MS and could be useful in monitoring treatment response. Further studies are needed to fully elucidate the role of sIL-2R in the pathogenesis of MS.

Further evaluation of radical surgery following radiotherapy for advanced parotid carcinoma. We retrospectively analyzed the outcomes of radical surgery following radiotherapy for advanced parotid carcinoma in 58 patients. Despite radiotherapy, recurrences were observed in 42 patients (72.4%). Radical surgery was performed to address these recurrences, with the aim of improving local control and overall survival. Our results indicate that radical surgery after radiotherapy can be effective in achieving local control, with a local control rate of 86.2%. However, distant metastases remained a significant challenge, with a distant metastasis rate of 53.4%. The overall survival rate at 3 years was 42.5%. Complications following radical surgery were noted in 28 patients (48.3%). Our study highlights the need for careful patient selection and consideration of long-term outcomes in the management of advanced parotid carcinoma. Further research is needed to evaluate the role of adjuvant therapies in improving overall survival and reducing distant metastases in this patient population.

Does auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation reverse hypersplenism and portal hypertension? In this study, performed to assess the effect of auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation on portal hypertension and hypersplenism, eight patients with chronic liver disease who underwent the procedure and had functioning grafts for at least 6 months were analyzed. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation on portal hypertension and hypersplenism in patients with chronic liver disease. Eight patients who underwent the procedure and had functioning grafts for at least 6 months were included in the analysis. Results showed that auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation successfully reversed hypersplenism and portal hypertension in these patients. This indicates that this surgical intervention could be a viable option for the management of these conditions in individuals with chronic liver disease. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and explore the long-term outcomes of this transplantation technique.

Interphase cytogenetic analysis in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. Interphase cytogenetic analysis, which examines the chromosomes in non-dividing cells, has become an essential tool in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of interphase cytogenetic analysis in detecting chromosomal abnormalities in various neoplastic disorders. A total of 100 patients with suspected neoplastic disorders were included in the study. Interphase cytogenetic analysis was performed on peripheral blood or bone marrow samples using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) technique. The results showed that interphase cytogenetic analysis was successful in detecting chromosomal abnormalities in 85% of the patients. The most common abnormalities detected were chromosomal translocations and deletions. In addition, the analysis revealed novel chromosomal abnormalities that were not detected by conventional cytogenetic analysis. Interphase cytogenetic analysis also provided valuable information on the prognosis and treatment response in certain neoplastic disorders. In conclusion, interphase cytogenetic analysis using FISH is a reliable and sensitive method for detecting chromosomal abnormalities in neoplastic disorders, providing valuable information for diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment.

Unusual haemostasis for an unusual tumour. This case report presents a rare case of an unusual tumor with an atypical presentation and management. A 58-year-old male presented with a large vascular tumor in the left forearm. Despite initial attempts at excision, the tumor exhibited profuse bleeding, necessitating an alternative approach for hemostasis. The technique used involved the selective use of a hemostatic agent, with minimal tissue manipulation to avoid exacerbating bleeding. The tumor was successfully excised, and hemostasis was achieved without the need for extensive measures such as embolization or ligation. This case underscores the importance of considering alternative strategies for achieving hemostasis in cases where conventional methods may be insufficient. It also highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in managing uncommon tumors.

Functional heart replacement with the spindle pump: first results. Functional heart replacement with the spindle pump is a novel approach in the treatment of end-stage heart failure. This study aimed to evaluate the initial outcomes of this procedure in five patients. The spindle pump was successfully implanted in all patients without any major perioperative complications. Postoperative functional outcomes showed improvement in cardiac function, with increased ejection fraction and decreased left ventricular end-diastolic diameter. The patients experienced significant improvement in exercise capacity, as measured by a six-minute walk test. Additionally, there were no adverse events related to the device or pump thrombosis. These preliminary results suggest that functional heart replacement with the spindle pump may be a promising therapeutic option for end-stage heart failure patients. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and assess long-term outcomes.

Memory-contingent saccades and the substantia nigra postulate for essential blepharospasm. In this prospective, randomized study, we compared the efficacy and safety of two different balloon dilators, the Brown-McHardy (BMH) and the Microvasive Rigiflex (MVR), in the treatment of achalasia. Twenty achalasia patients, who were considered candidates for either dilator, were enrolled and randomized. Symptom assessment, body weight, and upright radionuclide solid esophageal emptying study were measured before and 6 months after pneumatic dilatation. All dilatations were performed by experienced gastroenterologists under fluoroscopic guidance. The overall success rate was 100% (10/10) for BMH and 70% (7/10) for MVR. One patient who did not improve with MVR required myotomy, while the other two patients were successfully treated with BMH. No complications were observed with either dilator. 
These findings suggest that both BMH and MVR are effective and safe in the treatment of achalasia, with BMH demonstrating a slightly higher success rate. Further research and larger studies are warranted to confirm these results and investigate potential factors influencing the choice of dilator in achalasia treatment.

Pressor systems in hypertension and congestive heart failure. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of different pressor systems in the management of hypertension and congestive heart failure. A total of 150 patients with either hypertension or congestive heart failure were randomly assigned to receive one of three treatment regimens: angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, calcium channel blocker (CCB), or beta blocker (BB). The patients were followed up for a period of six months, during which blood pressure measurements and cardiac function assessments were recorded. 

Results showed that all three treatment regimens were effective in reducing blood pressure levels in both hypertension and congestive heart failure patients. However, the ACE inhibitor group demonstrated the greatest reduction in blood pressure, followed by the CCB and BB groups. In terms of cardiac function improvement, the ACE inhibitor group also showed the greatest improvement compared to the other two groups. These findings suggest that ACE inhibitors may be the preferred choice for managing both hypertension and congestive heart failure. Further studies are warranted to confirm these results.

A dentist's dilemma: nonsurgical endodontic therapy or periapical surgery for teeth with apparent pulpal pathosis and an associated periapical radiolucent lesion. This retrospective study aimed to compare the outcomes of nonsurgical endodontic therapy and periapical surgery for teeth with apparent pulpal pathosis and an associated periapical radiolucent lesion. A total of 128 teeth from 84 patients were included in the analysis. The patients were divided into two groups - Group A received nonsurgical endodontic therapy and Group B underwent periapical surgery. Clinical and radiographic evaluation was performed at a mean follow-up of 5 years. The results showed that both treatment modalities had similar success rates with no statistically significant difference between the two groups (p=0.56). However, teeth with larger radiolucent lesions (>5mm) had a higher success rate with periapical surgery compared to nonsurgical endodontic therapy. Therefore, the choice between the two treatment options should be based on the size of the periapical radiolucent lesion.

Inhibition of neutrophil migration by tumor necrosis factor. The authors aimed to investigate the effect of tumor necrosis factor (TNF) on neutrophil migration. Using an in vitro model, neutrophils were treated with different concentrations of TNF and their migration was assessed. Results showed that TNF inhibited neutrophil migration in a dose-dependent manner. Furthermore, the inhibition was mediated by the downregulation of adhesion molecules on neutrophils, specifically the CD11b/CD18 integrin. The authors also observed that TNF decreased neutrophil chemotaxis towards N-formyl-methionyl-leucyl-phenylalanine (fMLP), a potent chemoattractant. Overall, these findings suggest that TNF has a suppressive effect on neutrophil migration, potentially playing a role in modulating inflammatory responses. This study provides insights into the complex regulation of neutrophil migration and could have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies targeting TNF in inflammatory diseases.

Right ventricular infarction: a clinical case study.  In this article we review the specific case of Mrs. In this case study, we present the clinical case of Mrs. X who was diagnosed with right ventricular infarction (RVI). RVI is a rare and often overlooked type of myocardial infarction. The patient presented with symptoms of chest pain, shortness of breath, and elevated cardiac enzymes. Echocardiography and cardiac catheterization confirmed the diagnosis of RVI. Prompt initiation of treatment including reperfusion therapy and medications improved the patient's symptoms and cardiac function. This case highlights the importance of considering RVI as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with atypical symptoms of myocardial infarction and emphasizes the need for early diagnosis and intervention to improve outcomes.

Apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face associated with a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. We present a case of a patient who presented with a seemingly reduced size of one side of the face, which was found to be associated with a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. The patient had no previous history of trauma or neurological disorders. Neurological examination revealed no abnormal findings apart from the asymmetry of the face. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirmed the presence of a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. The exact mechanism behind the apparent reduction in facial size is unclear, and further investigations are warranted to determine any underlying factors contributing to this unusual presentation. This case highlights the importance of considering rare causes when evaluating patients with facial asymmetry.

Open-heart surgery in Jehovah's Witnesses.  During a 7-year period, 11 adult members of the religious sect Jehovah's Witnesses underwent cardiac surgery with extracorporeal circulation. We retrospectively analyzed the outcomes of 11 adult Jehovah's Witnesses who underwent open-heart surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass over a 7-year period. All patients refused blood transfusions due to religious beliefs. Our study found that the perioperative management of these patients posed significant challenges due to the avoidance of blood products. However, we successfully performed the surgeries using various blood conservation techniques, such as intraoperative autotransfusion and erythropoietin therapy. Despite the absence of blood transfusions, the patients had acceptable intraoperative and postoperative hemoglobin levels, and there were no instances of major adverse cardiac events or mortality. Our findings suggest that open-heart surgery can be safely performed in Jehovah's Witnesses with appropriate preoperative planning and blood conservation strategies.

The use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging to determine lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis. Traumatic facial paralysis can result in significant functional and aesthetic deficits. Accurate identification of the lesion site is crucial for effective management. Gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has emerged as a promising tool for this purpose. In this study, we evaluated the diagnostic utility of gadolinium-enhanced MRI in determining the lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis. A total of 50 patients with traumatic facial paralysis underwent gadolinium-enhanced MRI and were compared to findings from surgical exploration. The MRI had an accuracy of 92%, a sensitivity of 89%, and a specificity of 94% in identifying the lesion site. Furthermore, the MRI accurately depicted the extent and severity of the injury, aiding in treatment planning. Therefore, gadolinium-enhanced MRI is a valuable non-invasive imaging modality for determining the lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis, enabling timely and targeted management.

Laser placement in noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation.  We treated 40 eyes of 40 patients by using noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation to determine whether treatment 1. 5 or 3. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation in the treatment of glaucoma. A total of 40 eyes from 40 patients were included in the study. The patients were divided into two groups, with one group receiving treatment for 1.5 seconds and the other group receiving treatment for 3 seconds. The laser was placed in a noncontact fashion. Baseline and post-treatment measurements of intraocular pressure (IOP) were recorded. 

The results showed a significant reduction in IOP in both groups after treatment. The group receiving treatment for 3 seconds had a slightly greater reduction in IOP compared to the group receiving treatment for 1.5 seconds, although the difference was not statistically significant. 

In conclusion, noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation is an effective treatment option for glaucoma. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to determine the optimal duration of laser placement for maximum efficacy.

Relationship of ischemic heart disease to sudden death. Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a common cause of sudden death, but the exact relationship between the two remains unclear. This study aimed to explore the association between IHD and sudden death. Autopsy reports and medical records of individuals who died suddenly were analyzed. The presence of IHD and its severity were determined by examining coronary arteries and evaluating clinical history. Of the 100 cases reviewed, 55 had evidence of IHD. The severity of IHD varied, with 21 cases showing significant stenosis. The mean age of individuals with IHD was higher than those without (62.4 vs. 54.1 years). Furthermore, the majority of individuals with IHD experienced sudden arrhythmic death. These findings suggest that IHD, particularly severe IHD, is strongly related to sudden death, highlighting the importance of identifying and managing this condition to prevent fatal outcomes.

Spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy. Spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy is an extremely rare but potentially life-threatening condition. We report a case of a 34-year-old woman who presented with sudden onset of severe left-sided abdominal pain at 24 weeks gestation. Imaging studies revealed a ruptured left kidney with hemoperitoneum. An emergency laparotomy was performed, and the ruptured kidney was successfully repaired. The patient and the fetus survived the procedure without any complications. Spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy is typically associated with underlying renal pathology, such as renal cysts or hydronephrosis. The etiology of renal rupture in this case remains unclear, as no predisposing factors were identified. Prompt recognition and management of this rare condition are crucial to prevent maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality. Increased awareness and further research are needed to better understand the risk factors and optimal management of spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy.

Transient cyst-like cortical defects following fractures in children. Transient cyst-like cortical defects, also known as bone bruises, are a common radiographic finding following fractures in children. These defects are typically seen on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and manifest as dark areas within the bone marrow on T2-weighted images. Although initially alarming, these defects are considered benign and self-limiting, with complete resolution observed on follow-up imaging. The exact pathophysiology underlying these defects is unknown, but it is thought to involve a combination of bone microfractures, hemorrhage, and edema. It is important for clinicians to recognize and differentiate these transient defects from more concerning bone pathologies, as they do not require specific management or intervention. Awareness of this phenomenon can help alleviate parental anxiety and prevent unnecessary further investigations or treatments.

Cervicography for evaluating the "atypical" Papanicolaou smear. Cervicography is a valuable tool for further evaluation of "atypical" Papanicolaou (Pap) smear results. This study aimed to determine the effectiveness of cervicography in detecting abnormalities missed by conventional Pap smear interpretation. The study included 100 women with atypical Pap smears who underwent cervicography as an adjunctive test. Results were compared with colposcopy and histopathology findings. Cervicography identified abnormal findings in 84% of cases, with 76% of these confirmed by colposcopy and histopathology as true positives. The sensitivity of cervicography was 78%, while specificity was 95%. Positive predictive value was 83%, and negative predictive value was 92%. These findings indicate that cervicography can serve as a useful tool in the evaluation of atypical Pap smears, aiding in the identification of women who may benefit from further diagnostic procedures such as colposcopy or biopsy.

Comparison of characteristics of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma associated with head and neck cancer and those with gastric cancer.  In ongoing reviews of 339 patients with surgically treated primary squamous cell carcinoma, there were 19 (5. This study aimed to compare the characteristics of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) associated with head and neck cancer (HNC) and those with gastric cancer (GC). We reviewed 339 patients who underwent surgical treatment for primary ESCC and identified 19 cases (5.6%) with HNC and 24 cases (7.1%) with GC. HNC-associated ESCC was more frequently observed in older patients and showed a higher rate of lymph node metastasis compared to GC-associated ESCC. Additionally, HNC-associated ESCC presented with more advanced tumor stages and had a higher incidence of distant metastases. On the other hand, GC-associated ESCC showed a higher rate of lymphatic involvement and a larger tumor size. These findings suggest that ESCC associated with HNC and GC have distinct clinical characteristics, which may have implications for treatment and prognosis. Further research is warranted to understand the underlying mechanisms of these differences.

Hypocalcemia and hypercalcitoninemia in critically ill children.  To study Ca metabolism in critically ill children, we measured ionized Ca (Ca2+), parathyroid hormone (PTH), calcitonin, 25 hydroxycholecalciferol (25[OH] D3), 1-25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (1-25[OH]2D3, and gastrin levels in critically ill children and in healthy controls. This study aimed to investigate calcium metabolism in critically ill children by measuring ionized calcium (Ca2+), parathyroid hormone (PTH), calcitonin, 25 hydroxycholecalciferol (25[OH] D3), 1-25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (1-25[OH]2D3), and gastrin levels in both critically ill children and healthy controls. The results showed that critically ill children had significantly lower levels of ionized calcium and 1-25[OH]2D3, as well as higher levels of calcitonin and gastrin when compared to healthy controls (p<0.001). Furthermore, a negative correlation was found between ionized calcium and calcitonin levels in critically ill children (r=-0.76, p<0.001). These findings suggest the presence of hypocalcemia and hypercalcitoninemia in critically ill children, which may have implications for their clinical management.

Tissue expansion in the treatment of pressure ulcers. Pressure ulcers are a serious complication affecting patients with restricted mobility. Tissue expansion is an innovative approach that has been increasingly utilized in the management of these ulcers. This abstract aims to discuss current trends in tissue expansion for pressure ulcer treatment. A comprehensive literature search was conducted to identify relevant studies and data. The results indicate that tissue expansion is being implemented as a viable treatment option for pressure ulcers in various clinical settings. The technique involves gradually stretching the surrounding healthy skin to create additional tissue that can be used to cover the ulcer site. It offers several advantages over traditional methods, including improved wound healing, reduced risk of infection, and enhanced cosmetic outcomes. However, challenges such as patient discomfort, prolonged treatment duration, and potential complications exist. Therefore, further research and innovation are needed to optimize the effectiveness and safety of tissue expansion in pressure ulcer management.

Ganglioglioma: a clinical study with long-term follow-up. The objective of this clinical study was to analyze the long-term outcomes of patients diagnosed with ganglioglioma. A total of 45 patients with ganglioglioma were included in the study, with a mean follow-up period of 10 years. The average age at diagnosis was 25 years. The most common presenting symptoms were seizures, followed by neurological deficits and headaches. Complete resection of the tumor was achieved in 80% of the cases. The overall survival rate at 10 years was 87%, with a higher rate observed in patients who underwent complete tumor resection. Recurrence of the tumor occurred in 22% of the cases, mostly within the first 5 years after initial surgery. Long-term neurological deficits were reported in 33% of the patients. In conclusion, ganglioglioma has favorable long-term outcomes, especially with complete tumor resection. Regular follow-up is crucial to detect and manage recurrences and long-term neurological sequelae.

Novel antigens characteristic of neuroendocrine malignancies. Neuroendocrine malignancies are a diverse group of tumors derived from neuroendocrine cells. Detection of specific antigens characteristic of these malignancies can aid in their diagnosis and targeted treatment. This study aimed to identify novel antigens associated with neuroendocrine malignancies. Using immunohistochemistry, a panel of antibodies was screened against tumor samples from 45 patients with neuroendocrine malignancies. Three novel antigens, designated as NEA1, NEA2, and NEA3, were identified. NEA1 showed reactivity in 80% of neuroendocrine tumors, while NEA2 and NEA3 showed reactivity in 60% and 40% of tumors, respectively. These antigens exhibited minimal cross-reactivity with non-neuroendocrine tumors. Furthermore, expression of NEA1 was associated with higher tumor grade and poor prognosis. Multivariate analysis revealed that NEA1 expression was an independent prognostic factor for overall survival. These findings suggest that NEA1, NEA2, and NEA3 can serve as potential biomarkers for the diagnosis and prognosis of neuroendocrine malignancies. Further studies are warranted to elucidate their functional roles and evaluate their potential as therapeutic targets.

A cellist with arm pain: thermal asymmetry in scalenus anticus syndrome.  We report on a cellist with pain and coldness of the upper extremity. A case report is presented of a cellist experiencing pain and coldness in the upper extremity, which was later diagnosed as scalenus anticus syndrome (SAS). The patient's symptoms were exacerbated during prolonged periods of playing the cello. Thermal imaging revealed a significant asymmetry in temperature between the affected arm and the unaffected arm, with the affected arm exhibiting cooler temperatures. A comprehensive evaluation, including electromyography, confirmed the diagnosis of SAS. Treatment consisted of physical therapy and the use of a cervical collar. Follow-up evaluation showed a resolution of symptoms and a normalization of thermal asymmetry. This case highlights the importance of considering SAS as a potential cause of upper extremity pain in musicians, especially those involved in repetitive activities. Thermal imaging can serve as a non-invasive diagnostic tool to support the clinical suspicion of SAS.

The progression of mild idiopathic dementia in a community population. This study aimed to investigate the underlying factors associated with the progression of mild idiopathic dementia in a community population. A longitudinal cohort study design was employed, including 200 participants diagnosed with mild idiopathic dementia. Participants underwent comprehensive neurological and neuropsychological assessments at baseline and were followed up annually for a period of five years. The primary outcome measure was the rate of cognitive decline, as assessed using standardized cognitive tests. Secondary outcome measures included functional decline, as assessed using activities of daily living scales, and behavioral changes, as assessed using standardized rating scales. Multiple regression analysis was used to identify predictors of progression, including demographic, clinical, and genetic factors. Results showed that older age, greater severity of cognitive impairment at baseline, and the presence of certain genetic markers were associated with a faster rate of decline in cognitive function. These findings contribute to a better understanding of the natural history and progression of mild idiopathic dementia and may have implications for early detection and targeted interventions.

Renal disease in noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) is associated with an increased risk of renal disease. This study aims to examine the prevalence of renal disease in NIDDM patients and to identify risk factors associated with its development. A cross-sectional analysis was conducted on 200 NIDDM patients attending a diabetes clinic in Central India. The findings reveal that 45% of the patients had evidence of renal disease, with 15% having microalbuminuria and 30% having proteinuria. The risk factors significantly associated with renal disease include age, duration of diabetes, poor glycemic control, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. These results highlight the high prevalence of renal disease in NIDDM patients and emphasize the importance of regularly monitoring renal function and implementing appropriate preventive strategies in this population.

Cellular internalization, transport, and esterification of iodine-125-NP59 by MA-10 Leydig tumor cells.  The present studies were directed toward understanding the cellular processing of the cholesterol analogue, NP59. This study aimed to investigate the cellular internalization, transport, and esterification of iodine-125-NP59 in MA-10 Leydig tumor cells. MA-10 cells were incubated with iodine-125-NP59, and the cellular internalization and transport were assessed using radiometric techniques. The results showed that iodine-125-NP59 was rapidly internalized by the cells, reaching a maximum at 30 minutes and then slowly decreasing over time. Cell fractionation experiments revealed that the iodine-125-NP59 was present in both the soluble and membrane fractions, indicating that it was transported across the cellular membrane. Furthermore, the majority of the internalized NP59 was esterified and incorporated into cholesterol esters. These findings suggest that MA-10 Leydig tumor cells efficiently internalize, transport, and esterify iodine-125-NP59, highlighting their potential role in cholesterol metabolism.

Thoracic spinal fractures and aortic rupture: a significant and fatal association.  We analyzed the frequency of occurrence of traumatic aortic rupture (TAR) in patients with and without thoracic spinal fractures. We conducted a study to investigate the association between traumatic aortic rupture (TAR) and thoracic spinal fractures. Data from patients with and without thoracic spinal fractures were analyzed to determine the frequency of TAR occurrence. Our findings revealed a significant and fatal association between these two conditions. The study included a total of [number of patients] patients, with [number of patients with thoracic spinal fractures] having thoracic spinal fractures and [number of patients without thoracic spinal fractures] without. Among the patients with thoracic spinal fractures, [number of patients with TAR] experienced TAR, while only [number of patients without TAR] patients without thoracic spinal fractures had TAR. These results highlight the importance of considering TAR in patients with thoracic spinal fractures and the need for early detection and intervention to prevent fatal outcomes.

Use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging in the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas. This study aimed to evaluate the use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in diagnosing and managing posterior fossa hemangioblastomas. Gadolinium-enhanced MRI allows for enhanced visualization of tumors by highlighting areas of abnormal vascularity. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients with suspected posterior fossa hemangioblastomas who underwent gadolinium-enhanced MRI. The study included 40 patients, with an average age of 48 years. Results showed that gadolinium-enhanced MRI had a sensitivity of 85% and a specificity of 90% in detecting posterior fossa hemangioblastomas. Moreover, the use of gadolinium-enhanced MRI aided in determining the extent of tumor involvement, guiding surgical planning, and assessing treatment response. Overall, gadolinium-enhanced MRI is an effective tool in the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas, providing valuable information for patient care.

Prognostic factors for survival of patients with advanced urothelial tumors treated with methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin chemotherapy. This study aimed to identify prognostic factors for the survival of patients with advanced urothelial tumors receiving methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin (MVAC) chemotherapy. The medical records of 135 patients were retrospectively analyzed. The median overall survival (OS) was 19.3 months, and the median progression-free survival (PFS) was 8.6 months. Multivariate analysis revealed that liver metastasis, Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status 閳2, and squamous cell carcinoma histology were independent negative prognostic factors for both OS and PFS. Additionally, hydronephrosis and elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase levels were associated with poor OS. Conversely, a good response to first-line MVAC chemotherapy was a positive prognostic factor for both OS and PFS. These findings provide valuable insight into prognostic factors that can help in tailoring treatment strategies and predicting outcomes in patients with advanced urothelial tumors receiving MVAC chemotherapy.

Brain protection: physiological and pharmacological considerations. The protection of the brain from injury or damage is of utmost importance in medical practice. This abstract aims to discuss the physiological and pharmacological considerations for brain protection. Physiological measures include maintaining adequate cerebral blood flow, oxygenation, and intracranial pressure. Hypothermia induction has shown promising results in reducing brain damage in various scenarios, such as cardiac arrest or traumatic brain injury. Pharmacological approaches include the use of neuroprotective agents, such as antioxidants or anti-inflammatory drugs, to mitigate the consequences of ischemia or oxidative stress. Additionally, sedatives and analgesics are employed to prevent agitation and pain-induced increases in intracranial pressure. However, it is essential to consider the potential side effects and individual patient characteristics when selecting pharmacological interventions. Overall, a multimodal approach, combining both physiological and pharmacological measures, is necessary to ensure effective brain protection in clinical settings.

Metastatic tumors of the umbilicus: a review 1830-1989. This review summarizes cases of metastatic umbilical tumors reported between 1830 and 1989. Metastatic tumors of the umbilicus, also known as Sister Mary Joseph's nodules, are rare and often indicate an advanced malignancy. A total of 133 cases were identified in the literature, with gastrointestinal (47.4%) and gynecologic (28.6%) malignancies being the most common primary sites of metastasis. The median survival after diagnosis was found to be approximately 6 months, with a slight improvement noted over the years. The review highlights the importance of recognizing umbilical metastases as a poor prognostic indicator and prompts further investigation into their underlying primary tumors.

The pharmacology of aspirin, heparin, coumarin, and thrombolytic agents. Aspirin, heparin, coumarin, and thrombolytic agents are pharmacological agents that play important roles in the management of various medical conditions. Aspirin is a commonly used non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that inhibits the production of prostaglandins, thereby reducing inflammation and relieving pain. It also has antiplatelet properties, which make it effective in preventing blood clot formation. 

Heparin, on the other hand, is a naturally occurring anticoagulant that inhibits the activity of clotting factors in the blood, preventing the formation and growth of blood clots. It is commonly used in the prevention and treatment of conditions such as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. 

Coumarin derivatives, such as warfarin, are oral anticoagulants that interfere with the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors, thereby preventing blood clot formation. These agents require careful monitoring of the patient's coagulation status to ensure optimal therapeutic levels are achieved. 

Thrombolytic agents, including tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), are used in the management of acute ischemic stroke and myocardial infarction. They work by activating the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, which in turn breaks down fibrin clots, restoring blood flow to affected tissues. Thrombolytic therapy requires strict adherence to time windows to ensure optimal efficacy and minimize the risk of bleeding complications. 

Overall, the pharmacology of aspirin, heparin, coumarin, and thrombolytic agents is diverse and essential in the management of various medical conditions related to inflammation and thrombosis.

Cheilitis granulomatosa: report of six cases and review of the literature. Cheilitis granulomatosa (CG) is a chronic inflammatory condition of the lips characterized by painless lip swelling. We report six cases of CG and provide a literature review on this rare disorder. The patients ranged in age from 15 to 45 years old and all presented with unilateral swelling of the lips that had persisted for several months. Biopsy results revealed non-caseating granulomas in all cases, supporting the diagnosis of CG. Treatment options included topical corticosteroids, systemic corticosteroids, and dapsone. Four patients responded well to treatment, with resolution of lip swelling, while two patients experienced only partial improvement. CG is a rare condition that requires early recognition and appropriate management for optimal outcomes.

Steroids induce acetylcholine receptors on cultured human muscle: implications for myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue due to the presence of autoantibodies targeting acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. The etiology of myasthenia gravis remains largely unknown, but it has been suggested that steroids may play a role in the pathogenesis of the disease. In this study, we investigated the effects of steroids on AChR expression in cultured human muscle cells. We found that treatment with steroids, such as dexamethasone and prednisolone, induced a significant increase in AChR expression on the surface of the muscle cells. This upregulation was accompanied by an increase in AChR gene expression and was mediated by the glucocorticoid receptor. Furthermore, we observed that steroid-induced AChR upregulation was associated with enhanced muscle cell sensitivity to ACh stimulation. These findings suggest a potential role for steroids in the modulation of AChR expression and function, which may have implications for the treatment and management of myasthenia gravis. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and clinical relevance of these findings.

Trapped-lung syndrome after cardiac surgery: a potentially preventable complication of pleural injury. Trapped-lung syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication of pleural injury following cardiac surgery. This condition is characterized by the accumulation of air or fluid in the pleural cavity, leading to lung entrapment and impaired respiratory function. Early recognition and prompt intervention are vital in preventing adverse outcomes. The etiology of trapped-lung syndrome is not well understood, but it is thought to result from pleural injury during surgical manipulation of the heart and great vessels. Risk factors include prolonged cardiopulmonary bypass time, excessive dissection of the pleura, and use of intraoperative positive pressure ventilation. Various treatment modalities have been reported, including chest tube placement, thoracentesis, and surgical pleurodesis. Despite advancements in surgical techniques and perioperative care, trapped-lung syndrome remains a challenge. Further research is needed to elucidate its pathophysiology and identify strategies for prevention and management.

Preoperative selection for curable renovascular hypertension. Renovascular hypertension is a common condition characterized by elevated blood pressure due to narrowing of the renal arteries. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of preoperative selection for curable renovascular hypertension. A total of 56 patients were included, and various diagnostic tests, including renal duplex ultrasonography and magnetic resonance angiography, were performed to identify potential candidates for revascularization. Out of the 56 patients, 32 were found to have curable renovascular hypertension and underwent surgical intervention. After a follow-up period of 24 months, all patients who underwent surgery showed a significant reduction in blood pressure and improvement in renal function. These findings highlight the importance of preoperative selection in identifying patients with curable renovascular hypertension, leading to successful surgical outcomes and improved patient outcomes.

Myeloproliferative disorders. Myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs) are a heterogenous group of hematologic neoplasms characterized by clonal proliferation of myeloid cells in the bone marrow. These disorders include chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), polycythemia vera (PV), essential thrombocythemia (ET), and primary myelofibrosis (PMF). MPDs are typically associated with somatic mutations in genes involved in the JAK-STAT pathway, such as JAK2, CALR, and MPL.

The clinical presentation of MPDs varies depending on the specific disorder but often includes fatigue, splenomegaly, thrombosis, and hemorrhagic tendencies. Diagnosis is based on clinical features, complete blood count with differential, bone marrow biopsy, and identification of specific genetic mutations.

Treatment strategies for MPDs aim to control symptoms and prevent complications. In CML, tyrosine kinase inhibitors, such as imatinib, are the mainstay of therapy. PV is managed by phlebotomy and cytoreductive agents, while ET and PMF may require anti-platelet therapy and JAK inhibitors. Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is reserved for patients with high-risk disease or treatment failure.

In conclusion, MPDs are a group of hematologic neoplasms characterized by clonal expansion of myeloid cells. Treatment strategies focus on controlling symptoms and preventing complications, with targeted therapies playing a key role in disease management.

Congenital angiotropic lymphoma (intravascular lymphomatosis) of the T-cell type. Congenital angiotropic lymphoma, also known as intravascular lymphomatosis, is a rare and aggressive form of lymphoma characterized by the proliferation of lymphoma cells within small blood vessels. It predominantly affects the brain and skin. We report a case of congenital angiotropic lymphoma in a 3-month-old male infant presenting with petechiae, seizures, and hepatosplenomegaly. Histopathological examination revealed intravascular proliferation of T-cell lymphoma cells within small blood vessels in multiple organs. Immunohistochemistry confirmed the T-cell lineage. Despite aggressive chemotherapy, the patient succumbed to multiorgan failure. Congenital angiotropic lymphoma is an extremely rare and often fatal condition with a poor prognosis. Awareness of this entity is crucial for early diagnosis and prompt initiation of therapy. Further research is needed to understand the underlying etiology and develop effective targeted therapies for this devastating disease.

Lack of change in neurochemical markers during the postepileptic phase of intrahippocampal tetanus toxin syndrome in rats. The intrahippocampal tetanus toxin syndrome (ITTS) is a well-established model for studying epilepsy. While previous studies have reported changes in neurochemical markers during the pre- and ictal phases of ITTS, little is known about the postepileptic phase. In this study, we investigated the changes in neurochemical markers during the postepileptic phase of ITTS in rats. Our results showed that there was a lack of significant changes in neurochemical markers, including glutamate, GABA, and dopamine, during the postepileptic phase. This suggests that the neurochemical alterations observed in the pre- and ictal phases of ITTS are transient and do not persist into the postepileptic phase. These findings have important implications for understanding the mechanisms underlying ITTS and suggest that the postepileptic phase may represent a period of recovery and stabilization in the neurochemistry of the hippocampus. Further studies are needed to investigate the long-term effects of ITTS on neurochemical markers and their potential role in the pathogenesis of epilepsy.

Two urogenital sinus syndromes.  Interstitial cystitis and focal vulvitis. This article presents two urogenital sinus syndromes: interstitial cystitis and focal vulvitis. Interstitial cystitis is characterized by chronic pelvic pain and urinary symptoms such as urgency and frequency. Focal vulvitis is a rare condition characterized by focal inflammation of the vulva, leading to severe pain and discomfort. The etiology and pathogenesis of these syndromes remain unclear, although various theories suggest neurogenic, autoimmune, and infectious mechanisms. Treatment options include pharmacological agents, physical therapy, and surgical interventions, although outcomes vary among patients. A multidisciplinary approach is often necessary to manage these syndromes effectively. Further research is needed to better understand these conditions and develop more targeted treatment strategies.

Complications in percutaneous transluminal angioplasty: relationships with patient age.  Five hundred consecutive attempted lower limb angioplasties for ischaemic disease (370 patients, mean age 65. This study aimed to evaluate the relationship between patient age and complications in percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) for lower limb ischaemic disease. Five hundred consecutive angioplasties were performed on 370 patients with a mean age of 65 years. Complications were categorized as major or minor based on their clinical significance. The overall complication rate was 10.4%, with minor complications occurring more frequently than major complications. Increasing age was found to be significantly associated with a higher risk of major complications (p<0.001). The most common major complications were artery dissection, thrombosis, and peripheral embolism. Minor complications included access site bleeding and haematoma formation. Older patients were also more likely to require prolonged hospital stays (p=0.002). In conclusion, increasing age is a significant risk factor for major complications in PTA for lower limb ischaemic disease. This should be taken into consideration when deciding the most appropriate treatment approach for older patients.

Hepatic arterial embolization in cases of extensive celiac arterial stenosis. This study aimed to investigate the efficacy of hepatic arterial embolization in cases of extensive celiac arterial stenosis. Thirteen patients with significant celiac artery stenosis and hepatic hypoperfusion were included in the study. All patients underwent hepatic arterial embolization using microspheres. Post-procedural imaging showed successful embolization in all cases. Follow-up examinations revealed improved hepatic perfusion, with reduction in liver enzymes and improvement in liver function. Additionally, patients reported a decrease in symptoms related to hepatic hypoperfusion, such as abdominal pain and weight loss. No major procedure-related complications were observed. Hepatic arterial embolization appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for patients with extensive celiac arterial stenosis, resulting in improved hepatic perfusion and clinical outcomes.

Gallbladder carcinoma producing human chorionic gonadotropin. Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy, and its ability to produce human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is even more unusual. We report a case of gallbladder carcinoma in a 64-year-old male who presented with abdominal pain, weight loss, and elevated levels of hCG. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of gallbladder carcinoma, and immunohistochemical staining demonstrated the production of hCG by tumor cells. This case highlights the importance of considering gallbladder carcinoma in the differential diagnosis of patients with elevated hCG levels, even in the absence of pregnancy. It also emphasizes the need for further research to understand the underlying mechanisms of hCG production in gallbladder carcinoma and its potential implications for diagnosis and treatment.

Unusual haemostasis for an unusual tumour. Hemangiopericytoma (HPC) is an uncommon vascular tumor arising from pericytes. Here, we present a case of a 35-year-old male with a large HPC of the right thigh. During the surgical resection, we encountered unexpected bleeding that was resistant to conventional hemostatic measures. Further investigation revealed that the tumor was expressing high levels of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and platelet-derived growth factor-B (PDGF-B), both potent angiogenic factors. The aberrant expression of these factors likely contributed to the increased vascularity and abnormal bleeding observed in this tumor. Eventually, hemostasis was achieved by employing a combination of direct pressure, topical hemostatic agents, and selective embolization. This case highlights the importance of considering abnormal tumor-related hemostasis and the need for tailored management strategies in unique tumor types like HPC.

Unilateral hydrocephalus in adults. Unilateral hydrocephalus is a rare condition in adults, and its diagnosis can be challenging. In this retrospective study, we aimed to investigate the clinical presentation, radiological findings, and treatment outcomes in adults with unilateral hydrocephalus. We reviewed the medical records of 12 patients diagnosed with unilateral hydrocephalus between 2010 and 2020. Head computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans were performed in all patients. The most common presenting symptoms were headache, cognitive impairment, and gait disturbance. CT and MRI imaging revealed ventricular enlargement on the affected side. Surgical treatment with ventriculoperitoneal shunting resulted in symptom improvement and reduction in ventricular size in all patients. Unilateral hydrocephalus in adults can be effectively diagnosed and managed with the aid of CT and MRI imaging techniques.

Immunoscintigraphy of ovarian cancer with indium-111-labeled OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 monoclonal antibody.  The safety and diagnostic accuracy of immunoscintigraphy with the indium-111-labeled monoclonal antibody OV-TL 3 F(ab')2(111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2) for diagnosis and follow-up of ovarian cancer was prospectively studied in 31 patients. The objective of this study was to evaluate the safety and diagnostic accuracy of immunoscintigraphy using indium-111-labeled OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 monoclonal antibody (111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2) for the diagnosis and follow-up of ovarian cancer. A total of 31 patients with ovarian cancer were prospectively enrolled in the study. The results showed that the procedure was safe with no adverse effects reported. In terms of diagnostic accuracy, 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 immunoscintigraphy exhibited a sensitivity of 93.1% and specificity of 80.0% in detecting ovarian cancer lesions. The use of this radiolabeled monoclonal antibody also allowed for effective monitoring of disease progression or response to therapy in patients with ovarian cancer. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings and assess the clinical utility of 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 immunoscintigraphy in ovarian cancer management.

Hemodynamic determinants of vascular changes in hypertension and atherosclerosis.  Several new concepts are reviewed concerning structural and functional changes in atherosclerotic and hypertensive blood vessels. This review examines the hemodynamic determinants of vascular changes in hypertension and atherosclerosis. Structural and functional alterations in blood vessels affected by these conditions are discussed. The pathogenesis of atherosclerosis involves endothelial dysfunction, smooth muscle cell proliferation, and lipid accumulation in the arterial wall. In hypertension, increased blood pressure leads to vascular remodeling, including thickening of the arterial wall and hypertrophy of smooth muscle cells. These changes are mediated by various factors, such as oxidative stress, inflammation, and alterations in vascular tone. Understanding the mechanisms underlying vascular changes in hypertension and atherosclerosis is crucial for developing effective therapeutic interventions to prevent or treat these cardiovascular diseases. Further research is needed to explore novel targets for intervention and to improve clinical outcomes.

Absent or minimal cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities in Haemophilus influenzae meningitis. Haemophilus influenzae meningitis is a serious bacterial infection affecting the central nervous system. The analysis of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is crucial for its diagnosis. This study aimed to investigate the frequency and extent of CSF abnormalities in patients with H. influenzae meningitis. A retrospective analysis of medical records was conducted on 50 patients diagnosed with H. influenzae meningitis. CSF analysis revealed that 80% of patients had minimal abnormalities or were entirely normal. The most common CSF abnormalities observed were elevated white blood cell count, increased protein levels, and decreased glucose levels. However, these abnormalities were generally mild and did not exceed the reference range for CSF. Notably, 20% of patients exhibited no CSF abnormalities at all. These findings suggest that H. influenzae meningitis may present with absent or minimal CSF abnormalities, making it challenging to diagnose solely based on CSF analysis. Clinicians should be aware that negative CSF findings do not exclude the possibility of H. influenzae meningitis, and other diagnostic methods or clinical observations should be taken into consideration for accurate diagnosis and timely treatment.

Ventricular arrhythmias in ischemic heart disease. Ventricular arrhythmias are a common complication of ischemic heart disease (IHD). This study aimed to determine the prevalence and characteristics of ventricular arrhythmias in patients with IHD and explore their relationship with clinical factors. The study included 912 patients with documented IHD who underwent 24-hour Holter monitoring. Ventricular arrhythmias were classified into two groups: non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) and sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT). The results showed that ventricular arrhythmias were present in 52% of patients, with NSVT being more common (45%) than sustained VT (7%). Patients with ventricular arrhythmias were more likely to have a history of myocardial infarction and a lower ejection fraction. Age, gender, and hypertension were not significantly associated with ventricular arrhythmias. This study provides valuable insights into the prevalence and characteristics of ventricular arrhythmias in patients with IHD. Understanding the risk factors associated with ventricular arrhythmias can aid in risk stratification and inform management strategies for patients with IHD.

Internal fixation of femoral neck fractures.  Two methods compared. This study aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of two different methods of internal fixation for femoral neck fractures. A total of 120 patients were included in the study and randomly assigned to receive either cannulated screws or sliding hip screws for fixation. The primary outcome measures were the rate of fracture healing and the incidence of complications such as nonunion and avascular necrosis. Secondary outcome measures included hip function and pain levels assessed using the Harris Hip Score and Visual Analog Scale, respectively. The results showed that both fixation methods led to similar rates of fracture healing and comparable complication rates. However, patients in the sliding hip screw group demonstrated better hip function and lower pain levels compared to the cannulated screw group. Therefore, the use of sliding hip screws may be considered a better option for internal fixation of femoral neck fractures in terms of functional outcomes and pain relief.

Narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia.  OBJECTIVE: To determine the frequency and clinical characteristics of narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia (QRS duration less than or equal to 0. 11 seconds). This study aimed to determine the frequency and clinical characteristics of narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia (VT) with a QRS duration of less than or equal to 0.11 seconds. A total of 200 patients with episodes of VT were included in the study. Of these, 42 patients (21%) exhibited narrow QRS VT. The mean age of patients with narrow QRS VT was 58 years, and 62% were male. The most common symptom reported was palpitations (83%), followed by presyncope (33%) and syncope (14%). Structural heart disease was present in 71% of patients with narrow QRS VT. Management involved antiarrhythmic drugs, catheter ablation, or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement depending on individual patient characteristics. In conclusion, narrow QRS VT is a distinct clinical entity associated with a high prevalence of structural heart disease. Early recognition and appropriate management are crucial to prevent adverse outcomes and improve patient prognosis.

Incidence of hairy cell leukemia, mycosis fungoides, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia in first known HTLV-II-endemic population.  Unlike human T cell leukemia-lymphoma virus type I (HTLV-I), HTLV-II has not been convincingly linked to a malignancy. This study aimed to investigate the incidence of hairy cell leukemia (HCL), mycosis fungoides (MF), and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) in the first known human T cell leukemia-lymphoma virus type II (HTLV-II) endemic population. HTLV-II has not been definitively associated with any malignancy, unlike HTLV-I. The study analyzed a population with a high prevalence of HTLV-II infection and identified cases of HCL, MF, and CLL over a certain period. The results revealed a higher than expected incidence of HCL, with four cases observed in the study population. However, there were no documented cases of MF or CLL. These findings suggest a potential association between HTLV-II and HCL, highlighting the need for further investigation to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and determine the true causality of this relationship.

Postictal psychosis after partial complex seizures: a multiple case study. Postictal psychosis is a rare but well-recognized phenomenon that can occur after partial complex seizures. This multiple case study aims to further understand the clinical characteristics and risk factors associated with postictal psychosis. A total of 10 patients diagnosed with postictal psychosis were included in the study. Clinical data, including seizure semiology, psychiatric symptoms, and neuroimaging findings, were collected and analyzed. The mean age of onset of postictal psychosis was found to be 34.7 years, with a female predominance. The most common seizure semiology associated with postictal psychosis was complex partial seizures with temporal lobe focus. Psychiatric symptoms included hallucinations, delusions, and disorientation. Neuroimaging findings revealed abnormalities in the temporal lobe and frontal regions in all cases. The findings of this study suggest that postictal psychosis may be associated with specific seizure semiologies and neuroanatomical abnormalities. Further research is needed to determine the underlying pathophysiology and optimal treatment strategies for postictal psychosis.

Expandable biliary metal stents for malignancies: endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth. Endoscopic insertion of expandable biliary metal stents has been widely used in the management of malignant biliary strictures. However, one of the major challenges associated with these stents is tumor ingrowth, which can lead to stent occlusion and subsequent complications. In this study, we describe a novel technique of diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth in expandable biliary metal stents.

A total of 25 patients with malignant biliary strictures underwent endoscopic insertion of expandable metal stents. The stents were deployed successfully in all patients, providing immediate relief of biliary obstruction. However, over a follow-up period of 6 months, 8 patients developed tumor ingrowth in the stent. 

The diathermic cleaning technique involved the use of a flexible diathermic probe inserted through the working channel of the endoscope. The probe was carefully guided into the stent, and radiofrequency energy was applied to the tumor ingrowth, effectively ablating it. The procedure was well-tolerated by all patients, with no immediate or delayed complications observed.

Our study demonstrates the feasibility and efficacy of diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth in expandable biliary metal stents. This technique provides a minimally invasive alternative to surgical intervention and offers a promising solution for the management of tumor-related complications in patients with malignant biliary strictures. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare this technique with other treatment modalities.

Age-related hypotensive effect of placebo and active treatment in patients older than 60 years.  European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly. The Age-related hypotensive effect of placebo and active treatment in patients older than 60 years was investigated by the European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly. The study aimed to determine whether age influenced the blood pressure-lowering effect of antihypertensive treatment. A total of 741 patients aged 60-80 years were enrolled in a randomized placebo-controlled trial. They received either a placebo or active treatment with an antihypertensive drug for 6 months. Blood pressure measurements were taken at baseline and at the end of the study. The results showed a greater reduction in blood pressure with active treatment compared to placebo in patients aged 60-69 years.
