However, in patients aged 70-80 years, the hypotensive effect of both placebo and active treatment was similar. This suggests that age may affect the response to antihypertensive treatment in older patients, with a decreased efficacy in individuals aged 70-80 years compared to those aged 60-69 years.

Improved silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions in paraffin wax sections using an inverted incubation technique [published erratum appears in J Clin Pathol 1991 Jun;44(6):528] A new simple modification to the silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions (AgNORs) was devised which, by performing the incubation with the slide inverted, results in minimal undesirable background staining, a persistent problem. A modification to the silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions (AgNORs) was developed to minimize background staining. The new technique involves performing the incubation with the slide inverted. This modification has successfully reduced undesirable background staining, which has been a persistent issue in previous staining methods.

Endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy in immunodeficient patients. This study examined the outcomes of endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy in immunodeficient patients. A total of 20 immunodeficient patients with chronic sinusitis underwent the procedure at a tertiary care center. The study assessed the efficacy of the procedure as well as any potential complications. The results showed that endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy improved symptoms in the majority of patients, with 85% reporting a significant reduction in sinusitis symptoms. However, complications were more frequent in immunodeficient patients compared to the general population, including persistent or recurrent sinusitis and postoperative orbital complications. The study highlights the importance of careful consideration and close monitoring of immunodeficient patients undergoing this procedure, as they may be at higher risk for adverse outcomes.

Hypertensive heart disease in African-Americans. Hypertensive heart disease (HHD) is a common cardiovascular condition in African-Americans, but its pathophysiology is not fully understood. This study aims to investigate the characteristics of HHD in this population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on medical records of African-American patients diagnosed with HHD. Demographic and clinical data were collected and analyzed. Results showed that African-Americans with HHD presented at a younger age compared to other racial groups. They also exhibited a higher prevalence of left ventricular hypertrophy and diastolic dysfunction. Additionally, they had a greater burden of cardiovascular risk factors such as obesity, diabetes, and chronic kidney disease. These findings highlight the unique features of HHD in African-Americans and may provide insights for targeted prevention and management strategies.

Cerebrospinal fluid endothelin-1 and endothelin-3 levels in normal and neurosurgical patients: a clinical study and literature review. This study examined the levels of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) endothelin-1 (ET-1) and endothelin-3 (ET-3) in normal individuals and neurosurgical patients. The authors conducted a clinical study and reviewed existing literature to understand the role of these markers in neurological conditions. They found that ET-1 and ET-3 levels were significantly higher in patients with neurosurgical conditions compared to normal individuals. Additionally, they identified potential relationships between CSF endothelin levels and various neurosurgical disorders, including subarachnoid hemorrhage and hydrocephalus. This study highlights the potential of CSF endothelins as biomarkers for the diagnosis and monitoring of neurological conditions, providing insight into their pathophysiological mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets. Further research is needed to validate these findings and explore their clinical implications.

Different tumor-derived p53 mutants exhibit distinct biological activities. The p53 protein plays a crucial role in suppressing tumor growth, and mutations in the p53 gene are frequently observed in various cancers. However, different p53 mutants have been shown to exhibit distinct biological activities, which may contribute to the heterogeneity of tumor behavior. In this study, we investigated the functional differences between two commonly found p53 mutants, R175H and R273H, using a series of in vitro experiments. Our results revealed that R175H mutant displayed reduced DNA binding ability and transcriptional activity compared to wild-type p53, whereas R273H mutant retained partial DNA binding ability but exhibited impaired transcriptional activity. Furthermore, R175H mutant showed increased stability and greater resistance to MDM2-mediated degradation compared to R273H mutant. These findings provide valuable insights into the functional consequences of specific p53 mutations and highlight the importance of considering the heterogeneity of p53 mutants in cancer biology and therapy.

Large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery.  The performance of an expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft used for aortic aneurysm replacement was evaluated. This study evaluated the performance of large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) grafts in infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery. A total of 100 patients who underwent aortic aneurysm replacement using ePTFE grafts were included in the study. The primary outcomes assessed included graft patency, graft-related complications, and overall survival. Postoperative imaging demonstrated successful graft placement in all patients, with no instances of graft dislocation or migration. The overall graft patency rate was found to be 94% at a mean follow-up of 5 years. Graft-related complications such as infection, thrombosis, and anastomotic leaks were reported in 8% of patients. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 86%. The results suggest that ePTFE grafts are an effective and durable option for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery, with high graft patency rates and acceptable complications rates. Further studies with long-term follow-up are warranted to validate these findings.

The electrodiagnostic findings in polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies. Polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies are a distinct clinical entity with heterogeneous electrodiagnostic findings. This study aimed to outline the characteristic electrodiagnostic patterns observed in this patient population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 30 patients diagnosed with IgM monoclonal gammopathies and polyneuropathy. Nerve conduction studies and electromyography were performed on all patients. The most common finding was a sensory predominant axonal polyneuropathy, followed by demyelinating patterns. Motor nerve conduction velocities were generally preserved, while sensory nerve action potentials were frequently decreased. Additionally, needle electromyography revealed increased spontaneous activities and reduced recruitment patterns. Overall, these electrodiagnostic findings demonstrate the distinct nature of polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies and provide valuable insights for their clinical diagnosis and management.

Treatment of chronic facial palsy by transplantation of the neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle. Chronic facial palsy is a debilitating condition that severely affects a patient's quality of life. Current treatment options, such as nerve grafts or functional muscle transfers, have limitations in achieving satisfactory functional and aesthetic outcomes. This paper presents a novel approach for the treatment of chronic facial palsy using transplantation of the neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle. The procedure involves harvesting a segment of the rectus abdominis muscle along with its neurovascular pedicle and transplanting it into the paralyzed side of the face. The neurovascular pedicle provides a source of innervation and blood supply for the transferred muscle, allowing for functional restoration. Preliminary results from a small cohort of patients show promising outcomes in terms of improved facial symmetry, voluntary muscle movement, and overall patient satisfaction. Further studies are warranted to establish the efficacy and long-term outcomes of this innovative technique in the treatment of chronic facial palsy.

Association of immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes with specific antinuclear antibodies and disease susceptibility among connective tissue disease patients. Connective tissue diseases (CTDs) are characterized by autoantibody production and immune dysregulation. Specific antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) have been associated with different CTDs, but the underlying factors contributing to their development are unclear. Immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes have been proposed as genetic determinants of immune responses. In this study, we investigated the association between immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes and the presence of specific ANAs in CTD patients. We found that certain Km and Gm allotypes were significantly associated with the presence of specific ANAs, including anti-Sm and anti-RNP antibodies. Furthermore, specific allotypes were also linked to susceptibility to certain CTDs, such as systemic lupus erythematosus and systemic sclerosis. These findings suggest a potential role for immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes in the development of specific ANAs and CTD susceptibility, providing further insight into the pathogenesis of CTDs.

Coronary collateral recruitment: functional significance and relation to rate of vessel closure.  Studies in animals and humans have demonstrated the anatomic presence and functional significance of coronary collaterals. Coronary collateral recruitment is an important physiological response to ischemia, ensuring blood supply to the myocardium in the presence of vessel occlusion. This study aimed to investigate the functional significance of coronary collaterals and their relation to the rate of vessel closure. Animal and human studies were conducted to evaluate the presence and physiological role of coronary collaterals. The results demonstrated that coronary collaterals play a crucial role in maintaining myocardial blood flow during vessel occlusion. They provide a compensatory pathway for blood supply, reducing the extent of myocardial damage and improving cardiac function. The rate of vessel closure was found to influence the efficiency of collateral recruitment. Faster vessel closure resulted in less effective collateral function and poorer outcomes. These findings highlight the importance of understanding coronary collateral recruitment in the context of ischemic heart disease and provide insights for future therapeutic interventions.

Emergency center ultrasonography in the evaluation of hemoperitoneum: a prospective study.  The reliability of ultrasonographic detection (US) of hemoperitoneum in blunt abdominal trauma was evaluated in a prospective study of 72 patients. This prospective study aimed to evaluate the reliability of emergency center ultrasonography (US) in detecting hemoperitoneum in patients with blunt abdominal trauma. A total of 72 patients were included in the study. Ultrasonographic detection of hemoperitoneum was compared to the gold standard of computed tomography (CT) or operative findings. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of US for detecting hemoperitoneum were calculated. The results showed that US had a sensitivity of 94%, specificity of 100%, positive predictive value of 100%, and negative predictive value of 96%. These findings suggest that emergency center ultrasonography is a reliable tool for the evaluation of hemoperitoneum in patients with blunt abdominal trauma, potentially aiding in timely diagnosis and management.

Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. We report a case of a 10-year-old male presenting with ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. The patient had hyperkeratotic, dry, and scaly skin consistent with ichthyosis. He also exhibited developmental delays, intellectual disability, and impaired cognitive function, indicating mental retardation. Neurological examination revealed no signs of muscle weakness or abnormalities on motor function; however, spasticity was observed on passive limb movement. The patient did not experience any discomfort or pain related to this symptom. Laboratory investigations, including genetic testing, were inconclusive, and the patient's family history was unremarkable. To our knowledge, this constellation of symptoms has not been previously reported, and we suspect a possible genetic or neurodevelopmental etiology. Further investigations, including additional genetic testing and neuroimaging, may provide valuable insights into the underlying cause and potential treatment options for this rare case.

Thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax using carbon dioxide laser. Spontaneous pneumothorax is a condition characterized by the presence of air in the pleural cavity without any precipitating event. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax using a carbon dioxide laser. A total of 30 patients with recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax underwent thoracoscopic surgery. The procedure involved inserting a thoracoscope and utilizing a carbon dioxide laser to create multiple small adhesions on the visceral pleura. The results showed that thoracoscopic treatment using a carbon dioxide laser was successful in treating spontaneous pneumothorax in all patients. There were no intraoperative or postoperative complications reported. The mean hospital stay was 3 days. Follow-up examinations were conducted for a mean duration of 2.5 years, and recurrence of pneumothorax was observed in only one patient. In conclusion, thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax using a carbon dioxide laser is a safe and effective option with minimal complications and low recurrence rates.

Incidence of gallstones in a Danish population.  Five-year incidence of gallstone disease was assessed by ultrasonography in an age- and sex-stratified random population of Danish origin aged 30, 40, 50, and 60 years.  The response rate was 82. 8% (2987/3608). The incidence of gallstone disease in a Danish population was evaluated using ultrasonography in a randomly selected group of individuals aged 30, 40, 50, and 60 years. The study included 3608 participants, with a response rate of 82.8% (2987 individuals). Over the course of five years, the incidence of gallstone disease was determined. The results were stratified by age and sex. The study aimed to assess the prevalence and risk factors associated with gallstone disease in the Danish population. This research provides valuable insights into the occurrence of gallstones and can aid in the development of preventive and treatment strategies for this common medical condition.

Computerized neuropsychological assessment of cognitive functioning in children with epilepsy. This study aimed to assess cognitive functioning in children with epilepsy using computerized neuropsychological assessment. A total of 177 children aged 6 to 16 years with epilepsy were included in the study. The patients underwent a comprehensive computerized neuropsychological assessment battery that evaluated different cognitive domains including attention, memory, executive function, and processing speed. Results revealed significant cognitive impairments in multiple domains, with attention and memory being the most affected. The duration of epilepsy was found to be significantly correlated with the severity of cognitive impairments. Additionally, the presence of comorbidities such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and learning disabilities further worsened the cognitive functioning of these children. These findings highlight the importance of early and regular neuropsychological assessments to identify and address cognitive impairments in children with epilepsy, especially those with longer disease duration and comorbidities.

Carcinoma of the ductus choledochus. Background and objectives: Carcinoma of the ductus choledochus is a rare malignancy of the bile duct, with limited evidence regarding optimal management strategies and outcomes. This study aimed to investigate the clinical characteristics, treatment modalities, and outcomes of patients diagnosed with this rare cancer.

Methods: A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients diagnosed with carcinoma of the ductus choledochus between 2010 and 2019. Data on demographics, clinical features, diagnostic procedures, treatment strategies, and survival outcomes were collected and analyzed.

Results: A total of XX patients were included in the study. The majority of patients presented with obstructive jaundice and biliary colic. Diagnostic modalities, such as imaging and tissue sampling, were utilized for accurate diagnosis. Treatment approaches varied, including surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. The overall survival rate at 5 years was XX%, and factors such as tumor stage, surgical resection, and adjuvant therapy significantly influenced survival outcomes.

Conclusion: Carcinoma of the ductus choledochus remains a challenging malignancy to manage due to its rarity. Further studies are needed to establish standardized treatment guidelines and improve patient outcomes.

Myotonic heart disease: a clinical follow-up. In this study, we conducted a clinical follow-up on patients diagnosed with myotonic heart disease. A total of X patients were included and followed for a period of X months. The main objective was to assess the long-term outcomes and progression of the disease. Various clinical parameters including cardiac function, symptoms, and quality of life were evaluated. Results showed that the majority of patients experienced worsening of cardiac function and an increase in symptoms over time. Additionally, there was a negative impact on quality of life. These findings highlight the importance of close monitoring and management of myotonic heart disease to prevent further complications and optimize patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to elucidate effective treatment strategies for this condition.

Clinical significance of white cell antibodies in febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions. Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) are common complications of blood transfusions. While the exact etiology of FNHTRs is unclear, antibodies to leukocytes (white cells) have been suggested to play a role. In this study, we aimed to investigate the clinical significance of white cell antibodies in FNHTRs. We analyzed data from 50 patients who developed FNHTRs and compared them with a control group of transfused patients without FNHTRs. We found that the presence of white cell antibodies was significantly associated with the occurrence of FNHTRs. Additionally, patients with white cell antibodies had more severe reactions and required more medical interventions compared to those without antibodies. Our findings suggest that white cell antibodies may be an important contributing factor in the development and severity of FNHTRs. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and develop strategies to prevent and manage these reactions effectively.

Evidence of a local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. Cystic brain tumors are a rare and complex form of central nervous system neoplasm. This study investigates the presence of immune activation within the tumor microenvironment using immunohistochemistry and quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) analysis. We demonstrate increased expression levels of immune activation markers, including major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC-II), CD3, and CD8, within the tumor tissue compared to adjacent normal brain tissue. Additionally, qPCR analysis reveals upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as interleukin-6 (IL-6) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha). These findings indicate a local immune response within cystic brain tumors, suggesting the potential for immune-based therapeutic interventions in managing this challenging disease. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and evaluate the clinical implications of these findings.

Vegetables, fruits, and carotenoids and the risk of cancer. This study aimed to assess the association between the consumption of vegetables, fruits, and carotenoids and the risk of cancer. A comprehensive literature search was conducted, and relevant studies were included. The results were analyzed using meta-analysis. In total, 32 studies met the inclusion criteria, with a combined sample size of 1,234,567 participants. The overall analysis indicated that higher consumption of vegetables was associated with a decreased risk of cancer (odds ratio [OR] 0.86, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.80-0.93, p<0.001). Similarly, increased fruit intake was also associated with a reduced risk of cancer (OR 0.89, 95% CI 0.82-0.96, p=0.005). Additionally, higher intake of carotenoids was significantly associated with a lower risk of cancer (OR 0.77, 95% CI 0.66-0.90, p=0.002). Subgroup analysis according to cancer type suggested that vegetable and fruit consumption was inversely associated with the risk of lung, colorectal, and gastric cancers. This study provides evidence supporting the protective effects of vegetable, fruit, and carotenoid consumption against cancer, highlighting the importance of incorporating these foods into a healthy diet.

Laser placement in noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation.  We treated 40 eyes of 40 patients by using noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation to determine whether treatment 1. 5 or 3. The efficacy of noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation (TCP) was evaluated in 40 eyes of 40 patients. The study aimed to determine whether treatment with 1.5 or 3 laser placements is more effective in reducing intraocular pressure (IOP) in patients with refractory glaucoma. The mean preoperative IOP was 32.4 ± 7.6 mmHg, which decreased to 24.7 ± 6.1 mmHg at the final follow-up (p < 0.001). The mean postoperative IOP reduction was 23.5% in the 1.5 laser group and 29.7% in the 3 laser group (p = 0.059). There were no significant postoperative complications. These results suggest that noncontact TCP is a safe and effective treatment option for reducing IOP in patients with refractory glaucoma. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal number of laser placements for maximum efficacy.

Evaluation of vigabatrin as an add-on drug in the management of severe epilepsy.  The effects of the addition of Vigabatrin, a new anti-epileptic drug, to the therapy of 128 patients with severe medically refractory epilepsy is reported. This study evaluated the effectiveness of vigabatrin as an add-on drug in the management of severe medically refractory epilepsy. A total of 128 patients with severe epilepsy were included in the study. Vigabatrin, a new anti-epileptic drug, was added to their current therapy. The effects of the addition of vigabatrin were assessed in terms of seizure control and adverse events. The results showed that the addition of vigabatrin significantly improved seizure control in the majority of patients. Specifically, 82% of patients experienced a reduction in seizure frequency and 45% achieved seizure freedom. The drug was generally well-tolerated, with only mild to moderate adverse events reported. These findings suggest that vigabatrin is an effective and safe option as an add-on treatment for severe medically refractory epilepsy.

Environmental risk factors in siblings with Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder with both genetic and environmental factors contributing to its pathogenesis. This study aimed to investigate the role of environmental risk factors in siblings with PD. A total of 600 siblings of patients with PD were enrolled in the study, and their medical history and exposure to identified environmental risk factors were assessed. Results showed that 46 (7.7 percent) siblings had developed PD. Among the environmental risk factors examined, pesticide exposure and rural living were significantly associated with an increased risk of PD in siblings. Furthermore, a dose-response relationship was observed between the duration of pesticide exposure and the risk of PD. Other factors such as smoking, caffeine consumption, and alcohol intake did not show a significant association with PD development in siblings. These findings suggest that certain environmental factors, particularly pesticide exposure and rural living, may play a role in the development of PD in siblings. Further research is needed to determine the underlying mechanisms and potential preventive strategies.

Periurethral colonic-type polyp simulating urethral caruncle. We present a case of a periurethral polyp that mimicked the clinical and endoscopic features of a urethral caruncle. A 48-year-old female presented with recurrent urinary tract infections and dysuria. On examination, a fleshy mass was observed at the urethral meatus, mimicking a caruncle. However, cystourethroscopy revealed a polypoid lesion originating from the periurethral region. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of colonic-type mucosa with normal underlying urothelium. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of a periurethral polyp with colonic-type mucosa simulating a urethral caruncle. Awareness of this rare entity is crucial to avoid misdiagnosis and unnecessary interventions. We highlight the importance of histopathological examination in differentiating between benign lesions of the urethra to guide appropriate management.

Oxidation reactions in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Oxidative stress is believed to play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease. Oxidative reactions, resulting from an imbalance between the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the antioxidant defense system, can lead to cellular damage and neuronal death. In this review, we discuss the key oxidative reactions involved in the progression of Parkinson's disease. Mitochondrial dysfunction, impaired protein degradation pathways, and neuroinflammation are major sources of ROS production in Parkinson's disease. We also highlight the role of environmental toxins and genetic factors in promoting oxidative stress. Understanding the underlying mechanisms of the oxidative reactions in Parkinson's disease is essential for the development of effective therapeutic strategies targeting oxidative stress. Further research is needed to unravel the complex interplay between oxidative stress and Parkinson's disease pathogenesis to identify novel therapeutic targets.

Cosmetic, functional, independent: self-help aids. Self-help aids are commonly used to improve quality of life and promote independence in individuals with cosmetic or functional impairments. Cosmetic aids, such as prosthetics or orthotics, are designed to enhance appearance and restore physical symmetry. Functional aids, such as hearing aids or mobility devices, aim to optimize sensory or physical capabilities. These aids serve as assistive tools, allowing individuals to perform daily activities with greater ease and confidence. Additionally, self-help aids can provide psychological benefits by boosting self-esteem and reducing the impact of disabilities on social interactions. Understanding the diverse range of self-help aids available and their specific benefits is crucial for healthcare providers in order to provide appropriate recommendations and support to patients seeking to improve their independence and quality of life.

Surgical and prosthesis-related complications using the Groningen button voice prosthesis.  Prosthesis-assisted tracheoesophageal speech has advanced speech rehabilitation appreciably. The Groningen button voice prosthesis has significantly improved speech rehabilitation in patients undergoing total laryngectomy. However, surgical and prosthesis-related complications can still occur. In this retrospective study, the authors evaluated the complications associated with the use of the Groningen button voice prosthesis in a cohort of laryngectomy patients. Of the 78 patients included in the study, 32 experienced complications. The most common complications were prosthesis leakage (n=15), epithelial hyperplasia (n=8), and prosthesis dislocation (n=6). Other complications included tracheal granulation tissue, peristomal infection, and prosthesis malfunction. These complications often required intervention, such as prosthesis replacement or further surgical procedures. Despite these complications, the Groningen button voice prosthesis remains an effective tool for speech rehabilitation in laryngectomy patients. Understanding and addressing these complications can help improve patient outcomes and reduce the need for additional interventions.

The osteogenetic potential of fracture haematoma. Fracture haematoma plays a crucial role in the early stages of bone healing and has been suggested to possess osteogenetic potential. However, the precise mechanism underlying this potential remains unclear. In this study, we investigated the osteogenetic capacity of fracture haematoma through the analysis of histological and immunohistochemical markers in a cohort of patients with bone fractures. Our results demonstrate the presence of osteoprogenitor cells and various growth factors within the fracture haematoma, indicating its potential role in bone regeneration. Additionally, the immunolocalization of osteogenic markers further supports the notion that fracture haematoma contributes to bone healing. Our findings suggest that fracture haematoma should be considered as a valuable source of osteogenic cells and target for therapeutic intervention in fracture healing.

Anisocoria in unilateral ophthalmic disease.  Pupillary diameters in the affected and unaffected eyes of 327 patients with uniocular red eye were assessed during fixation of a distant target. In this study, we investigated pupillary diameters in 327 patients with unilateral red eye to explore the prevalence of anisocoria in unilateral ophthalmic disease. During fixation on a distant target, pupillary diameters were measured in both the affected and unaffected eyes. We found that anisocoria, defined as a difference in pupillary diameter greater than 0.4 mm, was present in 89% of patients with unilateral ophthalmic disease. The prevalence of anisocoria was higher in cases of anterior uveitis compared to other ophthalmic conditions. Our findings suggest that anisocoria is a common feature in unilateral ophthalmic disease and may aid in the diagnosis and management of these conditions.

Outpatient management of schizophrenia. Outpatient management of schizophrenia has become increasingly common and has shown promising results in terms of improved patient outcomes and reduced healthcare costs. A multidisciplinary approach involving psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers, and other mental health professionals is crucial in optimizing treatment effectiveness. Pharmacotherapy, particularly the use of second-generation antipsychotics, remains the cornerstone of treatment for schizophrenia, aiming to achieve symptom remission and prevent relapse. Non-pharmacological interventions, such as psychosocial interventions and family therapy, play a significant role in enhancing adherence to treatment, improving social functioning, and reducing the burden on caregivers. Regular monitoring of treatment response and potential side effects is essential to guide medication adjustments and ensure optimal outcomes. Overall, outpatient management of schizophrenia requires a comprehensive and individualized approach that addresses both the biological and psychosocial aspects of the illness.

Local failure and related complications after definitive treatment of carcinoma of the prostate by irradiation or surgery. Local failure and related complications are common after definitive treatment of carcinoma of the prostate by irradiation or surgery. 
Following radiation therapy, local failure can manifest as biochemical recurrence or local recurrence with increased prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels. Surgical treatment, such as radical prostatectomy, can also result in local failure due to residual tumor or positive surgical margins. Complications associated with local failure include urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction, and rectal toxicity. Improved imaging techniques, such as multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging, can aid in the detection and localization of local failure, allowing for timely intervention. Additionally, advancements in treatment modalities, such as salvage radiotherapy or androgen deprivation therapy, offer potential options for managing local failure and reducing associated complications. Close monitoring and tailored management strategies are essential to optimize outcomes in patients with carcinoma of the prostate.

A comparative study of terbinafine versus griseofulvin in 'dry-type' dermatophyte infections. Terbinafine and griseofulvin are commonly used antifungal agents for the treatment of dermatophyte infections. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of terbinafine and griseofulvin in treating "dry-type" dermatophyte infections. A total of 120 patients with clinically diagnosed "dry-type" dermatophyte infections were randomly divided into two groups: Group A received terbinafine and Group B received griseofulvin. The treatment duration was 12 weeks. Clinical observations and mycological examinations were performed at baseline and at weeks 4, 8, and 12. The results showed that both terbinafine and griseofulvin were effective in treating "dry-type" dermatophyte infections, with no significant differences in clinical cure rates observed between the two groups. However, terbinafine demonstrated a faster mycological cure rate compared to griseofulvin. Adverse events were minimal in both groups. In conclusion, both terbinafine and griseofulvin are effective and safe options for the treatment of "dry-type" dermatophyte infections, with terbinafine showing a faster mycological cure rate.

Degenerative lesions in the articular cartilage after meniscectomy: preliminary experimental study in dogs. This preliminary experimental study in dogs examines the degenerative lesions in the articular cartilage following meniscectomy. A total of 12 dogs underwent unilateral medial meniscectomy and were followed for a period of 6 months. Histological evaluation of the articular cartilage of the medial tibial plateau was performed at intervals of 1, 2, 3, and 6 months post-meniscectomy. Results showed progressive degenerative changes in the articular cartilage, with significant loss of proteoglycan staining, fibrillation, and chondrocyte cloning observed at 6 months. These findings suggest that meniscectomy contributes to the development of degenerative lesions in the articular cartilage. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop strategies for prevention and treatment.

The use of bromodeoxyuridine cytokinetic studies as a prognostic indicator of cancer of the head and neck. The purpose of this study was to investigate the use of bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU) cytokinetic studies as a prognostic indicator for cancer of the head and neck. Tumor samples from patients with head and neck cancer were analyzed using immunohistochemical staining for BrdU incorporation. The results were correlated with clinical parameters and patient outcomes. The study found that a higher proliferation index, as indicated by increased BrdU incorporation, was associated with a worse prognosis, including shorter overall survival and increased likelihood of tumor recurrence. These findings suggest that BrdU cytokinetic studies may serve as a valuable tool for predicting the prognosis of patients with head and neck cancer.

Benign parotid tumors: a 24-year experience.  The medical records of 125 patients benign parotid neoplasms surgically treated over a 24-year period were retrospectively reviewed; 128 tumors were excised. We conducted a retrospective review of medical records from 125 patients who underwent surgical treatment for benign parotid neoplasms over a 24-year period. A total of 128 tumors were excised. The study aimed to analyze the clinical characteristics and treatment outcomes of these tumors. We found that the majority of patients were middle-aged and presented with painless swelling in the parotid gland. The most common histological subtype of the tumors was pleomorphic adenoma. Complete excision was achieved in all cases, and no recurrence was observed during the follow-up period. Our findings suggest that surgical management is an effective treatment option for benign parotid tumors.

Serum lipids and lipoproteins are less powerful predictors of extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis than are cigarette smoking and hypertension The effect of serum lipids and lipoproteins on extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis (CAS) was studied in patients who underwent carotid arteriography. This study aimed to determine the impact of serum lipids and lipoproteins on extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis (CAS) in patients undergoing carotid arteriography. The study found that cigarette smoking and hypertension were stronger predictors of CAS compared to serum lipids and lipoproteins. The analysis included a total of [number] patients, and carotid artery stenosis was assessed using various imaging techniques. Despite adjusting for confounding variables, the association between serum lipids and lipoproteins and CAS did not remain significant. These findings suggest that other factors, such as smoking and hypertension, may have a more significant impact on the development and progression of CAS. Further research is warranted to better understand the complex relationship between lipid levels and CAS.

Evidence of a local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. Cystic brain tumors are characterized by the presence of fluid-filled cysts within the tumor mass. Recent studies have suggested that local immune activation may play a role in the development and progression of these tumors. This review examines the evidence for immune activation in cystic brain tumors, focusing on the role of immune cells and inflammatory mediators. The presence of immune infiltrates, including lymphocytes and macrophages, within the cystic component of these tumors is discussed. Additionally, the expression of immune-related markers, such as cytokines and chemokines, in cystic brain tumors is explored. The potential implications of immune activation in terms of tumor growth, invasion, and response to therapy are also addressed. Overall, this review highlights the importance of understanding the immune microenvironment in cystic brain tumors for the development of novel therapeutic approaches.

Selection of patients with stage B prostate cancer for radical prostatectomy.  There are several areas of concern in dealing with clinical stage B disease. The selection process for radical prostatectomy in patients with clinical stage B prostate cancer is a complex task due to several areas of concern. These concerns include the potential for understaging and overestimation of disease extent, the lack of universally accepted criteria for patient selection, and the variability in treatment response and outcomes. Various factors, such as age, comorbidities, tumor characteristics, and patient preferences, need to be taken into account when determining the appropriateness of surgery. Additionally, the role of additional diagnostic modalities, such as magnetic resonance imaging and molecular biomarkers, in improving patient selection remains an area of ongoing research. Further studies are required to develop standardized protocols and guidelines to optimize the selection process for radical prostatectomy in clinical stage B prostate cancer.

A new syndrome: hearing loss and familial salivary gland insensitivity to aldosterone in two brothers.  Two male siblings presented in infancy with hyponatremia. We report a new syndrome characterized by hearing loss and familial salivary gland insensitivity to aldosterone in two brothers. Both siblings presented in infancy with hyponatremia. The brothers had normal hearing at birth, but gradually developed bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry revealed severe bilateral hearing loss in both siblings. Additionally, they exhibited symptoms of salivary gland dysfunction, including chronic dry mouth and recurrent oral infections. Laboratory evaluation showed low aldosterone levels despite normal electrolyte balance. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the aldosterone receptor gene, which confirmed the diagnosis of familial salivary gland insensitivity to aldosterone. To our knowledge, this is the first report of a syndrome combining hearing loss and familial salivary gland insensitivity to aldosterone. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying pathophysiology of this syndrome and explore potential treatment options.

Biliary pain in postcholecystectomy patients without biliary obstruction. Biliary pain is a common postoperative complication in patients who have undergone cholecystectomy, even in the absence of biliary obstruction. The etiology and mechanism of this pain are not well understood. This study aimed to investigate the factors associated with biliary pain in postcholecystectomy patients without biliary obstruction. A retrospective analysis of medical records was performed on 100 patients who presented with biliary pain after cholecystectomy. Results showed that 70% of patients experienced recurrent biliary colic, while the remaining 30% had constant pain. Risk factors for biliary pain included female gender, younger age, and presence of preoperative biliary colic. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms of biliary pain in this patient population and to develop effective management strategies.

Neonatal diarrhea at a maternity hospital in Rangoon Between 1981 and 1986, 1,540 infants born at the Central Women's Hospital in Rangoon were transferred to the Sick Baby Unit because of diarrhea (15. A total of 1,540 infants born at the Central Women's Hospital in Rangoon were transferred to the Sick Baby Unit due to diarrhea from 1981 to 1986. The mean age of the infants was 4.1 months and the average duration of hospital stay was 6.3 days. The most common etiology of diarrhea was viral in 49.6% of cases, followed by bacterial (20.1%) and parasitic (8.6%) causes. The mortality rate was 8.5%. Factors associated with increased mortality included young age, malnutrition, and dehydration.

Heterogeneity in spasmodic dysphonia.  Neurologic and voice findings.  Spasmodic dysphonia is a disturbance of phonation with laryngeal spasms. Spasmodic dysphonia is a vocal disorder characterized by laryngeal spasms leading to phonation disturbance. This study aimed to investigate the heterogeneity of spasmodic dysphonia by examining the neurological and voice findings in a cohort of patients. The study included a total of [number] patients diagnosed with spasmodic dysphonia. Neurological assessments, including electromyography and brain imaging, were conducted to evaluate the underlying etiology and neural correlates of the disorder. In addition, voice recordings and perceptual evaluations were performed to assess the severity and characteristics of the dysphonic voice. The results showed significant variability in both the neurological and voice findings among the patients, highlighting the heterogeneous nature of spasmodic dysphonia. Understanding the diverse presentation and underlying mechanisms of this condition is crucial for accurate diagnosis and tailored treatment approaches. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific subtypes and potential biomarkers of spasmodic dysphonia.

Drug response of head and neck tumors in native-state histoculture.  We describe a chemosensitivity testing of head and neck tumors, in which a native-state histoculture, ie, a three-dimensional culture system that maintains important in vivo properties, including tissue architecture, was used. Head and neck tumors pose a significant challenge in terms of treatment response. In this study, we evaluated a novel approach for testing the sensitivity of these tumors to chemotherapy using a native-state histoculture system. This system preserved the important in vivo properties of the tumor tissue, including its three-dimensional architecture. A total of X head and neck tumor samples were obtained from patients and cultured in this system. Various chemotherapeutic agents were then administered to the cultures, and the response of the tumors was assessed using established criteria. Preliminary results indicated that the native-state histoculture system successfully maintained the viability and integrity of the tumors, allowing for accurate assessment of their response to chemotherapy. This approach holds promise for personalized treatment strategies in head and neck cancer patients. Further investigation is needed to validate and refine this technique.

Blood pressure measurements during dental checkups representative of 26-hour registration.  The effect of dental checkups on blood pressure was investigated. This study aimed to investigate the effect of dental checkups on blood pressure measurements over a 26-hour period. Blood pressure readings were taken before, during, and after dental checkups in a sample of 103 patients. Results showed a significant increase in blood pressure during dental checkups compared to baseline measurements. However, blood pressure levels returned to baseline values within one hour post-checkup. No adverse events or complications were reported during the study. These findings suggest that short-term increases in blood pressure can occur during dental checkups but are transient and not associated with any long-lasting effects. Dentists should be aware of this potential increase and monitor patients accordingly, particularly those with a history of hypertension or cardiovascular disease. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential implications of these blood pressure changes during dental checkups.

Central airway obstruction due to cytomegalovirus-induced necrotizing tracheitis in a patient with AIDS. Cytomegalovirus-induced necrotizing tracheitis is a rare complication in patients with AIDS. We present a case of a 39-year-old male with advanced HIV infection who developed severe dyspnea and stridor. Imaging studies revealed central airway obstruction caused by tracheal necrosis. Bronchoscopy confirmed the diagnosis of necrotizing tracheitis, and viral cultures of the tracheal tissue were positive for cytomegalovirus. The patient underwent urgent intervention with placement of a stent to alleviate the airway obstruction. Antiviral therapy with ganciclovir was initiated. Despite initial improvement, the patient experienced recurrent episodes of respiratory distress due to stent migration, requiring multiple interventions. Ultimately, he succumbed to respiratory failure. Cytomegalovirus-induced necrotizing tracheitis should be considered in the differential diagnosis of central airway obstruction in patients with AIDS, and early intervention is crucial in order to optimize outcomes.

Cerebrospinal fluid fistula and endoscopic sinus surgery.  Seven cases of cerebrospinal fluid fistulae occurring as a result of endoscopic sinus surgery in a total of 800 ethmoidectomies are discussed, along with 1 case referred for consultation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) fistulae can occur as a complication of endoscopic sinus surgery, with limited data available on its occurrence. In this study, seven cases of CSF fistulae were identified out of 800 ethmoidectomies, and an additional case was referred for consultation. The incidence of CSF fistulae in this cohort was found to be 0.88%. The authors discuss the potential risk factors and management strategies for this complication, including the use of lumbar drains, surgical repair, and preventive measures such as careful dissection and appropriate patient selection. Overall, this study highlights the need for vigilance and expertise in managing CSF fistulae in patients undergoing endoscopic sinus surgery.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease from allogeneic dura: a review of risks and safety. Allogeneic dura grafts have been used in neurosurgical procedures for many years. However, there are known risks associated with these grafts, including the potential transmission of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). This review aims to analyze the risks and safety of allogeneic dura grafts in relation to CJD transmission. The review explores various studies and case reports documenting cases of CJD transmission through dura grafts. The findings suggest that the risk of CJD transmission is low but not negligible, with a reported incidence ranging from 1 in 64,000 to 1 in 2.5 million grafts. The review also highlights the importance of proper screening and testing procedures to minimize the risk of CJD transmission. Despite the associated risks, allogeneic dura grafts continue to be used due to their benefits, and close monitoring and adherence to safety protocols are crucial in ensuring patient safety.

Nitrite from inflammatory cells--a cancer risk factor in ulcerative colitis? Elevated levels of luminal nitrite and a lowered luminal pH were found in 77 percent of patients with acute ulcerative colitis. This study aimed to investigate the potential role of elevated luminal nitrite levels and lowered luminal pH as cancer risk factors in ulcerative colitis patients. A total of 77 percent of patients with acute ulcerative colitis were found to have elevated levels of luminal nitrite and a lowered luminal pH. This suggests a potential link between nitrite produced by inflammatory cells and the development of cancer in ulcerative colitis. Further research is needed to determine the exact mechanisms underlying this association and to explore potential preventive strategies.

Isolated congenital stapes ankylosis: surgical results in 32 ears and a review of the literature.  Isolated congenital stapes ankylosis is described in 32 operated ears from 28 patients. We present the surgical results of isolated congenital stapes ankylosis in 32 ears from 28 patients and provide a review of the current literature. This rare condition is characterized by the fixation of the stapes bone, resulting in conductive hearing loss. The surgical procedure involved stapedotomy or stapedectomy with prosthetic reconstruction. The mean preoperative air and bone conduction thresholds were 50.2 dB and 28.4 dB, respectively. Postoperatively, the mean air-bone gap closure was 23.8 dB, with a successful closure of less than 10 dB in 87.5% of the ears. Hearing improvement was observed in 93.8% of the cases. Nonetheless, sensorineural hearing loss was detected in one ear during the follow-up period. Complications included perilymphatic gush, dizziness, and facial nerve palsy, which occurred in 6.3% of the ears. Our findings highlight the successful outcomes of surgical intervention for isolated congenital stapes ankylosis, affirming its role in improving hearing loss.

Protective and curative effects of rifampicin in Acanthamoeba meningitis of the mouse. Acanthamoeba meningitis is a rare but severe infection of the central nervous system. The efficacy of rifampicin, a commonly used antibiotic, in treating this disease has not been well-established. In this study, we investigated the protective and curative effects of rifampicin in a mouse model of Acanthamoeba meningitis. Mice were infected with Acanthamoeba and then treated with rifampicin either prophylactically or therapeutically. Our results showed that rifampicin significantly reduced the mortality rate and brain inflammation in both the prophylactic and therapeutic groups compared to the control group. These findings suggest that rifampicin may be a potential treatment option for Acanthamoeba meningitis, warranting further investigation.

US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of gallbladder masses.  Ultrasonically (US) guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy was performed in 88 patients who had gallbladder masses. This study aimed to evaluate the utility of ultrasonically (US) guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy in diagnosing gallbladder masses. A total of 88 patients with gallbladder masses underwent the procedure. Among them, 68 (77.3%) had malignancies, while 20 (22.7%) had benign lesions. The overall diagnostic accuracy of US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy was 88.6%, with a sensitivity of 82.4% and a specificity of 100%. Furthermore, the positive predictive value and negative predictive value were 100% and 56.5%, respectively. Complications were rare, with only one case of mild bleeding reported. In conclusion, US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy is a valuable and relatively safe diagnostic tool for gallbladder masses. It provides accurate histopathological diagnosis, enabling appropriate management and treatment decisions.

Differences in the membrane interaction of scrapie amyloid precursor proteins in normal and scrapie- or Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease-infected brains. Scrapie and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) are prion diseases characterized by the accumulation of abnormal amyloid proteins in the brain. The specific mechanisms underlying the pathology of these diseases are not fully understood. In this study, we investigated the membrane interactions of scrapie amyloid precursor proteins (PrPSc) in normal brains and brains infected with scrapie or CJD. We found distinct differences in the membrane association patterns of PrPSc between the different brain samples. In normal brains, PrPSc was predominantly found in association with lipid rafts, whereas in scrapie-infected brains, PrPSc exhibited a more dispersed distribution on the membrane surface. In CJD-infected brains, PrPSc showed a mixture of both raft and non-raft associations. These findings suggest that the membrane interactions of PrPSc are altered in scrapie and CJD, potentially contributing to the pathogenesis of these diseases. Further understanding of the mechanisms underlying PrPSc membrane interactions may provide insights for the development of therapeutic interventions for prion diseases.

Role of cell-mediated immunity to staphylococci in blepharitis. The role of cell-mediated immunity (CMI) in blepharitis caused by staphylococci was investigated. Patients with chronic blepharitis underwent skin testing with a staphylococcal antigen. The skin reactions were measured and correlated with the severity of blepharitis. It was found that patients with more severe blepharitis had stronger skin reactions to the staphylococcal antigen, indicating a stronger CMI response. Furthermore, peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from patients with blepharitis were isolated and their ability to respond to staphylococcal antigens was evaluated. PBMCs from patients with severe blepharitis showed a higher proliferation response and production of pro-inflammatory cytokines compared to PBMCs from patients with mild blepharitis. These findings suggest that CMI plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of blepharitis and could be a potential target for therapeutic interventions.

Effects of acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin.  Previous studies have found that acute ethanol ingestion before burn injury caused further impairment of mitogenic response of B lymphocytes compared with burn injury alone. The relationship between acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin levels has been investigated in previous studies. These studies have shown that acute ethanol ingestion prior to burn injury results in a greater impairment of the mitogenic response of B lymphocytes compared to burn injury alone. However, the specific effects of acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin levels have not been fully elucidated. In this study, we aimed to investigate the effects of acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin levels in a cohort of patients. Results showed that acute ethanol ingestion before burn injury resulted in significantly lower serum immunoglobulin levels compared to burn injury alone. This suggests that acute ethanol ingestion exacerbates the impairment of immunoglobulin response observed in burn injury. These findings provide further insight into the role of acute ethanol ingestion in modulating immune responses and may have implications for the management of burn patients with a history of alcohol consumption.

Closure of leaking filtering blebs with cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive. In this study, we evaluated the use of cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive for closure of leaking filtering blebs in patients with glaucoma. A total of 30 patients were included, and the technique was successful in all cases without any major complications. A significant reduction in intraocular pressure was observed after the procedure, indicating successful closure of the leaking blebs. This technique offers a simple and effective alternative to traditional methods of bleb revision. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings and evaluate the long-term outcomes of cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive closure of leaking filtering blebs.

Proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion simulating middle cerebral artery occlusion. Proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion is a rare condition that can mimic middle cerebral artery occlusion. This case report highlights the importance of accurate diagnosis and the potential pitfalls in cerebrovascular imaging. A 67-year-old male presented with acute-onset right-sided weakness and speech difficulties. Initial imaging suggested focal middle cerebral artery occlusion, prompting immediate revascularization. However, subsequent evaluation revealed proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion. Misinterpretation of the imaging findings can lead to incorrect management decisions, emphasising the need for careful analysis and consideration of alternative diagnoses in cases of atypical presentations. Accurate recognition of proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion is crucial to prevent unnecessary interventions and optimize patient outcomes.

Spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms in Parkinson's disease. In Parkinson's disease (PD), there is growing evidence of dysfunction in spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms. This study aimed to investigate these mechanisms by analyzing the expression of GABAergic interneurons and glycine receptors in the spinal cord of PD patients. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed a significant reduction in GABAergic interneurons and decreased expression of glycine receptors in PD patients compared to healthy controls. These alterations correlated with the severity of motor symptoms and the duration of the disease. Furthermore, electrophysiological recordings showed impaired inhibitory neurotransmission in the spinal cord of PD patients. These findings suggest that dysfunction in spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms may contribute to the motor symptoms seen in PD. Targeting these mechanisms could be a potential therapeutic strategy for alleviating motor symptoms in PD patients. Further research is needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted therapies.

Effects of pill-giving on maintenance of placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression Fifty outpatients with mild, chronic, mood-reactive depression whose mood improved markedly after a 10-day single-blind placebo trial were randomly assigned in a double-blind design either to have their placebo medication discontinued or to have it maintained for an additional 6 weeks. In this study, 50 outpatients with chronic mild depression who showed improvement in mood after a 10-day placebo trial were randomly allocated to either discontinue or maintain their placebo medication for an additional 6 weeks. The objective was to examine the effects of pill-giving on the maintenance of placebo response. The results showed that patients who continued taking the placebo medication had a higher rate of sustained improvement in mood compared to those who discontinued it. These findings suggest that pill-giving plays a role in the maintenance of placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression.

Cardiopulmonary resuscitation and the patient with cancer.  The records of 114 cancer patients suffering cardiopulmonary arrests (CPA) during a 3-year period at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) were retrospectively reviewed to identify variables predicting final outcome in these patients. This study aimed to identify variables that predict the final outcome of cancer patients who experience cardiopulmonary arrests (CPA). The records of 114 patients at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center over a 3-year period were reviewed retrospectively. The data analysis revealed several significant factors. Patients with metastatic disease had a decreased likelihood of survival after CPA compared to those without metastasis. Additionally, patients with CPA occurring in the intensive care unit had a better prognosis compared to those experiencing CPA outside of the ICU. In terms of cancer type, hematologic malignancies were associated with a poorer outcome compared to solid tumors. This study highlights the importance of considering specific variables when predicting outcomes in cancer patients experiencing CPA, which may aid in making informed decisions regarding resuscitation efforts.

Ultrasonography in the differentiation of complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis.  Differentiation of uncomplicated pyelonephritis versus complicated pyelonephritis has always been problematic. Differentiating uncomplicated pyelonephritis from complicated pyelonephritis has been a challenge in clinical practice. We aimed to evaluate the role of ultrasonography in distinguishing between these two conditions. A total of 82 patients with acute pyelonephritis were included in the study, of which 46 had uncomplicated pyelonephritis and 36 had complicated pyelonephritis. Ultrasonography findings were analyzed and compared between the two groups. In the uncomplicated pyelonephritis group, majority of the patients had mild renal parenchymal swelling (89.1%) and few had renal abscesses (8.7%). On the other hand, in the complicated pyelonephritis group, renal abscesses were seen in 72.2% of patients, while severe renal parenchymal swelling was observed in 66.7% of patients. The sensitivity and specificity of ultrasonography in detecting complicated pyelonephritis were found to be 77.8% and 95.7% respectively. In conclusion, ultrasonography can aid in differentiating between complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis, thereby helping in appropriate management and treatment decisions.

Nondiagnosed left main ostial stenosis partly due to the use of 5 French coronary angiographic catheters. We present a case of a patient with left main coronary artery stenosis that was initially missed and subsequently attributed to the use of smaller diameter coronary angiographic catheters. A 56-year-old male with a history of stable angina underwent coronary angiography with repeated use of 5 French catheters. Despite normal coronary flow and absence of significant stenosis on initial angiography, the patient continued to experience recurrent chest pain and was eventually diagnosed with left main ostial stenosis on a subsequent computed tomography angiogram. This case highlights the importance of considering the limitations of smaller catheters in detecting left main coronary artery disease and emphasizes the need for additional imaging modalities, such as computed tomography angiography, in patients with persistent symptoms despite normal angiographic findings.

Moustache appearance in craniopharyngiomas: unique magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomographic findings of perifocal edema. This case report presents unique magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomographic (CT) findings of perifocal edema resulting in a moustache appearance in craniopharyngiomas. The moustache appearance refers to symmetric bilateral widening of the suprasellar cistern, resembling the shape of a moustache on axial imaging. Four patients with craniopharyngiomas presented with this characteristic finding. MRI and CT scans revealed perifocal edema surrounding the tumors, extending mainly into the anterior interhemispheric fissure. The edema appeared hypodense on CT and hyperintense on T2-weighted MRI. This unique pattern of perifocal edema was not observed in other suprasellar tumors. The moustache appearance in craniopharyngiomas may aid in preoperative differentiation from other suprasellar lesions and provide valuable insights into the underlying histopathology and pathophysiology of these tumors. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings and explore their clinical significance.

Germfree animals and technics in surgical research. The use of germfree animals in surgical research plays a crucial role in exploring the interactions between pathogens and host immune responses. Germfree animals are born and maintained in a sterile environment, devoid of any microorganisms. This enables researchers to investigate the effects of specific pathogens on various surgical procedures and evaluate the efficacy of preventive measures, including antibiotics and vaccines. Additionally, germfree animals assist in understanding the mechanisms of infection by providing a controlled environment to study the pathogenesis of surgical site infections. Their utility extends to studying the impact of surgical interventions on gut microbiota and subsequent systemic effects. Various surgical techniques, including aseptic procedures and laminar flow operating rooms, are utilized to maintain sterility during experiments. Overall, germfree animals are crucial tools for surgical research, contributing to advancements in infection control and improving patient outcomes.

Results of treatment of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy. A retrospective study on the treatment outcomes of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy was conducted in 85 patients over a 5-year period. The study aimed to evaluate the functional outcomes and complications associated with this surgical procedure. Overall, satisfactory functional outcomes were achieved in 75% of the patients, with a mean follow-up of 36 months. However, the occurrence of postoperative complications was relatively high, with 28% of the patients experiencing wound infection and 15% developing postoperative stiffness. Additionally, the study found that younger patients and those with comminuted fractures had poorer functional outcomes. Despite the relatively high complication rates, partial patellectomy remains a viable treatment option for displaced patellar fractures, especially in cases where anatomical reduction cannot be achieved. Further studies are warranted to explore ways to reduce postoperative complications and improve overall treatment outcomes.

Overnight admission of outpatient strabismus patients.  The trend to outpatient strabismus surgery prompted us to determine the frequency of, and the reasons for, postoperative overnight hospital admission following such surgery. The increasing popularity of outpatient strabismus surgery has led to a need for a better understanding of the frequency and rationale for overnight hospital admission following surgery. In this study, we analyzed the data of patients who underwent strabismus surgery in an ambulatory setting. Out of a total of 200 patients, 25 (12.5%) required admission to the hospital overnight. The most common reasons for admission were nausea and vomiting (44%), pain control (24%), and ophthalmic monitoring (20%). Other factors contributing to overnight admission included patient preference (8%) and surgical complications (4%). Interestingly, patients who underwent adjustable suture surgery were more likely to be admitted compared to those who underwent non-adjustable suture surgery. These findings suggest that while the majority of strabismus patients can be managed as outpatients, a subset of patients may require overnight admission for optimal postoperative care.

Therapy of persistent human papillomavirus disease with two different interferon species. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of two different interferon species in the treatment of persistent human papillomavirus (HPV) disease. A total of 120 patients with persistent HPV infection were enrolled in the study and randomly assigned to receive either interferon-alpha or interferon-beta therapy. The patients underwent a 6-month treatment period followed by a 6-month follow-up period. The primary outcome measure was the clearance of HPV infection, determined by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis. Secondary outcome measures included improvement in symptoms and adverse events. Results showed that both interferon-alpha and interferon-beta effectively cleared HPV infection in a significant proportion of patients. However, interferon-beta demonstrated a higher clearance rate compared to interferon-alpha (68% vs 55%). Both therapies were well-tolerated, with minimal adverse events reported. These findings suggest that both interferon species are viable options for the treatment of persistent HPV disease, with interferon-beta showing slightly superior efficacy. Further studies are needed to confirm these results and optimize treatment strategies.

Dissociation between pain and autonomic disturbances in cluster headache. Cluster headache is a primary headache disorder characterized by severe, unilateral pain accompanied by autonomic disturbances. However, in some cases, there may be dissociation between pain and autonomic symptoms. This case report presents a 45-year-old male with a history of episodic cluster headache who experienced attacks without associated autonomic disturbances. The patient reported severe, unilateral orbital and temporal pain consistent with cluster headache, but did not experience ipsilateral lacrimation, rhinorrhea, or ptosis during these episodes. Neurological examination and brain imaging were unremarkable. The patient was initially treated with oxygen therapy and triptans, but experienced only partial relief. He responded well to verapamil, a calcium channel blocker, and has remained symptom-free on maintenance therapy. Dissociation of pain and autonomic symptoms in cluster headache is rare, but has been previously reported. Clinicians should be aware of this atypical presentation and consider it in their differential diagnosis when evaluating patients with severe, unilateral headache. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms of dissociation in cluster headache.

Reduction of the membrane fluidity of human breast cancer cells by tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol on the membrane fluidity of human breast cancer cells. Two breast cancer cell lines, MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231, were treated with tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol at various concentrations. The membrane fluidity was measured using a fluorescence polarization technique. The results showed that both tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol significantly reduced the membrane fluidity of the breast cancer cells in a concentration-dependent manner. However, the effect was more pronounced with tamoxifen. These findings suggest that tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol may exert their anti-cancer effects, at least in part, by altering the membrane fluidity of breast cancer cells. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and to explore the potential clinical implications of these findings.

Application of coronary angioplasty to the septal perforator arteries. Coronary angioplasty is a commonly applied procedure for the treatment of coronary artery disease. However, its application to the septal perforator arteries, which supply blood to the septum of the heart, has been relatively understudied. This abstract aims to summarize the current understanding and effectiveness of coronary angioplasty in the septal perforator arteries. Recent studies have shown promising results with the use of this procedure, indicating improved coronary blood flow and alleviation of symptoms. However, further research is still needed to establish optimal techniques, procedural safety, and long-term outcomes. This abstract highlights the potential of septal perforator angioplasty as a valuable intervention in the management of coronary artery disease.

Biotype as determinant of natural immunising effect of cholera. The role of biotype in the natural immunizing effect of cholera has been investigated in this study. Cholera is a serious diarrheal disease caused by Vibrio cholerae, and it is known that infection with one biotype can provide protection against subsequent infection with the same biotype. However, the immunizing effect across different biotypes is not well understood. This study aimed to analyze the serological response of individuals infected with different biotypes of V. cholerae and assess the cross-protection between biotypes. The findings suggest that the biotype of the infecting strain influences the natural immunizing effect of cholera and may have implications for vaccine development and control strategies.

Adventitial red blood cells produce intimal platelet accumulation in cerebral arteries of cats following subarachnoid hemorrhage. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a devastating condition that can lead to the accumulation of red blood cells (RBCs) in the cerebral arteries, triggering an inflammatory response and subsequent intimal platelet accumulation. This study aimed to investigate the role of adventitial RBCs in this process. A feline SAH model was utilized, and cerebral arteries were examined for RBC accumulation and platelet adhesion. Results showed significant adventitial RBC accumulation in the affected arteries, which correlated with increased platelet adhesion on the intimal surface. Furthermore, inhibition of adventitial RBC accumulation using a specific antibody reduced platelet adhesion, suggesting a causal relationship. These findings highlight the crucial role of adventitial RBCs in promoting intimal platelet accumulation following SAH. Targeting adventitial RBCs could potentially offer a therapeutic strategy to reduce platelet adhesion and mitigate the adverse consequences of SAH-induced cerebral artery inflammation. Further investigation is warranted to explore the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon and develop targeted interventions for SAH management.

Treatment of cutaneous T cell lymphoma with a combination of low-dose interferon alfa-2b and retinoids. Cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL) is a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that affects the skin. Current treatments for CTCL often involve systemic chemotherapy and immunotherapy, which can have significant side effects. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of a combination treatment using low-dose interferon alfa-2b and retinoids in 20 patients with CTCL. The treatment regimen was well-tolerated and resulted in a significant improvement in skin lesions and overall response rate. Adverse events were minimal and manageable. These findings suggest that the combination of low-dose interferon alfa-2b and retinoids may be a safe and effective treatment option for patients with CTCL, offering an alternative to more aggressive therapies. Further studies with larger patient cohorts are needed to confirm these findings and determine the long-term efficacy and safety of this combination treatment.

Cervical spine stabilization.  A three-dimensional, biomechanical evaluation of rotational stability, strength, and failure mechanisms. Cervical spine stabilization is an essential component of treating various spinal pathologies and injuries. This study aimed to evaluate the rotational stability, strength, and failure mechanisms of three-dimensional cervical spine stabilization techniques. Ten cadaveric cervical spine specimens were subjected to biomechanical testing using a custom-built testing apparatus. Each specimen underwent axial rotation under different conditions, including intact, destabilized with a simulated disc herniation, and stabilized with three different techniques: anterior cervical discectomy and fusion, hybrid construct, and posterior cervical fixation. The rotational stability was assessed by measuring range of motion, torque, and failure load. The results showed that all stabilization techniques significantly reduced the range of motion and torque compared to the destabilized condition. However, the posterior cervical fixation technique demonstrated superior rotational stability and failure load compared to the other techniques. This study provides valuable insights into the biomechanical aspects of cervical spine stabilization, aiding in the development of more effective surgical interventions.

Response of the Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome to treatment of associated small-cell lung carcinoma.  We evaluated the outcome in 16 patients with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) associated with histologically verified small-cell carcinoma (SCC). This study aimed to assess the response of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) associated with small-cell lung carcinoma (SCC) to treatment. Sixteen patients with histologically confirmed SCC and LEMS were included in the evaluation. Treatment consisted of chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy for SCC, and immunosuppressive therapy for LEMS. Out of the 16 patients, 9 had a complete or partial response to treatment, while the remaining 7 showed no response. Overall, the median survival time was 11 months. The study suggests that treatment of the underlying SCC can lead to improvement in LEMS symptoms in some patients, although the response rate was not high. Further research is needed to explore better treatment strategies for this association.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease--more than a renal disease.  Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the most common genetic disease, affecting a half million Americans. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is a genetic disorder that affects the kidneys and is considered the most prevalent genetic disease in the United States, affecting approximately 500,000 individuals. However, recent research has shown that ADPKD is not just a renal disease, but also has systemic manifestations.
