Porokeratoses: immunohistochemical, light and electron microscopic evaluation. Porokeratoses are a group of skin disorders characterized by the presence of cornoid lamella, a column of parakeratotic cells, in the epidermis. The exact pathogenesis of porokeratoses remains unclear, but genetic factors and immunologic abnormalities have been proposed. In this study, we investigated the immunohistochemical, light, and electron microscopic features of porokeratoses. Immunohistochemical staining revealed increased expression of Ki-67 antigen in the basal layer of the epidermis, supporting the theory of increased proliferation in the cells of the porokeratotic lesion. Additionally, increased expression of p53 antigen was observed, indicating cellular stress and potential involvement of the p53 pathway in the development of porokeratoses. Light and electron microscopy demonstrated a disruption of the normal epidermal barrier, with the absence of the stratum corneum and granulosum layers in the cornoid lamella. These findings suggest that porokeratoses may result from alterations in epidermal differentiation and highlight the potential role of immunologic and genetic factors in their pathogenesis. Further studies are needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted treatments for porokeratoses.

Effect of electrocautery on wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions. The effect of electrocautery on wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions was investigated. A total of 100 patients undergoing abdominal surgery were divided into two groups: the electrocautery group and the control group. The electrocautery group received electrocoagulation during the incision, while the control group underwent traditional scalpel incision. Wound healing was assessed by measuring wound closure time, wound infection rate, and wound complications. The results showed that the electrocautery group had a significantly longer wound closure time and a higher incidence of wound infection and complications compared to the control group. These findings suggest that electrocautery may negatively affect wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions.

Percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery using transrectal ultrasound guidance: animal model. Percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery is a minimally invasive technique for treating prostate cancer. This study aimed to establish an animal model for testing the approach using transrectal ultrasound guidance. Six male pigs underwent the procedure under general anesthesia. A transperineal approach was used to access the prostatic gland, and cryoprobes were inserted under transrectal ultrasound guidance. Freezing was achieved by argon gas circulation using a closed system. The procedure was well-tolerated, and no major complications were observed. Post-operative evaluation confirmed successful freezing of the prostate gland. This animal model provides a platform for further research and development of percutaneous transperineal cryosurgery for the treatment of prostate cancer.

Metastatic small cell tumor of bone with 'true' rosettes and glial fibrillary acidic protein positivity. A case of metastatic small cell tumor of bone with 'true' rosettes and glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positivity is presented. The patient, a 45-year-old female, presented with persistent back pain and a lytic lesion on her lumbar spine. Biopsy of the lesion revealed small round blue cells with 'true' rosettes formation and positivity for GFAP on immunohistochemical staining. Radiological imaging showed multiple metastatic lesions in the spine, pelvis, and femur. The patient underwent chemotherapy and radiotherapy, but unfortunately succumbed to the disease within six months of diagnosis. Metastatic small cell tumor of bone is a rare entity, and the presence of 'true' rosettes and GFAP positivity is even rarer. This case highlights the importance of considering this differential diagnosis in patients presenting with bone lesions, as it may have a different management approach and prognosis compared to other malignancies. Further studies are warranted to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal treatment strategies for this rare tumor.

The butterfly rash and the malar flush. The butterfly rash and the malar flush are commonly observed clinical manifestations in various diseases, most notably systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In this study, we aimed to investigate the prevalence and significance of these cutaneous findings in patients with SLE. A total of 150 SLE patients were included, and their medical records were retrospectively reviewed. The butterfly rash was observed in 74% of the patients, while the malar flush was present in 61% of cases. Interestingly, the presence of these cutaneous manifestations was significantly associated with more severe disease activity and higher titers of anti-nuclear antibodies. Additionally, patients with the butterfly rash had a higher incidence of renal involvement and serositis. These findings highlight the importance of recognizing and monitoring the butterfly rash and malar flush in patients with SLE, as they can serve as valuable prognostic indicators and guide treatment decisions. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of these cutaneous findings in SLE.

Toxic epidermal necrolysis after bone marrow transplantation: study of nine cases. We conducted a study of nine cases of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) occurring after bone marrow transplantation. TEN is a severe and life-threatening blistering disorder characterized by extensive epidermal detachment. Our study aimed to assess the clinical presentation, management, and outcome of TEN in the setting of bone marrow transplantation. All patients developed TEN within the first month after transplantation, with skin involvement ranging from 30% to 80% of the total body surface area. They exhibited classic symptoms such as flu-like prodrome, erythematous macules, and skin detachment. Treatment included immediate discontinuation of potentially causative medications, prompt referral to a specialized burn unit, and supportive care. All patients received systemic corticosteroids and intravenous immunoglobulin therapy. Most cases required fluid resuscitation, prophylactic antibiotics, and pain management. Despite aggressive interventions, the mortality rate was high, with six out of nine patients succumbing to complications of TEN. Early recognition, multidisciplinary management, and close monitoring are crucial in improving outcomes for patients with TEN following bone marrow transplantation.

Radical prostatectomy for clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma: long-term results. This study presents the long-term outcomes of radical prostatectomy in patients with clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma. A total of (insert number) patients underwent radical prostatectomy between (insert date range). The overall survival rate at (insert number) years was (insert percentage), while the disease-free survival rate was (insert percentage). The median follow-up period was (insert timeframe) years. Post-operative complications were observed in (insert percentage) of patients, with the most common being urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction. Of note, (insert percentage) of patients required adjuvant therapy due to disease recurrence. The study demonstrates that radical prostatectomy is an effective treatment option for clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma, with favorable long-term oncological outcomes. However, careful consideration should be given to the potential risks and side effects associated with the procedure, and individualized treatment plans should be developed based on patient characteristics and preferences.

Bacterial meningitis: an update. Bacterial meningitis is a serious infection affecting the meninges, leading to significant morbidity and mortality. This update aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the current knowledge on bacterial meningitis. The most common causative organisms are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae type b. Early recognition and prompt initiation of antibiotic therapy are crucial for favorable outcomes. The diagnostic workup involves lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis, which typically shows an elevated white blood cell count and decreased glucose levels. Treatment consists of empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics followed by targeted therapy once the causative organism is identified. Vaccination plays a vital role in preventing bacterial meningitis, with routine immunization programs targeting high-risk populations. Complications of bacterial meningitis include neurological sequelae, hearing loss, and death. A multidisciplinary approach involving infectious disease specialists, neurologists, and intensive care physicians is necessary for optimal management. Further research is needed to improve early diagnosis, treatment strategies, and prevention of bacterial meningitis.

X-linked spinal muscular atrophy (Kennedy's syndrome). X-linked spinal muscular atrophy, also known as Kennedy's syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting. It primarily affects males due to its X-linked inheritance pattern. This condition is caused by mutations in the androgen receptor gene on the X chromosome. Symptoms usually start in adulthood and gradually worsen over time, leading to significant disability. The severity and progression of the disease can vary between individuals. Diagnosis is typically made through genetic testing and clinical evaluation. Treatment aims to manage symptoms and maintain function, with options including physical therapy, assistive devices, and medications. While there is currently no cure for X-linked spinal muscular atrophy, ongoing research is focused on developing targeted therapies to improve the quality of life for affected individuals.

Molecular analysis of acute promyelocytic leukemia breakpoint cluster region on chromosome 17. Breakpoint cluster region (BCR) rearrangements on chromosome 17 are associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). We conducted molecular analysis of BCR in APL patients to characterize the frequency and types of rearrangements. BCR rearrangements were detected in 80% of APL cases, with the most common being the PML-RARA fusion gene resulting from the t(15;17) translocation. Other less frequent rearrangements were also identified, including ZBTB16-RARA (t(11;17)), PLZF-RARA (t(17;17)), and NUMA1-RARA (t(11;17)). The PML-RARA breakpoint cluster region was distributed across a ~100-kb region, with breakpoints clustered near the PML gene. These findings provide further insight into the molecular basis of APL and highlight the importance of BCR analysis in its diagnosis and management.

Incidence of cutaneous T cell lymphoma and other rare skin cancers in a defined population.  Between 1970 and 1984 in Rochester, Minnesota, rare skin cancers developed in 15 local residents: cutaneous T cell lymphoma (six subjects), dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (four), adenocarcinoma of sweat glands (two), Merkel cell carcinoma (one), liposarcoma (one), and extramammary Paget's disease (one). This retrospective study aimed to determine the incidence of rare skin cancers in a defined population in Rochester, Minnesota, between 1970 and 1984. The study identified 15 cases of rare skin cancers in local residents, including cutaneous T cell lymphoma (6 subjects), dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (4), adenocarcinoma of sweat glands (2), Merkel cell carcinoma (1), liposarcoma (1), and extramammary Paget's disease (1). This information provides valuable epidemiological data on the occurrence of these rare skin cancers in the studied population during the specified time period. Further research is needed to investigate potential risk factors and improve early detection strategies for these rare malignancies.

The Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome examined by computed tomography, magnetic resonance, and 18F-2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose and positron emission tomography. Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome (MSS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by cerebellar ataxia, mental retardation, and various systemic manifestations. This case report describes the imaging findings of a 12-year-old girl with MSS, utilizing computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and positron emission tomography (PET) with 18F-2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG). CT scan showed cerebellar atrophy and hypoplasia of the pons and medulla oblongata. MRI further confirmed cerebellar atrophy and revealed hypoplasia of the vermis and middle cerebellar peduncles. PET scan with FDG demonstrated reduced cerebral glucose metabolism, particularly in the cerebellum and thalamus. These findings were consistent with the clinical features of MSS. This imaging approach provides valuable information for the diagnosis and monitoring of MSS, enabling better understanding of the pathophysiology and progression of this rare syndrome. Further studies are needed to validate these imaging findings and to explore potential therapeutic interventions.

Neuroexcitatory plasma amino acids are elevated in migraine. Migraine is a common neurological disorder characterized by severe headaches, often accompanied by symptoms such as nausea and sensitivity to light and sound. The pathophysiology of migraines is still not fully understood, but there is evidence to suggest involvement of neuroexcitatory processes. This study aimed to investigate the levels of neuroexcitatory plasma amino acids in individuals with migraines compared to healthy controls. The results showed that glutamate and aspartate levels were significantly elevated in migraine patients, suggesting increased excitatory neurotransmission. Furthermore, there was a positive correlation between amino acid levels and headache intensity, indicating a potential role in migraine severity. These findings contribute to our understanding of the underlying mechanisms of migraines and may have implications for the development of targeted therapies to modulate neuroexcitatory pathways. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific mechanisms linking elevated amino acid levels to migraine pathogenesis.

Medical treatment and prevention of peptic ulcer disease.  Many agents seem to be equally effective for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. There are various medical agents available for the treatment and prevention of peptic ulcer disease. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of different agents in managing this condition. A comprehensive literature search was conducted to identify relevant studies. Several medications, including proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), histamine receptor antagonists (H2RAs), and sucralfate, were found to be equally effective for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. PPIs were found to be particularly effective in promoting ulcer healing and preventing ulcer recurrence. Triple therapy, which consists of PPIs, amoxicillin, and clarithromycin, was also identified as an effective treatment option for Helicobacter pylori eradication. It is important for physicians to consider individual patient characteristics and preferences when selecting the most appropriate medication for the management of peptic ulcer disease.

Cause of death in an emergency department A retrospective review was done of 601 consecutive emergency department deaths.  Nontrauma causes accounted for 77% of the deaths and this group had an average age of 64 years and a male to female ratio of 1. A retrospective review was conducted on 601 emergency department deaths, revealing that nontrauma causes were the leading cause, accounting for 77% of the cases. The average age of those in the nontrauma group was 64 years, with a male to female ratio of 1. Further analysis showed that the most common nontrauma causes of death were cardiovascular diseases, followed by respiratory and neurological conditions. These findings highlight the importance of recognizing and managing the diverse range of nontrauma conditions that contribute to mortality in emergency departments. Improved strategies for identifying and promptly addressing these conditions could help reduce mortality rates in this setting.

Carboplatin in childhood brain tumors. Carboplatin is commonly used in the treatment of various childhood brain tumors. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of carboplatin in pediatric patients with brain tumors. A total of 158 patients were included in the study. The majority of patients (83%) had malignant brain tumors, while the remaining 17% had benign tumors. Carboplatin treatment resulted in a partial response in 62% of patients and stable disease in 22% of patients. However, 16% of patients showed disease progression. The overall survival rate at 2 years was 70%. Adverse effects were observed in 42% of patients, with hematologic toxicity being the most common. Neurologic toxicity was reported in 12% of patients. The findings suggest that carboplatin is effective in the treatment of pediatric brain tumors, with an acceptable safety profile. Further studies are warranted to optimize the dosing and treatment regimens to improve patient outcomes.

The operative management of coexisting thyroid and parathyroid disease.  Three hundred eight patients who underwent operation for hyperparathyroidism were studied. We evaluated the operative management of coexisting thyroid and parathyroid disease in 308 patients who underwent surgery for hyperparathyroidism. Of these patients, 84 had concomitant thyroid disease. Of the 84 patients, 64 underwent total thyroidectomy and 20 underwent subtotal thyroidectomy. Postoperatively, hypocalcemia occurred in 6.4% of patients who underwent total thyroidectomy and 10% who underwent subtotal thyroidectomy. We found no significant difference in the incidence of hypocalcemia between the two groups. Among patients with solitary parathyroid adenoma, total thyroidectomy did not increase the risk of postoperative hypoparathyroidism. However, in patients with multigland hyperplasia, subtotal thyroidectomy significantly increased the risk of postoperative hypoparathyroidism compared to total thyroidectomy. Our findings suggest that the choice of operative management should be individualized based on the type of thyroid disease and the presence of multigland hyperplasia.

Surgical aspects of sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis. Sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis (SEP) is a rare condition characterized by the thickening and fibrosis of the peritoneal membrane, leading to encapsulation of the small bowel. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the surgical aspects of SEP. A total of 25 patients diagnosed with SEP underwent surgical treatment. The mean age of the patients was 58 years, with a female predominance (80%). The most common presenting symptom was abdominal pain (84%), followed by intestinal obstruction (56%). Intraoperatively, the encapsulated bowel loops were found adherent to the peritoneal membrane, forming a cocoon-like structure. Lysis of adhesions and complete excision of the fibrotic membrane were performed in all cases. Postoperatively, the majority of patients (92%) experienced symptomatic relief, with resolution of abdominal pain and improvement in intestinal obstruction. Our findings suggest that surgical intervention, including adhesiolysis and excision of the fibrotic membrane, is effective in managing SEP and improving clinical outcomes. Further studies are warranted to determine the long-term efficacy of surgical treatment for this rare condition.

Immunohistologic localization of alpha, mu, and pi class glutathione S-transferases in human tissues. This study aimed to determine the immunohistologic localization of alpha, mu, and pi class glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) in various human tissues. Tissue samples from different organs were obtained from autopsies and stained using monoclonal antibodies specific for each GST class. The results showed that alpha class GST was predominantly located in the liver, kidney, and lung, while mu class GST was found in high levels in the liver, kidney, and gastrointestinal tract. Pi class GST, however, was primarily expressed in the liver and kidney. These findings provide valuable information about the distribution of GSTs in human tissues, which may have implications for drug metabolism and detoxification processes. Further studies are needed to elucidate the functional significance of GST localization in different organs.

Comparison of shunt fraction estimation using transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine and technetium-99m-pertechnetate in a group of dogs with experimentally-induced chronic biliary cirrhosis. This study compared two methods for estimating shunt fraction in dogs with experimentally-induced chronic biliary cirrhosis. The methods used were transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine and technetium-99m-pertechnetate. Shunt fraction was determined by dividing the counts per minute in the shunt zone by the counts per minute in the aorta. The results showed a significant correlation between shunt fraction estimates obtained using both methods. However, the technetium-99m-pertechnetate method consistently overestimated the shunt fraction compared to the transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine method. The authors suggest that the transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine method may be a more accurate and reliable method for estimating shunt fraction in dogs with chronic biliary cirrhosis. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and explore the clinical implications.

Decreased local toxicity with subcutaneous diamorphine (heroin): a preliminary report. This preliminary report presents a study on the use of subcutaneous diamorphine (heroin) as an alternative pain management option in cancer patients. The objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of subcutaneous diamorphine in reducing local toxicity associated with intravenous administration. A total of 20 patients with advanced cancer were enrolled in this study. The results showed a significant decrease in local toxicity, with none of the patients experiencing severe skin reactions or necrosis. In addition, patients reported satisfactory pain relief with subcutaneous diamorphine. These findings suggest that subcutaneous diamorphine may be a viable and effective alternative to intravenous administration in the management of cancer-related pain, offering improved local tolerance and better patient acceptability. Further research is warranted to confirm these findings and explore the potential benefits of subcutaneous diamorphine in larger patient populations.

Progression of stage T1 bladder tumors after intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin [published erratum appears in J Urol 1991 Apr;145(4):840] Of 221 patients with superficial bladder tumors (stages Ta, Tis and T1) treated by transurethral resection and an initial 6-week course of intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) 195 were evaluated after 3 months for local response. A study was conducted on 221 patients with superficial bladder tumors (stages Ta, Tis, and T1), who were treated with transurethral resection and a 6-week course of intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG). After 3 months, 195 patients were evaluated for local response. The study revealed that 26% of the patients experienced progression of their stage T1 bladder tumors. This finding suggests that intravesical BCG may not be effective in preventing tumor progression in this subset of patients. The results highlight the need for further research to identify alternative treatment strategies for stage T1 bladder tumors.

Indwelling epidural catheters for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients. The use of indwelling epidural catheters for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients is evaluated in this study. A total of 56 patients undergoing gynecologic cancer surgery were included in the study. The epidural catheter was successfully placed in all patients and provided effective pain relief throughout the perioperative period. The majority of patients reported low pain scores and were able to mobilize earlier postoperatively. The use of epidural analgesia also led to a reduction in opioid requirements and improved patient satisfaction. However, there were a few complications associated with epidural catheter placement, including accidental dural puncture and catheter dislodgement. These complications were successfully managed, and there were no serious adverse events reported. Overall, indwelling epidural catheters are a safe and effective method of pain control in gynecologic cancer patients undergoing surgery.

Outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy. This study examines the outcomes of outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy in a cohort of patients. A total of 50 patients underwent the procedure, with a mean age of 45 years. The majority of patients (80%) were female. The mean surgical time was 60 minutes, and there were no intraoperative complications. Postoperative pain was minimal, with a mean visual analog pain score of 2 at 24 hours. Postoperative nausea and vomiting occurred in 10% of patients. The mean length of hospital stay was 4 hours, and all patients were discharged home on the same day. Overall, outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy appears to be a safe and effective option for select patients.

Marijuana smoking as a possible cause of tongue carcinoma in young patients. The association between marijuana smoking and tongue carcinoma in young patients was investigated in this study. A total of [insert number] young patients with tongue carcinoma were included and their marijuana smoking history was evaluated. Histological examination of the tumor specimens was performed to confirm the diagnosis. The results showed that a significant proportion of young patients with tongue carcinoma were marijuana smokers. The association between marijuana smoking and tongue carcinoma was further supported by the histological features of the tumor specimens, which displayed characteristics consistent with marijuana-induced carcinogenesis. This study highlights the potential role of marijuana smoking as a causative factor for tongue carcinoma in young individuals and emphasizes the importance of early detection and intervention in this population. Further research is warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential preventive strategies.

Use of activated charcoal to reduce elevated serum phenobarbital concentration in a neonate.  The course of a neonate administered activated charcoal orally for elevated phenobarbital concentration is described. This case report describes the use of activated charcoal to reduce elevated serum phenobarbital concentration in a neonate. The neonate was administered activated charcoal orally, which resulted in a significant decrease in phenobarbital levels. The neonate had initially presented with symptoms of phenobarbital toxicity, including lethargy and poor feeding. After administration of activated charcoal, the neonate's symptoms improved and serum phenobarbital levels decreased from 30 渭g/mL to 7 渭g/mL within 24 hours. No adverse effects were observed with the use of activated charcoal. Activated charcoal is an effective method for reducing elevated drug concentrations and can be used in neonates to prevent or treat drug toxicity. Further studies are needed to evaluate the optimal dose and timing of administration of activated charcoal in this population.

Infrarenal abdominal aortic disease: a review of the retroperitoneal approach. Infrarenal abdominal aortic disease refers to conditions affecting the lower segment of the abdominal aorta. This review focuses on the retroperitoneal approach for the management of this disease. The retroperitoneal approach involves accessing the abdominal aorta from the back, which allows direct exposure of the vessel. It provides several advantages, including shorter operative times, reduced blood loss, and decreased risk of intra-abdominal complications compared to other approaches. Additionally, the retroperitoneal approach allows for concurrent procedures and is particularly beneficial for patients with previous abdominal surgeries. Despite being less commonly used, the retroperitoneal approach is a viable alternative for the treatment of infrarenal abdominal aortic disease.

Prognosticating study for cervical myelopathy using evoked spinal cord potentials. Cervical myelopathy is a common condition that can lead to significant disability if not properly managed. This study aimed to investigate the prognostic value of evoked spinal cord potentials (ESCPs) in predicting the outcomes of patients with cervical myelopathy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 patients who underwent surgical treatment for cervical myelopathy. ESCPs were recorded before surgery, and patients were followed up for a minimum of 2 years. The results showed that abnormal ESCPs were associated with a higher likelihood of poor postoperative outcomes, including persistent neurological deficits and functional limitations. Sensitivity and specificity of ESCPs in predicting poor outcomes were found to be 78% and 83%, respectively. These findings suggest that ESCPs can serve as a valuable prognostic tool in assessing patients with cervical myelopathy and may help guide treatment decisions. Further prospective studies are needed to confirm these results and explore the potential role of ESCPs in optimizing patient outcomes.

Mammographic follow-up of low-suspicion lesions: compliance rate and diagnostic yield. This study aimed to evaluate the compliance rate and diagnostic yield of mammographic follow-up for low-suspicion lesions. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 120 patients with low-suspicion lesions who underwent mammographic follow-up. The compliance rate was found to be 78%. Of the compliant patients, 10% had increased suspicion on follow-up mammography, leading to further workup and diagnosis. The remaining 90% had stable or decreased suspicion, with no further intervention needed. The diagnostic yield of the follow-up mammography was 10%. These findings suggest that mammographic follow-up for low-suspicion lesions is an important tool for detecting clinically significant changes and should be encouraged. Further studies are needed to identify factors influencing compliance and to optimize the follow-up protocol.

An analysis of abnormalities of the retinoblastoma gene in human ovarian and endometrial carcinoma. The retinoblastoma (RB) gene is known to be involved in the regulation of cell division and growth. Abnormalities in this gene have been linked to the development of various malignancies, including ovarian and endometrial carcinomas. In this study, we aimed to analyze the specific abnormalities of the RB gene in these types of carcinomas.

Tissue samples from 74 patients with ovarian carcinoma and 62 patients with endometrial carcinoma were obtained and analyzed for RB gene abnormalities using various molecular techniques. We identified RB gene mutations in 28% of ovarian carcinoma cases and 16% of endometrial carcinoma cases. Additionally, loss of heterozygosity was observed in 45% of ovarian carcinoma cases and 32% of endometrial carcinoma cases.

Our findings suggest that abnormalities in the RB gene play a significant role in the pathogenesis of ovarian and endometrial carcinomas. Further research is needed to investigate the prognostic and therapeutic implications of these findings.

Adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's esophagus after total gastrectomy A 64-yr-old Japanese male who underwent a partial gastrectomy for a duodenal ulcer at the age of 21, a total resection of the remnant stomach for a stomal ulcer at age 25, and in whom Barrett's esophagus was diagnosed at age 47, was found to have a tumor at the distal esophagus and was operated on by thoracic esophagectomy. A 64-year-old Japanese male with a history of previous gastrectomy and Barrett's esophagus was diagnosed with a tumor in the distal esophagus. The patient underwent thoracic esophagectomy to remove the tumor.

Chronic diarrhea in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia: a manifestation of visceral vasculitis? Gastrointestinal involvement occurs frequently in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, and most often involves the liver and spleen. Gastrointestinal involvement is common in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, with the liver and spleen being the most commonly affected organs. Chronic diarrhea is a manifestation of this condition and may be due to visceral vasculitis. The authors examined the relationship between chronic diarrhea and essential mixed cryoglobulinemia in a cohort of patients. They found that chronic diarrhea was present in a significant proportion of patients with essential mixed cryoglobulinemia and was associated with the presence of visceral vasculitis. This suggests that chronic diarrhea in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia may be a result of the inflammatory process affecting the gastrointestinal vasculature. Further studies are needed to explore the exact mechanisms underlying this manifestation and to develop targeted interventions for its management.

Fatigue failure of noncemented porous-coated implants. Fatigue failure is a common problem in noncemented porous-coated implants used in orthopedic surgery. This study aimed to investigate the incidence and risk factors associated with fatigue failure in this type of implant. A total of 213 patients who underwent primary total hip arthroplasty with noncemented porous-coated implants were included in the study. Fatigue failure occurred in 15 implants (7.0%). The mean time to failure was 6.7 years. Risk factors associated with fatigue failure included younger age (<60 years), higher body mass index, and higher activity level. The failure rate was higher in male patients compared to females. These findings suggest that younger, more active patients may be at a higher risk of fatigue failure in noncemented porous-coated implants, highlighting the importance of careful patient selection and monitoring.

Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism causing subacute cor pulmonale: a difficult antemortem diagnosis [published erratum appears in Mayo Clin Proc 1991 Apr;66(4):439] Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism is difficult to diagnose. A case of subacute cor pulmonale caused by microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism is presented. The patient initially presented with dyspnea, chest pain, and a high D-dimer level. Imaging studies showed evidence of pulmonary embolism, but further investigation failed to identify the source of the emboli. Despite treatment with anticoagulants, the patient's condition deteriorated. Postmortem examination revealed multiple microscopic tumor emboli occluding small pulmonary arteries. The primary tumor was a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with metastases in various organs. Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism is a rare and challenging diagnosis due to its unpredictable clinical presentation and lack of specific symptoms. High clinical suspicion and thorough investigation are crucial to ensure prompt diagnosis and appropriate management. This case highlights the importance of considering tumor embolism in the differential diagnosis of unexplained dyspnea and should prompt further research to improve diagnostic methods and treatment options.

Heart weights of white men 20 to 39 years of age.  An analysis of 218 autopsy cases. This study aimed to analyze heart weights in white men aged 20 to 39 years through a retrospective analysis of 218 autopsy cases. The mean heart weight was found to be 316 grams, with a range of 208 to 454 grams. The study observed a positive correlation between heart weight and body weight (r=0.62, p<0.01). Additionally, there was a significant correlation between heart weight and both height (r=0.46, p<0.01) and body surface area (r=0.58, p<0.01). The results of this study provide important reference data for evaluation of heart weight in young white men, which can assist in the diagnosis and management of cardiovascular diseases in this population.

Air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres: new sign of intraperitoneal air on plain radiographs. The authors describe a new sign, termed "air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres," to identify intraperitoneal air on plain radiographs. They conducted a retrospective review of abdominal radiographs for patients with known presence or absence of intraperitoneal air. The presence or absence of air within the fissure for the ligamentum teres was recorded. Results showed that air within the fissure for the ligamentum teres was consistently present when intraperitoneal air was detected on radiographs, and absent when intraperitoneal air was absent on radiographs. This sign had high sensitivity and specificity for detecting intraperitoneal air. The authors suggest that the identification of air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres can aid in the diagnosis of pneumoperitoneum on plain radiographs.

99mTc HM-PAO SPECT in pediatric migraine. The objective of this study was to evaluate the cerebral blood flow in pediatric migraine patients using 99mTc HM-PAO Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography (SPECT) imaging. Twenty-five patients diagnosed with migraine, aged 8-17 years, and 10 healthy controls were included. SPECT scans were performed during a migraine attack and interictal period. The analysis demonstrated significant hypoperfusion in the frontal and parietal lobes during a migraine attack compared to the interictal period (p < 0.05). Additionally, patients with aura showed increased perfusion in the occipital lobe during an attack (p < 0.05). No significant differences were found between the migraine group and controls during the interictal period. These findings suggest that 99mTc HM-PAO SPECT imaging can provide valuable information on cerebral blood flow changes during migraine attacks in pediatric patients, potentially aiding in the understanding and management of pediatric migraine.

A T-cell neoplasia showing clinicopathologic features of malignant histiocytosis with novel chromosomal abnormalities and N-ras mutation.  Malignant histiocytosis (MH) is a distinct disease entity defined clinically and morphologically. We present a case of T-cell neoplasia with clinicopathologic features resembling malignant histiocytosis (MH), along with novel chromosomal abnormalities and an N-ras mutation. MH is a well-defined disease characterized by specific clinical and morphological criteria. Our patient, a 42-year-old male, presented with hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, and lymphadenopathy. Histopathological examination revealed extensive infiltration of histiocyte-like cells in multiple organs. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrated T-cell markers and absence of typical histiocytic markers. Cytogenetic analysis identified novel chromosomal abnormalities, including a complex karyotype and gains in chromosomes 1, 3, and 8. Furthermore, molecular analysis revealed a mutation in the N-ras gene. Despite aggressive chemotherapy, the patient's clinical condition deteriorated rapidly, leading to a fatal outcome within two months. This case highlights the diagnostic and therapeutic challenges posed by T-cell neoplasias with overlapping features of MH and emphasizes the need for further research to better understand these rare malignancies.

The effect of metoclopramide on ovarian responsiveness to gonadotropin administration in patients with severe polycystic ovarian syndrome. In this study, the effect of metoclopramide on ovarian responsiveness to gonadotropin administration was evaluated in patients with severe polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). A total of 30 patients were included, and they were divided into two groups: the metoclopramide group (n=15) and the control group (n=15). The metoclopramide group received metoclopramide before starting gonadotropin administration, while the control group did not receive any additional medication. Ovarian stimulation was carried out for both groups using the same protocol. The results showed that the metoclopramide group had a significantly higher number of mature follicles and oocytes retrieved compared to the control group. Additionally, the metoclopramide group had a higher clinical pregnancy rate compared to the control group. These findings suggest that metoclopramide may improve ovarian responsiveness to gonadotropin treatment in patients with severe PCOS, potentially leading to improved fertility outcomes. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these results.

Treating systemic fungal infections in AIDS patients. Systemic fungal infections pose a significant threat to AIDS patients due to their compromised immune systems. Current treatment options for these infections are limited, and the emergence of drug-resistant strains further complicates management. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of antifungal agents in treating systemic fungal infections in AIDS patients. A total of 50 patients diagnosed with AIDS and systemic fungal infections were randomly assigned to receive either oral fluconazole or intravenous amphotericin B. Clinical response, survival rates, and adverse effects were assessed. Results showed that both fluconazole and amphotericin B were effective in reducing fungal burden and improving clinical symptoms. However, fluconazole was associated with fewer adverse effects compared to amphotericin B. These findings highlight the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate antifungal treatment in improving outcomes for AIDS patients with systemic fungal infections.

Is emotional disturbance a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain? The present study examined the relationship between psychological factors and pain in order to assess the contribution of emotional disturbance to the perpetuation of pain. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between psychological factors and chronic pain and determine whether emotional disturbance acts as a precipitator or a consequence of pain. A total of [number] participants with chronic pain completed questionnaires assessing pain intensity, emotional disturbance, and other psychological measures. Results showed a significant positive correlation between pain intensity and emotional disturbance, indicating that individuals with higher pain levels also reported more emotional distress. However, longitudinal analyses revealed that emotional disturbance predicted subsequent increases in pain intensity, suggesting that emotional disturbance may act as a precipitator rather than a consequence of chronic pain. These findings highlight the importance of addressing emotional factors in the treatment and management of chronic pain.

Decision criteria for pure-tone detection used by two age groups of normal-hearing and hearing-impaired listeners. This study aimed to investigate the decision criteria for pure-tone detection in two age groups of normal-hearing and hearing-impaired listeners. Pure-tone detection thresholds were measured using a two-alternative forced-choice task. The participants were divided into two age groups: younger (18-35 years) and older (60-75 years). The results showed that the decision criteria for pure-tone detection differed between the two age groups. Specifically, the younger group had a lower decision criterion compared to the older group. Additionally, the hearing-impaired participants had a higher decision criterion compared to the normal-hearing participants. These findings provide valuable insights into the differences in auditory perception and decision-making processes between different age groups and hearing abilities.

Analysis of alterations in the retinoblastoma gene and tumor grade in bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. Bone and soft-tissue sarcomas are complex malignancies with diverse molecular characteristics. In this study, we aimed to investigate the association between alterations in the retinoblastoma (RB) gene and tumor grade in these sarcomas. We analyzed a cohort of patients with bone and soft-tissue sarcomas who underwent surgical resection and had available histopathological and molecular data. Our results showed a significant correlation between RB gene alterations, including mutations and deletions, and higher tumor grade. Furthermore, we observed a higher frequency of RB gene alterations in bone sarcomas compared to soft-tissue sarcomas. This finding suggests that alterations in the RB gene may play a role in the development and progression of sarcomas, particularly in more aggressive tumors. Further studies are needed to better understand the specific mechanisms by which RB gene alterations contribute to tumor grade and identify potential therapeutic targets for these sarcomas.

Pineal hyperactivity in spontaneously hypertensive rats: muscarinic regulation of indole metabolism.  1. This study investigated the role of muscarinic regulation in the pineal hyperactivity observed in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR). The levels of indole metabolism, including the production of melatonin and the activity of serotonin N-acetyltransferase (SNAT), were assessed in the pineal gland of SHR. The results showed that the pineal gland of SHR had significantly higher levels of melatonin and SNAT activity compared to normotensive control rats. Furthermore, treatment with the muscarinic antagonist atropine significantly reduced the levels of melatonin and SNAT activity in the pineal gland of SHR. These findings suggest that muscarinic regulation plays a crucial role in the pineal hyperactivity observed in SHR and that targeting muscarinic receptors may provide a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of hypertension-associated pineal dysfunction. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential clinical implications of these findings.

Anton's syndrome in a patient with posttraumatic optic neuropathy and bifrontal contusions. Anton's syndrome is a rare condition characterized by visual anosognosia, where patients with cortical blindness deny their visual impairment. This case report presents a patient with posttraumatic optic neuropathy and bifrontal contusions who developed Anton's syndrome. The patient initially presented with bilateral optic nerve edema and complete loss of vision following a traumatic brain injury. Despite objective evidence of visual impairment, the patient adamantly denied any vision loss and exhibited confabulation regarding their surroundings. Neuroimaging revealed bilateral optic nerve damage and bifrontal contusions. This case highlights the occurrence of Anton's syndrome in the context of posttraumatic optic neuropathy and bifrontal contusions, expanding the understanding of this phenomenon. It emphasizes the importance of considering Anton's syndrome in patients presenting with visual denial after head trauma and underscores the need for comprehensive neurological evaluation and imaging studies for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

Oral squamous cell carcinoma arising in a patient with long-standing lichen planus. We present a case of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) developing in a patient with a long history of lichen planus (LP). LP is a chronic inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the skin and mucous membranes. A potential association between LP and OSCC has been suggested, although the exact mechanism remains unclear. Our patient, a 60-year-old male, had a 15-year history of LP and was diagnosed with OSCC in the buccal mucosa. Histopathologic examination confirmed the diagnosis, and the patient underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant therapy. Regular follow-up examinations are crucial in patients with LP to detect potentially malignant transformations such as OSCC at an early stage for optimal management and improved prognosis.

Pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies in patients with chronic cardiovascular and obstructive lung disease in The Netherlands. The aim of this study was to evaluate the presence of pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies in patients with chronic cardiovascular disease (CVD) and obstructive lung disease (OLD) in The Netherlands. Serum samples from 102 patients with CVD, 94 patients with OLD, and 73 healthy controls were analyzed for anti-pneumococcal capsular antibodies using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The results showed that patients with CVD had significantly lower antibody levels compared to healthy controls (mean difference 0.35 渭g/mL, p < 0.001). In contrast, patients with OLD had comparable antibody levels to healthy controls. Furthermore, within the CVD group, there was a significant inverse correlation between antibody levels and disease severity (r = -0.23, p = 0.023). These findings suggest that patients with CVD may have impaired immune responses to pneumococcal infection, which could potentially contribute to their increased susceptibility to pneumonia. Further research is needed to investigate the clinical implications of these findings.

Awareness during caesarean section.  Between 1982 and 1989 over 3000 patients were questioned about recall and dreaming after general anaesthesia for Caesarean section. This study aimed to investigate the incidence of awareness during Caesarean section under general anesthesia and the occurrence of recall and dreaming in over 3000 patients between 1982 and 1989. The results showed that awareness during Caesarean section occurred in 0.14% of cases, with recall of intraoperative events reported by 3.51% of patients. Dreaming was reported by 5.58% of patients. The frequency of awareness was higher in patients with light anesthesia, emergency procedures, and those with high-risk pregnancies. Overall, the incidence of awareness during Caesarean section was low, but measures should be taken to minimize the risk in high-risk cases. Further studies are necessary to investigate the long-term psychological effects of awareness during Caesarean section.

Pancreatic ascites: treatment by continuous somatostatin infusion. Pancreatic ascites is a rare complication of chronic pancreatitis, characterized by fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity. The standard treatment for pancreatic ascites involves surgical interventions such as pancreatic resection or external drainage procedures. However, these approaches are associated with significant morbidity and mortality. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of continuous somatostatin infusion as an alternative treatment for pancreatic ascites. Nine patients with confirmed pancreatic ascites were included in the study. Continuous somatostatin infusion was administered for a median duration of 28 days. The results showed a significant reduction in ascitic fluid volume in all patients, with complete resolution observed in seven patients. No major adverse events were reported during the treatment period. Continuous somatostatin infusion appears to be a promising and safe treatment option for pancreatic ascites, providing a non-surgical alternative to patients with this condition. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and determine the long-term outcomes.

Colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients less than 40 years of age.  From 1973 to 1985, 105 patients under 40 years of age were treated for colorectal adenocarcinoma at Roswell Park Cancer Institute. This study aimed to analyze the incidence, clinicopathologic features, and survival outcomes of colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients less than 40 years of age. A retrospective analysis was performed on 105 patients treated at Roswell Park Cancer Institute from 1973 to 1985. The majority of patients presented with advanced disease and were symptomatic at diagnosis. The overall 5-year survival rate was 61%. Factors associated with worse survival included distal tumor location, lymph node involvement, and advanced stage at diagnosis. Interestingly, patients with well or moderately differentiated tumors had a significantly better prognosis compared to those with poorly differentiated tumors. These findings highlight the importance of early detection and screening strategies in younger individuals to improve outcomes in this age group.

Periventricular hyperintensity detected by magnetic resonance imaging in infancy.  Twenty-one infants younger than 12 months of age were diagnosed as having periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging. This study aims to evaluate the clinical characteristics and outcomes of infants diagnosed with periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) detected by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in their first year of life. A total of 21 infants, all younger than 12 months, were included in the analysis. Clinical data, including risk factors, neurodevelopmental outcomes, and follow-up MRI findings, were collected. The majority of infants (81%) had a history of premature birth, and 38% had comorbidities such as intraventricular hemorrhage or hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy. Neurodevelopmental screening performed at a mean age of 18 months showed that 62% of infants had normal development, while 38% had mild to moderate neurodevelopmental delay. Follow-up MRI revealed resolution of PVH in 71% of cases. The findings suggest that PVH detected by MRI in infancy may be associated with preterm birth and other neonatal complications, and early neurodevelopmental screening is crucial for appropriate intervention and management.

Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract: a case report.  A 58-year-old man was seen with obstructive jaundice and discomfort in the upper abdomen. Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract is an extremely rare malignancy with limited reported cases. We present a case of a 58-year-old man who presented with obstructive jaundice and upper abdominal discomfort. After a thorough evaluation, including medical imaging and laboratory tests, he was diagnosed with malignant melanoma of the biliary tract. The patient underwent a surgical resection of the tumor followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Despite the aggressive treatment, the patient's prognosis remains guarded due to the advanced stage of the disease and the rarity of effective treatment options. This case highlights the importance of early detection and prompt intervention in improving outcomes for this uncommon malignancy.

Extensive peripheral retinectomy combined with posterior 360 degrees retinotomy for retinal reattachment in advanced proliferative vitreoretinopathy cases. Advanced proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) cases often require extensive surgical interventions to achieve successful retinal reattachment. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of extensive peripheral retinectomy combined with posterior 360 degrees retinotomy in such cases. A total of 25 eyes with advanced PVR underwent this surgical technique. Anatomical success was achieved in 88% of eyes, with a mean follow-up of 18 months. Visual acuity improved in 56% of eyes, while 24% remained stable and 20% had a worsening of visual acuity. This surgical approach appears to be a viable option in the management of advanced PVR, leading to favorable anatomical outcomes and potential visual improvement.

Post-traumatic bile fistulae.  Bile leakage after liver injury has been reported to be a complication associated with significant mortality. Post-traumatic bile fistulae following liver injury have been associated with high mortality rates. A retrospective study was conducted to analyze the outcomes and management strategies for this complication. Analysis of medical records from 56 patients with post-traumatic bile fistulae revealed a mortality rate of 35.7%. The median time for fistula closure was 14 days, with the majority of cases (87.5%) closing spontaneously. Non-operative management, including enteral nutrition and biliary decompression, was successful in 71.4% of cases. Surgical intervention was required in 17.9% of cases, and endoscopic treatment was successful in 10.7% of cases. Complications such as sepsis and liver abscess occurred in 25% of patients. In conclusion, post-traumatic bile fistulae are associated with a significant risk of mortality, and a multidisciplinary approach including non-operative and operative interventions should be considered for optimal management.

Absence of acetylcholine-induced current in epithelial cells from thymus glands and thymomas of myasthenia gravis patients. In this study, we investigated the presence of acetylcholine-induced current in epithelial cells from thymus glands and thymomas of patients with myasthenia gravis (MG). Patch-clamp recordings were performed on freshly isolated thymic epithelial cells obtained from 10 MG patients and 10 control subjects. Our results showed a complete absence of acetylcholine-induced current in all thymic epithelial cells from MG patients, while robust currents were observed in control subjects. Additionally, no significant differences were observed between thymic epithelial cells obtained from thymomas and those obtained from thymus glands of MG patients. These findings suggest a dysfunction in the acetylcholine receptor signaling pathway specifically within thymic epithelial cells in MG patients. The loss of acetylcholine-induced current in thymic epithelial cells may contribute to the pathogenesis of MG by impairing the maturation and selection of T cells in the thymus. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets for this specific defect in MG patients.

Feasibility of reversing benzodiazepine tolerance with flumazenil To examine whether the benzodiazepine antagonist flumazenil can reverse tolerance to benzodiazepines but without precipitating withdrawal seizures, the antiepileptic effect of flumazenil itself and its ability to reverse tolerance at a dose that would leave sufficient receptors free for the binding of benzodiazepines were investigated. This study aimed to determine if the benzodiazepine antagonist, flumazenil, could reverse tolerance to benzodiazepines without inducing withdrawal seizures. The antiepileptic effect of flumazenil itself was assessed, along with its ability to reverse tolerance at a dose that would not interfere with the binding of benzodiazepines to receptors. The results showed that flumazenil did possess antiepileptic properties and was able to reverse benzodiazepine tolerance at an appropriate dose. These findings suggest that flumazenil may represent a viable option for the reversal of benzodiazepine tolerance, providing a potential solution for individuals who have developed tolerance to these medications. Further research is necessary to fully understand the effects and implications of flumazenil in this context.

Unusual presentation of recurrent Wegener's granulomatosis. We present a case of recurrent Wegener's granulomatosis with an unusual presentation. A 45-year-old male presented with symptoms of sinusitis, nasal discharge, and bilateral nasal obstruction. Imaging studies revealed extensive sinus opacification and nasal septum perforation. The patient underwent endoscopic sinus surgery, which confirmed the diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis with granulomas and necrotizing vasculitis. He was started on immunosuppressive therapy and showed significant improvement. However, six months later, he presented with a sudden onset of bilateral lower limb weakness. Imaging studies revealed spinal cord compression due to a spinal granuloma. He underwent surgery for decompression and further immunosuppressive therapy. This case highlights the diverse and unpredictable manifestations of Wegener's granulomatosis and the importance of early recognition and aggressive management to prevent severe complications.

Upper tract tumours following cystectomy for bladder cancer. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the incidence and characteristics of upper tract tumours (UTTs) following cystectomy for bladder cancer. A total of 342 patients who underwent cystectomy between 2005 and 2015 were included in the analysis. Out of the 342 patients, 12 (3.5%) developed UTTs during the follow-up period. The median time to diagnosis of UTTs was 32 months after cystectomy. The most common histological subtype of UTTs was urothelial carcinoma (66.7%). The majority of UTTs were low-grade (58.3%) and non-invasive (75%). The overall survival rate after diagnosis of UTTs was 66.7% at 5 years. In conclusion, although the incidence of UTTs following cystectomy for bladder cancer is relatively low, long-term monitoring is necessary due to the potential aggressiveness of these tumors.

Detection by CT during arterial portography of colorectal cancer metastases to liver.  A prospective evaluation of the accuracy of real-time ultrasonography (US), computed tomography (CT), infusion hepatic angiography (IHA), and computed tomography during arterial portography (CT-AP) was performed on 65 resected liver metastases of colorectal cancers. In this study, the accuracy of real-time ultrasonography (US), computed tomography (CT), infusion hepatic angiography (IHA), and computed tomography during arterial portography (CT-AP) was prospectively evaluated for the detection of colorectal cancer metastases to the liver. Sixty-five resected liver metastases from colorectal cancers were included in the study. CT-AP showed the highest accuracy, correctly identifying 61 out of 65 metastases, followed by CT (57 out of 65), IHA (50 out of 65), and US (39 out of 65). The results suggest that CT-AP is a reliable method for detecting liver metastases in colorectal cancer patients and may be considered as a valuable tool in the diagnostic workup.

A case of cecocolic intussusception with complete invagination and intussusception of the appendix with villous adenoma. This case report presents a rare occurrence of cecocolic intussusception with complete invagination and intussusception of the appendix with villous adenoma. A 48-year-old male was admitted with sudden onset abdominal pain and vomiting. Physical examination and imaging studies revealed cecal mass and intussusception. Emergency laparotomy was performed, revealing a cecocolic intussusception with complete invagination and an intussusception of the appendix. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of villous adenoma within the appendix. Cecocolic intussusception is a rare condition in adults, and the simultaneous involvement of the appendix is even rarer. This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and surgical intervention to prevent complications, such as intestine obstruction or ischemia. Moreover, the presence of a villous adenoma within the appendix suggests the potential for malignant transformation and the need for further surveillance.

Solitary, isolated metastasis from Ewing's sarcoma to the brain: case report. Ewing's sarcoma is a rare type of bone cancer that can metastasize to various organs. We present a case of a 24-year-old male with Ewing's sarcoma who developed a solitary brain metastasis. The patient had previously undergone surgery and chemotherapy for the primary tumor in his femur. Imaging studies revealed a single brain lesion, and he underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant radiation therapy. The histopathological examination confirmed the presence of Ewing's sarcoma in the brain metastasis. The patient was subsequently started on systemic chemotherapy. This case highlights the importance of considering brain metastasis as a possibility in patients with Ewing's sarcoma and the need for multidisciplinary management.

Neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis and segmental dilatation. Neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis, and segmental dilatation are rare congenital anomalies of the gastrointestinal tract that can result in significant morbidity and mortality in newborns. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical characteristics, management, and outcomes of patients with these conditions. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 35 neonates diagnosed with small bowel atresia, stenosis, or segmental dilatation over a 10-year period. The majority of patients presented with signs of bowel obstruction shortly after birth. Surgical intervention was required in all cases, with primary resection and anastomosis being the most common procedure performed. Complications, such as sepsis and anastomotic leak, were observed in a significant proportion of patients. Despite advances in surgical techniques and neonatal care, the overall mortality rate remained high. The long-term outcomes of survivors included nutritional, developmental, and growth issues. Further research is needed to enhance our understanding of the etiology, pathogenesis, and optimal management strategies for these complex and challenging conditions.

Anterior decompression and stabilization of thoracolumbar burst fractures by the use of the Slot-Zielke device.  Between July 1983 and November 1986, 29 patients with thoracolumbar burst fractures underwent a one-stage operation consisting of anterior decompression by subtotal vertebrectomy, reduction, and stabilization with the Slot-Zielke device. This study examined the use of the Slot-Zielke device for anterior decompression and stabilization of thoracolumbar burst fractures. A total of 29 patients underwent a one-stage operation between July 1983 and November 1986. The procedure involved subtotal vertebrectomy, reduction, and stabilization using the Slot-Zielke device. The results showed successful decompression and stabilization in all cases, with no cases of implant failure or neurologic deterioration. Postoperative complications included two cases of superficial infection and one case of transient neurologic deficit. The mean follow-up period was 27 months, with 27 patients showing good to excellent functional outcomes and only 2 patients experiencing fair outcomes. This study suggests that the Slot-Zielke device is an effective option for the management of thoracolumbar burst fractures, providing satisfactory decompression and stabilization.

Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy in multiple endocrine neoplasia. Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple endocrine tumors. Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy is a potential complication of MEN, but little is known about its incidence and characteristics. In this study, we identified six patients with MEN who developed catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy. The presenting symptoms included dyspnea, palpitations, and fatigue. Echocardiography revealed left ventricular systolic dysfunction and apical ballooning consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Increased levels of catecholamines were detected in all patients. Treatment involved beta-blockers and alpha-adrenergic antagonists, with favorable outcomes observed in four patients. Our findings highlight the importance of recognizing and managing catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy in patients with MEN to prevent further complications and improve patient outcomes.

Spindle cell carcinoma of the lung. Spindle cell carcinoma (SpCC) of the lung is a rare and aggressive subtype of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). It is characterized by the presence of spindle-shaped tumor cells, which show sarcomatoid differentiation. This study aimed to investigate the clinical and pathological characteristics, as well as the prognosis, of patients with SpCC of the lung. 

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 36 patients diagnosed with SpCC of the lung at a single institution. The results showed that SpCC accounted for 2.3% of all NSCLC cases during the study period. Most patients presented with advanced stage disease, and the majority had a history of smoking. Histologically, the tumor cells exhibited marked cellular pleomorphism and frequent mitotic activity. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrated variable expression of markers associated with both epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation. 

The prognosis of patients with SpCC was poor, with a median overall survival of only 7.5 months. Multivariate analysis revealed that advanced stage, presence of distant metastases, and poor performance status were independent negative prognostic factors. In conclusion, SpCC of the lung is a rare and aggressive subtype of NSCLC, associated with a poor prognosis. Further studies are needed to improve our understanding of the molecular basis and optimal treatment strategies for this challenging disease.

All-trans retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemias.  II. This study presents the findings of a retrospective analysis of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) patients treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA). A total of 82 patients diagnosed with APL were included in the analysis. The objective was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ATRA as a primary treatment for APL. All patients received ATRA as induction therapy, followed by consolidation therapy with chemotherapy. The overall response rate was found to be 98%, with a complete remission achieved in 92% of patients. The relapse rate was low at 7%. No significant treatment-related toxicity or mortality was observed. In addition, long-term follow-up showed sustained remission in the majority of patients. These results indicate that ATRA is highly effective and safe as a primary treatment for APL, providing a high rate of complete remission and low relapse rate. As such, ATRA should be considered as a key component in the management of APL patients.

Subtle cerebellar phenotype in mice homozygous for a targeted deletion of the En-2 homeobox. Mice with a targeted deletion of the En-2 homeobox gene were characterized for their cerebellar phenotype. The homozygous mutant mice exhibited subtle cerebellar abnormalities, including a smaller size and altered foliation pattern compared to wild-type mice. However, there were no significant deficits in motor coordination or general locomotor activity observed. These findings suggest that En-2 plays a role in cerebellar development and that its absence results in structural changes in the cerebellum. The subtle cerebellar phenotype seen in these mice highlights the complex nature of cerebellar development and the importance of homeobox genes in this process.

Mechanical sutures in perforation of the thoracic esophagus as a safe procedure in patients seen late.  Between 1976 and 1988, we treated 13 perforations of the thoracic esophagus, excluding ruptured carcinoma and intraoperative wounds, by mechanical sutures without exclusion. In the period from 1976 to 1988, we successfully managed 13 cases of perforation of the thoracic esophagus using mechanical sutures without any exclusion of patients, except for cases of ruptured carcinoma and intraoperative wounds. This approach proved to be a safe procedure even in patients who presented with late-stage disease. Our findings suggest that mechanical sutures can be an effective treatment option for thoracic esophageal perforation, providing a viable alternative to more invasive surgical interventions. Further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and compare this technique with other surgical approaches.

Survey of Alabama physicians' use of mammography, 1989. To understand the practices of Alabama physicians regarding mammography, a survey was conducted in 1989. Questionnaires were sent to 1,002 physicians, of which 609 responded (response rate: 60.7%). Of the respondents, 59.7% reported regularly performing mammograms, with 89.9% recommending them for women aged 35-70 and 80% for women aged 71 or older. However, only 52.8% provided mammograms for uninsured women, and 47.5% offered them on a sliding-fee scale. The main factors indicating a higher likelihood of offering mammograms were being female, practicing in metropolitan areas, and being affiliated with hospitals. The survey findings revealed a significant need for increased accessibility and affordability of mammography services, particularly for underserved populations.

Basic studies on a new material for inducing antitumor immune cells. There is a growing interest in developing new materials that can effectively induce antitumor immune responses. In this study, we investigated the potential of a novel material for this purpose. The material was designed to activate and enhance the function of immune cells involved in antitumor responses. In vitro experiments were conducted to assess the ability of the material to stimulate the proliferation and activation of various immune cell subsets. Our results showed that the material significantly increased the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines by immune cells, indicating its potential to recruit and activate immune cells at the tumor site. Furthermore, in vivo experiments using a mouse model of tumor growth demonstrated that the material effectively suppressed tumor growth and prolonged overall survival. These findings highlight the promising role of this novel material in the development of immunotherapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. Further investigations are warranted to fully understand its mechanisms of action and optimize its efficacy.

Neoadjuvant chemotherapy in invasive bladder cancer: the evolving role of surgery. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is increasingly being used in the management of invasive bladder cancer. This abstract aims to explore the evolving role of surgery in this setting. Several clinical trials and meta-analyses have demonstrated the benefit of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in improving survival outcomes for patients with invasive bladder cancer. This includes a higher likelihood of achieving a pathologic complete response, increased overall survival rates, and a decreased risk of disease recurrence. As a result, there is a shift towards a multimodal approach with neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery, potentially enabling bladder preservation in select patients. However, further research is needed to define patient selection criteria, optimal chemotherapy regimens, and surgical techniques to maximize outcomes in this evolving landscape.

The management of atypical non-cardiac chest pain. Non-cardiac chest pain poses a diagnostic and management challenge, often leading to unnecessary cardiac evaluations. We present a case series of three patients with atypical non-cardiac chest pain managed in our outpatient clinic. Initial evaluation included thorough history-taking and physical examination to rule out cardiac causes. Diagnostic tests, including esophageal manometry, upper endoscopy, and high-resolution esophageal impedance-pH monitoring, were performed to evaluate for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and esophageal motility disorders. All patients had normal cardiac workups and were ultimately diagnosed with GERD-related chest pain. Treatment with proton pump inhibitors and lifestyle modifications resulted in significant improvement in symptoms for all patients. Our findings highlight the importance of a comprehensive evaluation for non-cardiac chest pain to avoid unnecessary cardiac interventions and ensure appropriate management.

Management of Peyronie disease by implantation of inflatable penile prosthesis. Peyronie's disease is a condition characterized by the development of fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea of the penis, resulting in penile curvature and erectile dysfunction. Various treatment options have been explored, including oral medications, intralesional injections, and surgical interventions. In recent years, the use of inflatable penile prosthesis (IPP) has gained popularity as a management strategy for Peyronie's disease. This abstract reviews the current literature on the use of IPP in the treatment of Peyronie's disease, discussing its efficacy, safety profile, and patient satisfaction rates. The advantages of IPP include the ability to correct penile curvature, restore sexual function, and provide long-term durability. Furthermore, the procedure can be combined with other surgical techniques, such as plaque incision or grafting, to optimize outcomes. However, careful patient selection and counseling are crucial to ensure realistic expectations and maximize postoperative satisfaction. Ongoing research efforts aim to further refine the indications and refine the technique of IPP implantation in Peyronie's disease.

Estrogen and coronary heart disease in women. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between estrogen levels and coronary heart disease (CHD) in women. The authors analyzed data from a cohort study and examined the association between estrogen levels and the risk of developing CHD. They found that women with higher estrogen levels had a significantly lower risk of CHD compared to women with lower estrogen levels. The protective effect of estrogen on CHD was more pronounced in premenopausal women. The authors also observed that the use of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) was associated with a reduced risk of CHD in postmenopausal women. However, they noted that the use of HRT should be carefully evaluated due to the potential risks and side effects associated with long-term use. Overall, this study suggests that estrogen may play a protective role in the development of CHD in women, especially in the premenopausal period, and that HRT may have a beneficial effect on CHD prevention in postmenopausal women.

Long term effects of gastrocystoplasty in rats.  Twenty prepubescent rats underwent microsurgical gastrocystoplasty by a technique which is described. In this study, the long-term effects of gastrocystoplasty were investigated in prepubescent rats. Twenty rats underwent microsurgical gastrocystoplasty using a described technique. Over a follow-up period, various parameters were assessed including bladder capacity, histological analysis of the bladder mucosa, and urodynamic studies. Results showed a significant increase in bladder capacity compared to preoperative values. Histological analysis revealed a thickened bladder mucosa with increased collagen deposition. Urodynamic studies showed improved bladder compliance and detrusor contractility. However, these beneficial effects were accompanied by an increased incidence of urinary tract infections. In conclusion, while gastrocystoplasty improved bladder function in rats, the long-term consequences included bladder mucosal changes and an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

Implementation of preventive services in an HMO practice. This study aimed to assess the implementation of preventive services in a Health Maintenance Organization (HMO) practice. Data from 500 patient charts were reviewed to determine the proportion of patients receiving recommended preventive services, including vaccinations, cancer screenings, and health counseling. Results showed that the implementation of preventive services varied across different services, with higher rates observed for vaccinations and cancer screenings compared to health counseling. Several barriers to implementation were identified, including lack of provider awareness and patient compliance. These findings highlight the need for targeted interventions to improve the implementation of preventive services in HMO practices, ultimately leading to better patient outcomes and health promotion.
