Understanding this age-related decline in EPO response may have implications for the treatment of anemia in older patients and the development of targeted therapies to optimize erythropoietin production. Further research is needed to explore the mechanisms underlying this age-related decline in EPO response.

Neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy in large submucous fibroids. This study investigates the use of neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy in the treatment of large submucous fibroids. Ten patients with large submucous fibroids underwent hysteroscopic laser ablation using a neodymium: YAG laser. The procedure was successful in all cases, resulting in complete fibroid removal with minimal blood loss. Post-operative complications were rare and included cramping and vaginal discharge, which resolved spontaneously. Follow-up examinations at 3, 6, and 12 months showed no evidence of fibroid recurrence or residual symptoms. Neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy appears to be a safe and effective technique for the treatment of large submucous fibroids and may offer an alternative to hysterectomy in select patients. Further studies with larger patient populations are warranted to confirm these findings.

Multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses. We present a case of multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses. A 56-year-old male with a history of chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps presented with symptoms of headache and recurrent sinus infections. Imaging studies revealed multiple intracranial mucoceles involving the frontal, ethmoid, and sphenoid sinuses. The patient underwent endoscopic sinus surgery with excision of the mucoceles and sinus debridement. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of darkly pigmented fungal elements consistent with phaeohyphomycosis. The patient was subsequently started on systemic antifungal therapy with voriconazole. Follow-up imaging showed resolution of the mucoceles and improvement in symptoms. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis. Early recognition and appropriate management are crucial in preventing complications such as intracranial extension. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal treatment strategies for this rare condition.

Phospholipids from rat, human, and canine gastric mucosa.  Composition and metabolism of molecular classes of phosphatidylcholine. This study investigated the composition and metabolism of molecular classes of phosphatidylcholine (PC) in rat, human, and canine gastric mucosa. The study analyzed the phospholipid composition and distribution of PC molecular species in each species using high-performance liquid chromatography. The results showed that PC is the primary phospholipid in the gastric mucosa of all three species, with saturated and unsaturated fatty acids being the major constituents. The fatty acid composition of PC varied between species, with differences observed in the length and saturation of the fatty acyl chains. Additionally, the study examined the enzymatic activities responsible for the synthesis and catabolism of PC. The findings indicated that the metabolic pathways of PC synthesis and degradation differ between species, highlighting the importance of understanding species-specific differences in PC metabolism. Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the composition and metabolism of PC in the gastric mucosa of rats, humans, and dogs, which may have implications for the development of therapeutic interventions targeting gastric disorders.

Sclerotherapy of varicose and telangiectatic leg veins. A retrospective study was conducted on 50 patients to evaluate the efficacy of sclerotherapy in treating varicose and telangiectatic leg veins. All patients underwent multiple sclerotherapy sessions using a foam sclerosant. Results showed significant improvement in both varicose and telangiectatic leg veins, with a mean reduction in size of 70% and 80% respectively. Moreover, 96% of patients reported a decrease in pain and discomfort associated with these conditions. Complications were minimal, with only minor side effects such as transient erythema and mild edema reported. No serious adverse events were observed. Overall, sclerotherapy proved to be a safe and effective treatment option for varicose and telangiectatic leg veins, providing substantial reduction in size and improvement in symptoms. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term outcomes.

Quality of life in elderly, chronically ill outpatients.  Quality of life (QL) in elderly outpatients is poorly characterized. The quality of life (QL) of elderly outpatients with chronic illnesses is an area that lacks adequate characterization. Our study aimed to assess QL in this population and explore potential associations with various factors. We conducted a cross-sectional survey of 200 elderly outpatients (age 閳 65 years) with chronic illnesses attending a geriatric clinic. QL was assessed using the Short Form 36 (SF-36) questionnaire. Results showed that overall QL in this population was significantly lower compared to age-matched general population norms. Physical functioning, role limitations due to physical health, and general health perception were the most affected domains. Factors associated with poorer QL included increased age, female gender, lower educational level, presence of multiple chronic illnesses, and higher number of medications. In contrast, social support, regular exercise, and adherence to medical treatment were associated with better QL. Our findings highlight the need for targeted interventions to improve QL in elderly individuals with chronic illnesses, addressing both physical and psychosocial aspects.

Comparison of structure, mechanical properties, and functions of lumbar spinal ligaments. This study aims to compare the structure, mechanical properties, and functions of lumbar spinal ligaments. The lumbar spine is essential for providing stability and allowing for controlled motion. Ligaments play a crucial role in maintaining the structural integrity and function of the lumbar spine. Using cadaveric specimens, various mechanical tests were performed to evaluate the load-bearing capacity, stiffness, and elasticity of the anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments, ligamentum flavum, interspinous ligament, and supraspinous ligament. Histological analysis was also conducted to assess the composition and organization of collagen fibers within these ligaments. Additionally, the functional aspects of each ligament, such as their contribution to spinal stability and prevention of excessive motion, were investigated. The findings revealed differences in the structure, mechanical properties, and functions of the lumbar spinal ligaments, highlighting the importance of understanding their distinct roles in spinal support. This knowledge can aid in the diagnosis and treatment of various lumbar spinal pathologies and guide surgical interventions aimed at restoring stability and function.

Management of penile gunshot wounds. This literature review aims to present the management strategies for penile gunshot wounds. Penetrating injuries to the penis can result in significant morbidity and functional impairment. A thorough understanding of the anatomy and pathophysiology is essential for successful management. Immediate evaluation of the patient's hemodynamic stability should take precedence, followed by a meticulous assessment of the injury extent and associated structures involved. Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and tetanus prophylaxis is essential. Non-operative management may be considered for stable patients with superficial wounds, while surgical exploration is necessary for cases involving deep structures. Penile reconstruction techniques including primary repair, grafts, flaps, and penile prosthesis placement can be employed based on the extent of tissue loss and associated injuries. Early postoperative physiotherapy and psychosexual counseling are crucial for optimal functional outcomes. Complications such as infection, erectile dysfunction, urethral injury, and psychological issues should be anticipated and managed accordingly. Collaborative efforts between urologists, plastic surgeons, and mental health professionals are vital to achieve successful outcomes in penile gunshot injuries.

Ocular complications of rheumatic diseases of childhood. Rheumatic diseases in childhood can lead to ocular complications, which can have significant impact on visual function and quality of life. This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence and types of ocular complications in children with rheumatic diseases. A total of 96 patients were included in the study, and ocular complications were found in 31% of the patients. The most common complication was uveitis, followed by cataract and glaucoma. Other complications included scleritis, keratitis, and retinal vasculitis. Early recognition and treatment of these ocular complications are crucial in order to prevent visual impairment and optimize long-term outcomes in children with rheumatic diseases.

The Maylard incision in gynecologic surgery The transverse muscle-splitting Maylard incision was used in 175 gynecologic patients who required pelvic-abdominal surgery. The Maylard incision is commonly used in gynecologic surgery for patients requiring pelvic-abdominal procedures. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the transverse muscle-splitting Maylard incision in 175 gynecologic patients. The incision was found to provide excellent exposure and access to the pelvic and abdominal regions. The incision technique allowed for optimal visualization and manipulation of pelvic organs, facilitating surgical procedures with minimal morbidity and complication rates. Additionally, the incision showed satisfactory cosmetic outcomes. Overall, the Maylard incision is a reliable and efficient approach for gynecologic surgeries, providing adequate access to the pelvic-abdominal cavity while minimizing postoperative complications.

Effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Diabetic gastroparesis is a condition characterized by delayed gastric emptying due to dysfunction of the stomach muscles. Motilin is a peptide hormone that has been found to stimulate gastric motility. However, the effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis remains unclear. 

In this study, the effect of motilin on gastric emptying was investigated in a group of patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Gastric emptying was assessed by measuring the time it took for a radiolabeled meal to leave the stomach. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either motilin or a placebo before the gastric emptying test. 

The results showed that motilin significantly accelerated gastric emptying compared to the placebo. The mean gastric emptying time was shorter in the motilin group compared to the placebo group. Additionally, patients in the motilin group reported a reduction in symptoms such as early satiety and bloating.

These findings suggest that motilin may be a potential treatment option for patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Further research is needed to investigate the long-term effects and safety profile of motilin in this patient population.

Isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency induced by long-term griseofulvin therapy. Griseofulvin, an antifungal medication, has been associated with various adverse effects. We present a case of a 68-year-old male who experienced isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency after long-term griseofulvin therapy. The patient was initially prescribed griseofulvin for the treatment of dermatophytosis, and after 9 months of treatment, he developed symptoms of anemia. Laboratory investigations revealed a marked decrease in erythrocyte and reticulocyte counts, along with abnormal erythroid morphology. The patient also exhibited signs of renal dysfunction, including elevated serum creatinine levels. Bone marrow examination confirmed erythroid hypoplasia without any other significant abnormalities. Griseofulvin was discontinued, and the patient was started on erythropoietin therapy and supportive care for renal insufficiency. Subsequent follow-up showed improvement in erythrocyte counts and renal function. This case highlights the potential adverse effects of long-term griseofulvin therapy, including the rare occurrence of isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency. Close monitoring of patients on griseofulvin therapy is recommended to detect and manage such complications promptly.

Doppler diagnostics, indications, and control of surgical treatment in patients with carotid pathology. Doppler diagnostics plays a crucial role in the assessment of carotid pathology and helps determine the need for surgical intervention. It provides valuable information on blood flow velocity, stenosis severity, and plaque morphology. Indications for surgical treatment include symptomatic carotid stenosis 閳50% and asymptomatic carotid stenosis 閳70%. The goal of surgery is to prevent ischemic stroke and its associated morbidity and mortality. Several surgical techniques, such as carotid endarterectomy and carotid artery stenting, are available, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. Proper control of surgical treatment is essential, and regular follow-up with Doppler ultrasound is recommended to assess patency, restenosis, and complications. Doppler diagnostics remains an essential tool in the management of carotid pathology.

The neuromuscular pathology of the Eosinophilia-Myalgia syndrome.  The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a recently reorganized disorder in patients ingesting pharmacologic doses of L-tryptophan. The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a rare disorder that has been linked to the ingestion of high doses of L-tryptophan. This report focuses on the neuromuscular pathology observed in EMS. Eosinophilia, myalgia, and neuropathy are the main clinical manifestations of this syndrome. The pathological findings include eosinophilic infiltrates in various tissues, particularly in the fascia and muscle. In addition, there is evidence of muscle fiber atrophy and regeneration, as well as perifascicular muscle fiber necrosis. The pathogenesis of EMS is still poorly understood, but it has been suggested that eosinophils and their granule proteins may play a role in the development of the neuromuscular pathology. Further research is needed to fully comprehend the underlying mechanisms of EMS and develop effective treatments for this condition.

Atonic pupil: an unusual complication of cataract surgery. Atonic pupil, a rare and unusual complication of cataract surgery, is characterized by poor or absent pupillary constriction. We present a case report of a 60-year-old male who developed an atonic pupil following routine cataract surgery. The patient presented with symptoms of blurred vision and photophobia. Examination revealed a dilated and non-reactive pupil in the affected eye. MRI of the brain and orbit showed no abnormalities. A diagnosis of atonic pupil was made, and conservative management with topical dilating agents was initiated. Over a period of several weeks, the pupil gradually regained some constriction; however, complete recovery was not achieved. Atonic pupil should be considered as a potential complication following cataract surgery, and appropriate management strategies should be implemented to mitigate visual impairment.

Lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen: MR appearance. This study aimed to evaluate the magnetic resonance (MR) appearance of the lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen. MR images of 50 patients were retrospectively reviewed. The location, size, shape, and signal intensity of the lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen were assessed. The majority of the lumbar spinal nerves appeared as hypointense structures on T1-weighted images and hyperintense structures on T2-weighted images. The size and shape of the nerves varied among individuals, but most commonly had an oval shape with a slightly larger diameter in the anteroposterior direction. Some nerves exhibited a slight upward or downward deviation within the neural foramen. These findings provide valuable information regarding the normal MR appearance of the lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen, which can aid in the diagnosis and treatment of lumbar spine disorders.

Synergistic effects of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin in reducing adhesion formation in the rabbit uterine horn model. Adhesion formation after surgery poses a significant clinical challenge. This study evaluated the synergistic effects of INTERCEED(TC7), a bioresorbable adhesion barrier, and heparin in reducing adhesion formation in a rabbit uterine horn model. Following surgical trauma, the rabbits were randomly assigned to one of four treatment groups: INTERCEED(TC7) alone, heparin alone, combination therapy, or control. The adhesion scores were assessed after 1, 2, and 4 weeks. The combination therapy group showed significantly lower adhesion scores compared to all other groups at all time points (p<0.05). The reduction in adhesion formation was most apparent after 4 weeks, with a 78% decrease compared to the control group. No adverse effects were observed with the combination therapy. These findings suggest that the combination of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin holds promise as an effective strategy to prevent postoperative adhesion formation, potentially improving patient outcomes and reducing healthcare costs. Further studies are warranted to validate these results and explore the underlying mechanisms.

Intra-abdominal "angiosarcomatosis" report of two cases after pelvic irradiation. We report two cases of intra-abdominal "angiosarcomatosis" following pelvic irradiation for gynecological malignancies. The first case involved a 55-year-old female with a history of cervical cancer treated with radical hysterectomy and pelvic radiation. She presented with abdominal pain and was found to have multiple metastatic lesions in the liver and peritoneum. The second case involved a 61-year-old female with endometrial cancer treated with total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and adjuvant radiation therapy. She presented with ascites and multiple peritoneal nodules. Both cases showed histological features consistent with angiosarcoma, characterized by neoplastic cells forming vascular channels lined by atypical endothelial cells. This rare complication of pelvic irradiation should be considered in patients presenting with unexplained metastatic lesions or peritoneal nodules. Early recognition and prompt intervention are crucial for improved outcomes. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and treatment options for this challenging condition.

The risk for systemic vascular diseases and mortality in patients with central retinal vein occlusion.  In this cross-sectional study, the authors evaluated 197 patients diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) at the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute between 1980 and 1985 to determine the risk of systemic disease and mortality. This cross-sectional study aimed to assess the risk of systemic vascular diseases and mortality in patients diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). A total of 197 patients diagnosed with CRVO between 1980 and 1985 at the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute were included in the analysis. The authors found that 75% of the patients had at least one systemic vascular disease, with hypertension being the most prevalent (67%). The mortality rate was higher in patients with CRVO compared to the general population, with a standardized mortality ratio of 1.79. These findings suggest a potential association between CRVO and systemic vascular diseases, highlighting the need for further research and targeted interventions to improve patient outcomes.

Mucocele of the cystic duct remnant in eight liver transplant recipients: findings at cholangiography, CT, and US.  The case histories and radiologic studies of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant were retrospectively evaluated. This study retrospectively evaluated the case histories and radiologic findings of eight liver transplant recipients who developed mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant. Cholangiography, CT, and US were used to assess the condition. All eight patients presented with symptoms related to biliary obstruction, such as abdominal pain and cholestasis. Cholangiography demonstrated cystic dilatation of the allograft cystic duct remnant in all cases, with complete obstruction observed in two cases. CT and US showed a cystic mass in the biliary tree, with some cases showing enhancement of the wall or septations. Surgical management was performed in all cases, including cystic duct remnant excision and hepaticojejunostomy. This study highlights the importance of imaging modalities in diagnosing and managing mucocele of the cystic duct remnant in liver transplant recipients.

'Cystic papilloma' in humans? Demonstration of human papillomavirus in plantar epidermoid cysts. Plantar epidermoid cysts are commonly seen in podiatry and dermatology clinics. While they are typically benign and do not require treatment, there is limited knowledge regarding their etiology. This case study aimed to investigate the presence of human papillomavirus (HPV) in plantar epidermoid cysts. A total of 10 patients with plantar epidermoid cysts were included in the study. Histological analysis revealed characteristic features of epidermoid cysts, and immunohistochemical staining confirmed the presence of HPV. HPV types 2, 3, and 4 were identified in the cysts. To our knowledge, this is the first report providing evidence of HPV in plantar epidermoid cysts. The presence of HPV in these cysts raises questions regarding the potential role of HPV in their pathogenesis. Further investigations are warranted to determine the significance of HPV in the development and progression of plantar epidermoid cysts.

Flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma of submandibular gland.  Correlation of histologic features and prognosis. The correlation between histologic features, prognosis, and flow cytometric DNA content in adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) of the submandibular gland has been investigated. A total of 38 patients diagnosed with ACC were included in the study. Flow cytometric analysis of tumor DNA content was performed, and histologic features were assessed. The patients were followed up for prognosis, including local recurrence and metastasis. The results showed that ACC with diploid DNA content had a significantly better prognosis compared to those with aneuploid DNA content (p<0.05). Histologic features such as perineural invasion and high-grade tumor histology were associated with aneuploid DNA content and poorer prognosis. Therefore, flow cytometric DNA content analysis can provide additional prognostic information for ACC of the submandibular gland, in conjunction with histologic features.

Decalcification of a choroidal osteoma. Choroidal osteoma is a rare benign tumor of the eye, typically occurring in young women. In this case report, we present a patient with choroidal osteoma who developed decreased vision due to the formation of extensive calcification within the tumor. The patient underwent decalcification of the lesion using intravitreal ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) injections. Following treatment, the patient experienced a significant improvement in visual acuity. Serial imaging confirmed the reduction in calcification within the tumor. To our knowledge, this is the first report of successful decalcification of a choroidal osteoma using intravitreal EDTA injections. This technique may offer a safe and effective treatment option for patients with calcified choroidal osteoma and associated visual impairment.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. Pelvic pain is a common complaint in clinical practice, often posing a diagnostic challenge due to its multifactorial nature. This review focuses on the anatomical and physiological factors that contribute to pelvic pain. The pelvis is a complex region with various structures that can give rise to pain, including the reproductive organs, urinary tract, and musculoskeletal system. Understanding the innervation and functional anatomy of these structures is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management. Additionally, the hormonal changes associated with menstruation and pregnancy can further contribute to pelvic pain. Clinicians should have a comprehensive knowledge of pelvic anatomy and physiology to effectively evaluate and treat patients with pelvic pain. Further research is needed to enhance our understanding of this complex condition and develop targeted therapies.

Expression and characterization of TCA3: a murine inflammatory protein.  TCA3 is a cDNA originally isolated from activated T cells. TCA3 is a murine inflammatory protein that was initially identified as a cDNA isolated from activated T cells. It is widely expressed in various tissues and has been implicated in the inflammatory response. In this study, we aimed to characterize the expression and functional properties of TCA3. Using immunostaining techniques, we found that TCA3 is abundantly expressed in inflammatory cells, such as macrophages and neutrophils, during acute inflammation. Additionally, TCA3 expression was upregulated in response to various pro-inflammatory stimuli, including lipopolysaccharide and pro-inflammatory cytokines. Furthermore, we observed that TCA3 plays a role in the regulation of inflammatory cytokine production, as its overexpression enhanced the secretion of TNF-伪 and IL-6 in vitro. Our findings highlight the potential importance of TCA3 in mediating inflammatory responses and suggest that it may serve as a potential therapeutic target for inflammatory diseases.

Risk ratios and risk differences in estimating the effect of risk factors for cardiovascular disease in the elderly. This study aimed to evaluate the use of risk ratios and risk differences in estimating the effect of risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD) in the elderly population. Using data from a large cohort of elderly individuals, the researchers assessed the association between various risk factors (such as hypertension, diabetes, smoking, and obesity) and the incidence of CVD. Both risk ratios and risk differences were calculated to quantify the effect of each risk factor on CVD risk. The results showed that while risk ratios provided information on the relative risk associated with each risk factor, risk differences gave a more comprehensive understanding of the absolute risk reduction. The study suggested that considering both risk ratios and risk differences can provide a better assessment of the impact of risk factors for CVD in the elderly, enabling clinicians to make more informed decisions regarding prevention and treatment strategies.

Cyclosporine-induced thrombotic microangiopathy resulting in renal allograft loss and its successful reuse: a report of two cases. We present two cases of cyclosporine-induced thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) resulting in renal allograft loss and subsequent successful reuse. Both patients experienced TMA development with features of renal dysfunction, hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia following renal transplantation. Prompt withdrawal of cyclosporine and initiation of plasmapheresis effectively treated TMA in both cases. The explanted kidneys displayed TMA-associated histopathological findings. After recovery, the patients underwent successful renal retransplantation. Cyclosporine toxicity should be considered in cases of TMA occurring after renal transplantation, and early detection and appropriate management, including discontinuation of the drug and plasmapheresis, may prevent graft loss and enable reutilization of the allograft. This highlights the importance of careful monitoring of immunosuppressive drugs to prevent TMA-related complications.

Laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts. Ovarian cysts are a common gynecologic condition, and laparoscopic management has become the preferred approach due to its advantages over open surgery. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts in a single center. A total of 150 patients who underwent laparoscopic cystectomy or oophorectomy for ovarian cysts were included. The mean size of the cysts was 6 cm, and most were functional cysts. The overall complication rate was 8%, with postoperative hemorrhage being the most common complication. The mean hospital stay was 1.5 days. Laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts was found to be safe and effective, with low complication rates and short hospital stays. Further studies are needed to compare the outcomes of laparoscopic and open surgery for ovarian cysts.

Facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve: an experimental study in the rabbit. In this experimental study, facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve was investigated in rabbits. The study aimed to determine the feasibility and efficacy of this approach for facial muscle reanimation. Ten rabbits were used in the study, and a surgical procedure was performed to connect the trigeminal motor nerve to the facial nerve. The results showed successful reanimation of the facial muscles in all rabbits, with restoration of facial movement and muscle activation observed. The study suggests that facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve may be a viable option for restoring facial function in cases of facial nerve damage or paralysis.

Radical resection for carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater.  One hundred four consecutive patients who underwent radical resection for ampullary cancer between 1965 and 1989 were retrospectively reviewed. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of radical resection in patients with carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater. A total of 104 consecutive patients who underwent radical resection between 1965 and 1989 were reviewed. The primary outcomes assessed were overall survival and disease-free survival rates. Secondary outcomes included surgical complications and disease recurrence. The results showed that the overall survival rate at 5 years was 60%, while the disease-free survival rate was 50%. The most common surgical complications included pancreatitis and bile leakage. Disease recurrence occurred in 40% of the patients, with the liver being the most frequent site. In conclusion, radical resection for carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater was associated with favorable overall survival and disease-free survival rates. However, a high risk of disease recurrence and surgical complications should be taken into consideration when selecting appropriate treatment strategies for these patients.

Lateral medullary infarction: prognosis in an unselected series.  We describe the acute and long-term prognosis in 43 patients with lateral medullary infarction (LMI) collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. This study aimed to investigate the prognosis of lateral medullary infarction (LMI) in an unselected series of patients. A total of 43 patients with LMI were included in the study, and data was collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. The acute and long-term prognosis of these patients was described. The results showed that LMI had a varied prognosis, with some patients experiencing significant neurological deficits while others had a more favorable outcome. Factors such as age, sex, and the presence of comorbidities were found to be associated with the prognosis of LMI. This study provides important insights into the prognosis of LMI and highlights the need for individualized management and treatment strategies for patients with this condition.

Carcinoma of female urethra.  Manitoba experience: 1958-1987. This retrospective study examines the clinical characteristics and treatment outcomes of female urethral carcinoma in Manitoba between 1958 and 1987. A total of 21 cases were identified, with a mean age at diagnosis of 66.8 years. Squamous cell carcinoma was the most common histological subtype (76.2%), followed by transitional cell carcinoma (23.8%). The majority of patients presented with symptoms such as hematuria, dysuria, and urinary obstruction. Initial treatment consisted of surgery in 90.5% of cases, with local excision being the most common procedure. Adjuvant radiotherapy was administered in 57.1% of cases. The median overall survival was 49 months, with 5-year and 10-year survival rates of 35.7% and 23.8%, respectively. Poorly differentiated histology and advanced stage at diagnosis were associated with worse prognosis. This study provides valuable insights into the clinical characteristics and treatment outcomes of female urethral carcinoma in Manitoba during a specific time period.

Rehabilitation in brain disorders.  4. In this review article, the authors discuss the rehabilitation strategies in brain disorders. The article focuses on four specific brain disorders: stroke, traumatic brain injury (TBI), Parkinson's disease (PD), and multiple sclerosis (MS). The authors highlight the importance of rehabilitation in improving functional outcomes and quality of life in these patients. They describe various rehabilitation approaches, including physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, and cognitive rehabilitation. The article also discusses the role of multidisciplinary teams in providing comprehensive care to patients with brain disorders. The authors emphasize the need for individualized rehabilitation programs tailored to each patient's specific needs and goals. They further discuss the evidence supporting the effectiveness of rehabilitation interventions in each of the mentioned brain disorders. The article concludes by highlighting the importance of ongoing research in the field of rehabilitation to further improve outcomes for individuals with brain disorders.

DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors. We investigated the DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors to better understand their biology and potential prognostic implications. Twenty-eight patients (mean age 56.5 years) with histologically confirmed rectal carcinoid tumors were included in the study. DNA content was analyzed by flow cytometry and categorized into diploid or aneuploid patterns. The majority of the tumors (75%) displayed aneuploidy, while the remaining 25% were diploid. Patients with aneuploid tumors had a significantly higher tumor size and incidence of lymph node metastasis compared to those with diploid tumors. Our findings suggest that DNA ploidy pattern may serve as a useful prognostic marker in rectal carcinoid tumors. Further studies are needed to confirm these results and explore potential therapeutic implications.

Sensitivity and specificity of various morphological features of cervical condylomas. Cervical condylomas are common sexually transmitted infections caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. The identification of these lesions is crucial for early detection and treatment. This study aimed to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of various morphological features in diagnosing cervical condylomas. A total of 100 patients with suspected condylomas were included in the study. Each patient underwent colposcopy and histopathological examination. The morphological features assessed included color, surface texture, border, size, and presence of atypical cells. The results showed that the sensitivity of color, surface texture, border, size, and presence of atypical cells in diagnosing cervical condylomas were 78%, 84%, 72%, 60%, and 92%, respectively. The specificity was 92%, 76%, 84%, 88%, and 60% for the same features, respectively. In conclusion, the presence of atypical cells showed the highest sensitivity and specificity, suggesting that it is a reliable morphological feature for diagnosing cervical condylomas.

Nursing home patients transferred by ambulance to a VA emergency department.  Nursing home residents are frequently transferred to hospital emergency departments. The transfer of nursing home patients to hospital emergency departments, particularly those who are residents of nursing homes, is a frequent occurrence. This study aimed to evaluate the characteristics and outcomes of nursing home patients transferred by ambulance to a VA emergency department. 

The study included a retrospective analysis of electronic medical records of nursing home patients who were transferred to the VA emergency department via ambulance over a one-year period. Demographic data, clinical characteristics, reasons for transfer, and outcomes were analyzed. 

A total of 150 nursing home patients were included in the study. Most patients were elderly (mean age 80 years) and had multiple comorbidities. The major reasons for transfer included acute changes in mental status, falls, and suspected infections. 

The study found that the majority of transfers were deemed appropriate based on emergency department evaluation. However, a significant number of patients were hospitalized or admitted to a nursing home for further care. 

In conclusion, nursing home residents frequently require transfer to hospital emergency departments, often due to acute changes in their health status. Understanding the characteristics and outcomes of these transfers can help improve the care and management of nursing home patients in emergency settings.

Association of disease-free survival and percent of ideal dose in adjuvant breast chemotherapy. This study aimed to assess the association between disease-free survival (DFS) and the percent of ideal dose received in adjuvant breast chemotherapy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 150 breast cancer patients who received adjuvant chemotherapy. The percent of ideal dose received was calculated by dividing the actual dose received by the recommended dose for each patient. Kaplan-Meier analysis and Cox proportional hazards regression models were used to evaluate the relationship between DFS and the percent of ideal dose. Results showed that patients who received a higher percent of ideal dose had significantly longer DFS compared to those who received a lower percent of ideal dose (p < 0.001). After adjusting for age, stage, hormone receptor status, and chemotherapy regimen, the association remained significant (p = 0.02). This study suggests that adherence to the recommended dose of adjuvant breast chemotherapy may improve DFS outcomes for breast cancer patients.

Coronary collateral recruitment: functional significance and relation to rate of vessel closure.  Studies in animals and humans have demonstrated the anatomic presence and functional significance of coronary collaterals. Coronary collaterals are present in both animals and humans and have been shown to have functional significance. They play a role in maintaining blood flow to the heart when there is obstruction in a coronary artery. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between coronary collateral recruitment and the rate of vessel closure. The study included animal and human subjects and measured collateral flow index (CFI) using pressure-derived indexes and angiographic parameters. The results showed a positive correlation between CFI and the rate of vessel closure. The findings suggest that the presence and recruitment of coronary collaterals may have a protective effect against vessel closure in patients with coronary artery disease. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and potential clinical implications of coronary collateral recruitment.

Metastatic small cell tumor of bone with 'true' rosettes and glial fibrillary acidic protein positivity. Metastatic small cell tumor of bone is a rare and aggressive neoplasm with limited studies available. Here, we present a case of a metastatic small cell tumor of bone demonstrating unique histological features. The tumor exhibited 'true' rosettes, a finding rarely observed in bone tumors. Additionally, immunohistochemical staining revealed glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positivity in the tumor cells, suggesting a potential glial origin. However, further investigations are required to confirm this association. Metastatic small cell tumor of bone typically originates from pulmonary or extrapulmonary sites, and its diagnosis is challenging due to its resemblance to other small cell tumors. Knowledge of these distinctive histological features, including 'true' rosettes and GFAP positivity, expands our understanding of this tumor and may aid in accurate diagnosis and tailored treatment strategies. Further research is warranted to explore the underlying molecular mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets in this rare entity.

Extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm associated with a tortuous portal vein. Extrahepatic portal vein aneurysms (PVA) are extremely rare entities and are often associated with portal hypertension and liver cirrhosis. We present a case of a 62-year-old male with a tortuous portal vein and an incidental finding of an extrahepatic PVA. He presented with nonspecific abdominal discomfort and was found to have a dilated portal vein on imaging studies. Magnetic resonance angiography was performed, confirming the presence of a PVA measuring 2 cm in diameter. The patient was asymptomatic, and management included close observation with serial imaging. Extrahepatic PVA is a rare condition and can be an incidental finding in patients with portal hypertension or liver cirrhosis. Timely diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent potential complications such as rupture or thrombosis. Further research is needed to understand the etiology, natural history, and optimal management of this rare condition.

Pancreaticobiliary ductal union. Pancreaticobiliary ductal union refers to the anatomical connection between the pancreatic and bile ducts. The classification of this union plays a crucial role in understanding the development of various pancreaticobiliary diseases, such as pancreaticobiliary maljunction and choledochal cysts. In this study, we examined the different types of pancreaticobiliary ductal unions and their clinical implications. A total of 100 patients who underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography were included in the analysis. The types of pancreaticobiliary ductal unions were classified based on the arrangement of the bile and pancreatic ducts. The prevalence of each type was determined, and the associations with clinical characteristics and diseases were examined. Our findings reveal a high variability in the types of pancreaticobiliary ductal unions, and some types were significantly associated with an increased risk of pancreaticobiliary diseases. This study provides important insights into the classification and clinical implications of pancreaticobiliary ductal union, aiding in the diagnosis and management of pancreaticobiliary diseases.

Benign missense variations in the cystic fibrosis gene. Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. The majority of CF-causing mutations result in loss of function of the CFTR protein. However, there are also benign missense variations in the CFTR gene, which do not lead to CF. These variations have been found through genetic testing and are important to consider in the diagnosis of CF. Understanding the functional consequences of these missense variations is crucial to differentiate between disease-causing mutations and benign variants. Research has shown that some benign missense variations can still affect CFTR function to some extent, but not enough to cause CF. Further investigation is needed to fully understand the implications of these variations and their role in CF pathogenesis.

Polyglucosan body disease.  Adult polyglucosan disease has been described in 15 cases. Adult polyglucosan disease is a rare condition characterized by the accumulation of abnormal glycogen-like molecules in various tissues. This study presents 15 cases of polyglucosan body disease in adults. The most common presenting symptom was progressive lower limb weakness, followed by urinary symptoms and sensory disturbances. Neurological examination revealed spastic paraparesis in all cases, with varying degrees of sensory impairment. Muscle biopsy confirmed the presence of intracellular polyglucosan bodies. Genetic testing revealed mutations in the glycogen branching enzyme gene (GBE1) in all cases. Treatment options are limited, with supportive care being the mainstay. This study highlights the clinical and genetic features of polyglucosan body disease in adults, aiding in early diagnosis and management of this rare condition.

Susceptibility to invasive Haemophilus influenzae type b disease and the immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotype. Invasive Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) disease poses a significant threat to individuals with impaired immune responses. We investigated the association between susceptibility to Hib disease and the immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotype. Utilizing a case-control design, we studied 67 patients with invasive Hib disease and 82 healthy controls. Results showed a significantly higher prevalence of the G2m(n−) allotype among Hib disease cases compared to controls (p < 0.001). Furthermore, individuals with the G2m(n−) allotype had a significantly increased risk of developing invasive Hib disease (odds ratio = 4.25, 95% confidence interval: 1.99–9.09, p < 0.001). These findings suggest that the G2m(n−) allotype is associated with susceptibility to invasive Hib disease and may serve as a potential biomarker to identify individuals at higher risk for this life-threatening condition.

Effects of prostaglandin E1 on collagen diseases with high levels of circulating immune complexes. This study examines the effects of prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) on collagen diseases characterized by high levels of circulating immune complexes. A total of 30 patients with collagen diseases and high levels of immune complexes were included in the study. They were divided into two groups: one group received intravenous PGE1 therapy in addition to conventional treatment, and the other group received only conventional treatment. The results showed that the group treated with PGE1 had a significant reduction in circulating immune complexes compared to the control group. Additionally, the PGE1-treated group showed improvement in clinical symptoms and laboratory parameters including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein levels. These findings suggest that PGE1 may be a promising therapeutic option for collagen diseases characterized by high levels of immune complexes.

Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis.  Six patients with evidence of secondary syphilis presented with visual loss in both eyes caused by large, placoid, yellowish lesions with faded centers at the level of the pigment epithelium in the macula and juxtapapillary areas. Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis, a rare manifestation of secondary syphilis, is characterized by visual loss in both eyes due to large, yellowish lesions with faded centers at the level of the macular and juxtapapillary pigment epithelium. In this case series, six patients with evidence of secondary syphilis were identified. Ocular examination revealed the characteristic placoid lesions, which were confirmed by fluorescein angiography and optical coherence tomography. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with intravenous penicillin resulted in visual improvement in all patients. Awareness of this atypical presentation is crucial for early diagnosis and appropriate management of patients with syphilis, as delay in treatment can lead to irreversible visual impairment. Further studies are needed to better understand the underlying pathophysiology and optimal treatment approach for this rare ocular manifestation of syphilis.

Extrapyramidal features in advanced Down's syndrome: clinical evaluation and family history.  Extrapyramidal, frontal release, and other neurological signs were studied in 54 demented and non-demented patients with Down's syndrome (DS). This study aimed to evaluate extrapyramidal features, frontal release signs, and other neurological signs in 54 patients with Down's syndrome (DS) who were both demented and non-demented. The presence of these signs was assessed through clinical evaluation and examination of family history. The results showed that a high percentage of patients with DS exhibited extrapyramidal features, with 70% demonstrating bradykinesia and 61% showing rigidity. Additionally, 63% of patients showed frontal release signs, such as snout reflex and grasp reflex. Non-demented patients had a higher prevalence of these neurological signs compared to demented patients. Moreover, a positive family history of movement disorders was reported in 24% of patients. These findings suggest that extrapyramidal features are common in individuals with DS, and their presence may be influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. Further research is needed to investigate the underlying mechanisms and develop potential interventions for managing these neurological signs in DS patients.

Thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax using carbon dioxide laser. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of using a carbon dioxide laser for thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 48 patients who underwent thoracoscopic surgery using the carbon dioxide laser technique. The mean age of the patients was 32 years, with a male predominance. The success rate of the procedure, defined as absence of recurrent pneumothorax at 12 months follow-up, was 91.7%. The average operating time was 68 minutes, and the average hospital stay was 3.5 days. No major complications or mortalities were reported. Postoperative complications included subcutaneous emphysema in 8.3% of patients and persistent air leakage in 6.3% of patients. The use of carbon dioxide laser for thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax appears to be effective and safe, with a high success rate and low complication rate. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings.

Use of the metabolic tracer carbon-11-acetate for evaluation of regional myocardial perfusion.  The high first-pass myocardial extraction fraction of carbon-11-acetate suggests that its initial uptake depends on blood flow.  Accordingly, regional uptake of 11C-acetate at 4 min was compared to regional perfusion determined with nitrogen-13-ammonia in 119 segments in 15 patients with stable coronary artery disease by two methods.  A close correlation was observed between initial relative myocardial concentrations (segmental activity normalized to maximal activity) of both tracers (11C-acetate = 0. 88; 13N-ammonia + 0. The use of carbon-11-acetate as a metabolic tracer for evaluating regional myocardial perfusion shows promise. This study compared the uptake of carbon-11-acetate to regional perfusion determined with nitrogen-13-ammonia in patients with stable coronary artery disease. A strong correlation was observed between the initial relative myocardial concentrations of both tracers. The high first-pass extraction fraction of carbon-11-acetate suggests that its uptake is dependent on blood flow. These findings suggest that carbon-11-acetate could be a valuable tool for assessing myocardial perfusion noninvasively. Further research is needed to validate these results and explore the potential clinical applications of carbon-11-acetate in the evaluation of coronary artery disease.

Prehospital care: the future of emergency medical services. The aim of this article is to discuss the importance of prehospital care in the future of emergency medical services (EMS). Prehospital care plays a crucial role in saving lives and improving patient outcomes. This includes the management of acute medical conditions, trauma, and time-sensitive emergencies. With advancements in technology, the future of EMS will likely involve the use of telemedicine, mobile apps, and remote monitoring devices to enhance efficiency and accuracy of prehospital care. Additionally, the integration of EMS with other healthcare systems and the implementation of community paramedicine programs will further enhance patient care and reduce healthcare costs. It is essential for EMS providers, policymakers, and healthcare organizations to recognize the significance of prehospital care and invest in its development to ensure prompt and effective emergency medical support.

Colposcopic survey of Papanicolaou test-negative cases with hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis. This study aimed to evaluate the colposcopic findings of Papanicolaou (Pap) test-negative cases showing hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis. Colposcopy was performed on 65 patients with either hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis identified in their Pap tests. Abnormal colposcopic findings were observed in 34 cases (52.3%), including acetowhite epithelium (28.3%), punctation or mosaicism (20.0%), and atypical vascular changes (13.3%). Among the cases with abnormal colposcopy, 11 (32.4%) were diagnosed with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) grade 1 or 2, while the remaining cases were diagnosed with non-neoplastic changes. Colposcopy was found to be beneficial in detecting underlying cervical abnormalities in Pap test-negative cases with hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis.

Fluorosilicone oil in the treatment of retinal detachment. Retinal detachment is a serious condition that can lead to permanent vision loss if not treated promptly. The use of fluorosilicone oil has emerged as an effective treatment option for this condition. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications associated with the use of fluorosilicone oil in the management of retinal detachment. A total of 45 patients with retinal detachment were included in the study, and all underwent vitrectomy with the injection of fluorosilicone oil as a tamponade. The primary outcome measures were anatomical success and visual acuity improvements. The results showed that fluorosilicone oil achieved a high anatomical success rate, with 86.7% of patients achieving retinal reattachment. Moreover, visual acuity improved in 62.2% of patients. Complications such as cataract formation and glaucoma were observed in a small percentage of patients. In conclusion, fluorosilicone oil is a safe and effective treatment option for retinal detachment, providing favorable outcomes in terms of retinal reattachment and visual acuity improvement. Further studies are warranted to assess long-term outcomes and compare it with other tamponade agents.

Human immunodeficiency virus-induced immunosuppression: a risk factor for human papillomavirus infection.  In a group of 92 women with genital condylomata, 15 (16. In this study of 92 women with genital condylomata, we investigated the association between human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-induced immunosuppression and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. We found that 16.3% of the women were HIV-positive, and among them, the prevalence of HPV infection was significantly higher compared to HIV-negative women (80% vs. 52.4%). Moreover, the HIV-positive women had a higher rate of multiple HPV infections (73.3% vs. 42.1%). We also observed a higher frequency of high-risk HPV types in the HIV-positive group (60% vs. 28.6%). These results indicate that HIV-induced immunosuppression is a risk factor for HPV infection and is associated with a higher burden of multiple and high-risk HPV types. Therefore, HIV-positive women should be closely monitored and provided with appropriate HPV screening and preventive interventions.

Kinin/prostaglandin system: its therapeutic value in surgical stress. The kinin/prostaglandin system has been shown to play a crucial role in the pathophysiology of surgical stress. This study aimed to evaluate the therapeutic value of targeting this system in reducing surgical stress-related complications. Male Wistar rats were subjected to a laparotomy procedure under general anesthesia. Half of the animals received a pharmacological intervention targeting the kinin/prostaglandin system, while the other half served as controls. Parameters such as tissue edema, oxidative stress markers, and inflammatory cytokines were assessed. Additionally, postoperative complications, including wound healing, infection, and organ dysfunction, were monitored. The results demonstrated significant reductions in tissue edema, oxidative stress, and inflammatory cytokine levels in the intervention group. Furthermore, the incidence of postoperative complications was significantly lower in the intervention group compared to controls. These findings suggest that modulation of the kinin/prostaglandin system may have therapeutic potential in mitigating surgical stress and improving postoperative outcomes. Further research is warranted to investigate the underlying mechanisms and optimal therapeutic strategies.

Buerger's colour.  Cyanosis of the hands and feet in Buerger's disease is known as 'Buerger's colour'. Buerger's disease is a condition characterized by inflammation and clotting of small and medium-sized arteries and veins, primarily affecting the hands and feet. Cyanosis, a bluish discoloration of the skin due to inadequate oxygenation, is a common symptom of this disease. In Buerger's disease, cyanosis specifically observed in the hands and feet is referred to as 'Buerger's colour'. This distinct discoloration is caused by the compromised blood flow to these extremities due to arterial occlusion. The presence of Buerger's colour serves as an important clinical indicator for diagnosing and monitoring the progression of Buerger's disease. Recognizing this color change is crucial for healthcare professionals in identifying and managing patients with this condition.

Computed tomography-guided fine-needle aspiration of retroperitoneal lymph nodes in gynecologic oncology. Computed tomography-guided fine-needle aspiration (CT-FNA) has become an established diagnostic tool in various medical specialties. However, its role in gynecologic oncology, specifically in the evaluation of retroperitoneal lymph nodes, remains unclear. This study aimed to assess the accuracy and clinical impact of CT-FNA in gynecologic oncology patients with suspected retroperitoneal lymph node involvement.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent CT-FNA of retroperitoneal lymph nodes between January 20XX and December 20XX. Demographic and clinical data, imaging characteristics, cytology results, and subsequent management decisions were reviewed.

A total of XX patients were included in the analysis. CT-FNA demonstrated an overall sensitivity of XX% and specificity of XX% in diagnosing lymph node metastasis. The negative predictive value was XX%, suggesting its utility in ruling out metastatic involvement in some cases. CT-FNA influenced management decisions in XX% of patients, either guiding treatment plans or avoiding unnecessary surgery.

CT-FNA of retroperitoneal lymph nodes in gynecologic oncology patients is a valuable diagnostic tool, providing accurate information for decision-making and potentially avoiding invasive procedures. Further evaluation is warranted to determine its optimal role in the management of these patients.

Causes of death in hospitalized intravenous drug abusers.  The authors reviewed at autopsy the causes of death of 274 patients with evidence of intravenous drug abuse who had been admitted to a large public hospital. The autopsy findings of 274 intravenous drug abusers admitted to a large public hospital were reviewed to determine the causes of death. The most common causes of death were infectious diseases (52.3%), with bacterial endocarditis being the most frequent. Noninfectious causes accounted for 17.2% of deaths, including overdose and trauma. Heart-related diseases (including myocardial infarction and cardiomyopathy) were responsible for 11.7% of deaths, while respiratory diseases accounted for 8.4%. Other causes included liver disease, renal failure, and central nervous system infections. Polydrug use was common, with 76.6% of deaths involving more than one drug category. This study highlights the importance of infectious diseases, particularly bacterial endocarditis, in the mortality of intravenous drug abusers.

Occult vascular malformations of the optic chiasm: magnetic resonance imaging diagnosis and surgical laser resection.  Angiographically occult vascular malformations of the optic nerve and chiasm are extremely rare. The diagnosis and surgical treatment of angiographically occult vascular malformations of the optic nerve and chiasm are discussed in this study. These malformations are extremely rare. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was used to accurately diagnose and characterize the vascular abnormalities. Surgical laser resection was performed to treat the malformations. The study reports two cases of occult vascular malformations, one in the optic nerve and one in the optic chiasm. MRI helped identify the location and extent of the malformations, allowing for precise surgical planning. Surgical laser resection successfully removed the malformations, resulting in improved visual function in both cases. The study highlights the importance of MRI in the diagnosis and surgical management of angiographically occult vascular malformations of the optic nerve and chiasm, providing valuable insights for future cases.

Cone cerclage in pregnancy.  We report a technique of cone cerclage and the results and outcome in 17 patients who required a diagnostic cone biopsy in pregnancy. This study aims to report on the technique and outcomes of cone cerclage in pregnant patients who required a diagnostic cone biopsy. A total of 17 patients were included in the study. The cone cerclage procedure was performed to prevent cervical incompetence and subsequent preterm delivery. The technique involved the insertion of a non-absorbable suture around the cervical canal to reinforce its integrity. The results showed that all 17 patients successfully underwent the cone cerclage procedure without any complications. Postoperative evaluation revealed no signs of cervical insufficiency or preterm labor. The outcomes of pregnancy were also favorable, with all patients carrying their pregnancies to full term without any adverse events. These findings suggest that cone cerclage is an effective technique for preserving cervical integrity in pregnant patients requiring diagnostic cone biopsies, ultimately leading to positive pregnancy outcomes.

Regression of the left main trunk lesion by steroid administration in Takayasu's aortitis. We present a case of a 42-year-old woman with a diagnosis of Takayasu's aortitis, presenting with symptoms of ischemic heart disease and visual disturbances due to stenosis of the left main trunk. A high-dose steroid therapy was initiated resulting in substantial regression of the lesion. Follow-up imaging demonstrated a significant improvement in the stenosis, with near-complete resolution of the left main trunk lesion. The patient's symptoms also improved significantly. This case highlights the potential of steroid therapy in inducing regression of stenotic lesions in Takayasu's aortitis and emphasizes the importance of considering this treatment option in patients with symptomatic disease. Further studies are warranted to better understand the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon.

Successful control of bleeding from gastric antral vascular ectasia (watermelon stomach) by laser photocoagulation. Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE), also known as watermelon stomach, is a rare cause of gastrointestinal bleeding. We report a case of successful management of bleeding from GAVE using laser photocoagulation. A 63-year-old female presented with recurrent episodes of melena and anemia. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed characteristic linear red streaks in the antrum, confirming the diagnosis of GAVE. Laser photocoagulation was performed to cauterize the abnormal blood vessels. The patient had no further episodes of bleeding and her hemoglobin levels remained stable at follow-up. Laser photocoagulation appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for controlling bleeding in patients with GAVE. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare the efficacy of different therapeutic approaches.

Fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery following radical surgery of childhood craniopharyngiomas. Radical surgery for childhood craniopharyngiomas has been associated with the development of fusiform dilatations in the carotid arteries. These dilatations pose a significant risk for future complications such as thrombosis or aneurysm formation. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical significance of carotid artery dilatations after radical surgery in childhood craniopharyngiomas. A retrospective analysis was performed on 78 patients who underwent radical surgery for craniopharyngiomas during childhood. Imaging studies revealed carotid artery dilatations in 41% of the patients. The average time between surgery and detection of the dilatations was 4.6 years. Patients with dilatations had a significantly higher incidence of transient ischemic attacks and visual impairments compared to those without dilatations. Consequently, routine postoperative surveillance imaging and close follow-up are recommended for early detection and intervention to prevent potential complications associated with these fusiform dilatations.

Endoscopic treatment of biliary tract strictures in sclerosing cholangitis: a larger series and recommendations for treatment. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of endoscopic treatment for biliary tract strictures in patients with sclerosing cholangitis. A larger series of 80 patients with sclerosing cholangitis and biliary tract strictures underwent endoscopic treatment. Successful stent placement and resolution of strictures were achieved in 78. 8% of cases. The average time to stricture resolution was 7. 2 months. Stent migration and recurrent strictures were the main complications observed. Based on the results, the authors recommend endoscopic treatment as an effective approach for managing biliary tract strictures in patients with sclerosing cholangitis.

IgG and IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q in rheumatoid vasculitis. Rheumatoid vasculitis (RV) is a rare and severe complication of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) characterized by inflammation and damage to blood vessels. The pathogenesis of RV is not fully understood, but immune complexes, including those containing C1q, have been implicated. In this study, we investigated the presence of IgG and IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q in RV patients. Serum samples from 25 RV patients and 25 RA controls were analyzed using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Significantly higher levels of IgG and IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q were found in RV patients compared to RA controls (p<0.05). Additionally, the presence of these antibodies correlated with disease severity and clinical manifestations. These findings suggest that IgG and IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q may play a role in the pathogenesis of RV and could serve as potential biomarkers for disease activity and severity. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and explore their clinical implications.

Ventricular responses to mental stress testing in patients with coronary artery disease. This study aimed to investigate the ventricular responses to mental stress testing in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD). A total of 50 patients with CAD and 50 healthy controls underwent mental stress testing, during which their ventricular responses were assessed using echocardiography. The results showed that patients with CAD had significantly higher ventricular responses to mental stress compared to the healthy controls. Specifically, they exhibited increased left ventricular end-systolic volume and reduced left ventricular ejection fraction during mental stress. These findings suggest that mental stress can have negative effects on ventricular function in patients with CAD. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop interventions to mitigate the adverse ventricular responses to mental stress in this population.

Immunoglobulins A, G, and M to cytomegalovirus during recurrent infection in recipients of allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a common complication in recipients of allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT). This study aimed to evaluate the levels of immunoglobulins A, G, and M to CMV during recurrent infection in BMT recipients. A total of 45 BMT recipients who developed recurrent CMV infection were included in the study. Serum samples were collected at the time of recurrent infection and tested for CMV-specific immunoglobulins A, G, and M using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). The results showed that the levels of immunoglobulins A and G to CMV were significantly higher during recurrent infection compared to baseline levels. However, there was no significant difference in the levels of immunoglobulin M to CMV between recurrent infection and baseline. These findings suggest that the humoral immune response to CMV is enhanced during recurrent infection in BMT recipients, particularly for immunoglobulins A and G. Further studies are warranted to investigate the clinical implications of these findings.

Efficacy of doxazosin in specific hypertensive patient groups. The efficacy of doxazosin, an alpha-1 adrenergic antagonist, in specific hypertensive patient groups was evaluated. A randomised controlled trial was conducted among 150 patients with hypertension, divided into four groups: obese patients, elderly patients, patients with diabetes, and patients with renal impairment. Participants were assigned to receive either doxazosin or placebo for a duration of 12 weeks. The results showed a significant reduction in blood pressure in all patient groups treated with doxazosin compared to placebo. However, the magnitude of the blood pressure reduction varied among the different patient groups. Obese patients and elderly patients achieved the greatest reduction in blood pressure, followed by patients with diabetes and patients with renal impairment. These findings suggest that doxazosin may be particularly effective in controlling hypertension in obese and elderly patients, while still providing benefits in patients with diabetes and renal impairment. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings and determine optimal dosages for these specific patient groups.

Traumatic and spontaneous extracranial internal carotid artery dissections. Internal carotid artery dissections (ICAD) can occur as a result of trauma or spontaneously. We conducted a retrospective study to compare the clinical characteristics and outcomes of traumatic and spontaneous ICAD. We analyzed the medical records of patients diagnosed with ICAD between 2000 and 2019. A total of 65 patients were included, with 32 (49.2%) having traumatic ICAD and 33 (50.8%) having spontaneous ICAD. The mean age was higher in the spontaneous ICAD group (56.5 years) compared to the traumatic group (42.9 years). Spontaneous ICAD patients had a higher incidence of cardiovascular risk factors, such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The traumatic ICAD group had a higher proportion of patients with a history of recent neck trauma. There was no significant difference in the rate of ischemic stroke or mortality between the two groups. In conclusion, traumatic and spontaneous ICAD have distinct clinical characteristics, with spontaneous cases being associated with older age and more cardiovascular risk factors. However, the rate of ischemic stroke and mortality did not differ significantly between the two groups.

Partial laryngectomy after irradiation failure.  Forty-three patients who had partial laryngectomies after radiotherapy were evaluated. The authors conducted a retrospective study to evaluate the outcomes of partial laryngectomy in 43 patients who underwent the procedure following failed irradiation therapy. The majority of patients had advanced-stage laryngeal cancer. The study found that partial laryngectomy was successful in achieving local control in 75% of cases, with disease-free survival rates at 1, 2, and 5 years standing at 55%, 48%, and 27% respectively. The majority of complications observed were related to surgical wound healing and functional impairments. Voice outcomes were generally satisfactory, with 65% of patients achieving intelligible speech. Feeding tube dependence was noted in 19% of patients, while tracheotomy dependence was observed in 14%. The authors concluded that partial laryngectomy can be a viable salvage option for patients with failed irradiation, offering decent oncologic outcomes and functional rehabilitation. However, the potential for complications should be carefully considered in the treatment plan.

Magnetic resonance imaging of experimental rat brain tumors: histopathological evaluation. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a non-invasive imaging modality commonly used in the diagnosis and monitoring of brain tumors. However, the correlation between MRI findings and histopathological characteristics of brain tumors in experimental animal models remains unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the histopathological features of rat brain tumors as identified by MRI. Rats were implanted with glioma cells and underwent serial MRI scans. Subsequently, the tumors were excised and subjected to histopathological examination. The results showed that MRI accurately depicted the presence, location, and size of the brain tumors. Furthermore, MRI findings, such as tumor edge irregularity and necrosis, correlated well with histopathological characteristics. However, MRI had limitations in precisely determining tumor composition, such as the degree of infiltration or the presence of microvascular proliferation. These findings highlight the potential of MRI in preclinical research but emphasize the importance of histopathological evaluation for a comprehensive understanding of brain tumor characteristics.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome.  A clinical case series of 21 patients. We present a case series of 21 patients diagnosed with eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS). EMS is a rare disorder characterized by eosinophilia and myalgia, often associated with the use of L-tryptophan supplements. Common symptoms included severe muscle pain, peripheral neuropathy, skin lesions, and eosinophilia. The majority of patients had a history of L-tryptophan use prior to symptom onset. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated eosinophil counts and increased levels of creatine kinase and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Muscle and skin biopsies were performed in a subset of patients, which showed evidence of granulomatous inflammation and eosinophilic infiltrates. Treatment consisted of discontinuation of L-tryptophan supplements, corticosteroids, and symptomatic management. Most patients showed variable improvement in symptoms over time; however, some residual muscle weakness and neuropathy persisted. This case series highlights the importance of considering EMS in patients presenting with eosinophilia and myalgia, especially those with a history of L-tryptophan use. Further research is needed to elucidate the pathogenesis and optimal management of this rare disorder.

Ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia (Shwachman syndrome).  Report of a case with extensive skin lesions (clinical, histological, and ultrastructural findings). We present a case report of a patient with Shwachman syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia. The patient exhibited extensive skin lesions, which were evaluated clinically, histologically, and ultrastructurally. Clinical examination revealed generalized scaling and dryness of the skin with multiple erythematous patches. Histological analysis demonstrated hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and acanthosis. Ultrastructural examination revealed abnormal keratinocytes with disorganized tonofilaments and aberrant desmosomes. The patient also presented with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia, consistent with the diagnosis of Shwachman syndrome. This case highlights the variable manifestations of Shwachman syndrome and emphasizes the importance of considering this condition in patients with characteristic skin lesions in conjunction with other systemic features. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying pathophysiology and to develop targeted therapies for this complex disorder.

mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression: a novel genetic abnormality in mitochondrial diseases. This study aims to characterize a novel genetic abnormality in mitochondrial diseases known as mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression. The researchers conducted a retrospective analysis of patients with suspected mitochondrial disorders and identified seven individuals with mtDNA depletion in various tissues. Clinical symptoms included muscle weakness, developmental delay, and respiratory difficulties. Genetic analysis revealed mutations in genes responsible for mtDNA maintenance, including thymidine kinase 2 and deoxyguanosine kinase. Interestingly, the degree of mtDNA depletion varied among different tissues within the same individual, suggesting tissue-specific effects. Furthermore, the severity of clinical symptoms correlated with the extent of mtDNA depletion. This study expands our understanding of mitochondrial diseases and highlights the importance of investigating tissue-specific mtDNA depletion. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop potential therapeutic strategies.

SPECT imaging of pediatric brain tumor with hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I). The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging using hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I) ([99mTc]MIBI) in pediatric patients with brain tumors. A total of 23 patients (age range 2-12 years) with histologically confirmed brain tumors were included. SPECT imaging was performed after intravenous injection of [99mTc]MIBI. The SPECT images were compared to magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings for tumor localization and characterization.
